docs.name: Signal.Stream

aliases.name: Stream
aliases.comment:
Streams of events. Many interactions with the world can be formulated as
a stream of discrete events: mouse clicks, responses from servers, key presses,
etc.

values.name: fairMerge
values.comment: Like `merge`, but you get to decide which event wins when they come in at the same time.
values.type: (a -> a -> a) -> Signal.Stream.Stream a -> Signal.Stream.Stream a -> Signal.Stream.Stream a

values.name: filter
values.comment: Filter out and unwrap the `Just`s in the stream.

values.name: filterMap
values.comment:
Filter out some events. If the incoming event is mapped to a `Nothing` it
is dropped. If it is mapped to `Just` a value, we keep the value.

    numbers : Stream Int
    numbers =
        filterMap (\raw -> Result.toMaybe (String.toInt raw)) userInput

    userInput : Stream String
values.type: (a -> Maybe.Maybe b) -> Signal.Stream.Stream a -> Signal.Stream.Stream b

values.name: fold
values.comment:
Create a past-dependent value. Each update from the incoming stream will
be used to step the state forward. The outgoing signal represents the current
state.

    clickCount : Signal Int
    clickCount =
        fold (\click total -> total + 1) 0 Mouse.clicks

    timeSoFar : Stream Time
    timeSoFar =
        fold (+) 0 (fps 40)

So `clickCount` updates on each mouse click, incrementing by one. `timeSoFar`
is the time the program has been running, updated 40 times a second.
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> Signal.Stream.Stream a -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: fromSignal
values.comment:
Get a stream that triggers whenever the signal is *updated*. Note
that an update may result in the same value as before, so the resulting
`Stream` can have the same value twice in a row.

    moves : Stream (Int,Int)
    moves =
      fromSignal Mouse.position

values.name: keepIf
values.comment:
Filter out some events. The given function decides whether we should
keep an update. The following example only keeps even numbers.

    numbers : Stream Int

    isEven : Int -> Bool

    evens : Stream Int
    evens =
        keepIf isEven numbers

values.name: map
values.comment:
Apply a function to events as they come in. This lets you transform
streams.

    type Action = MouseClick | TimeDelta Float

    actions : Stream Action
    actions =
        map (always MouseClick) Mouse.clicks

values.name: merge
values.comment:
Merge two streams into one. This function is extremely useful for bringing
together lots of different streams to feed into a `fold`.

    type Action = MouseClick | TimeDelta Float

    actions : Stream Action
    actions =
        merge
            (map (always MouseClick) Mouse.clicks)
            (map TimeDelta (fps 40))

If an event comes from either of the incoming streams, it flows out the
outgoing stream. If an event comes on both streams at the same time, the left
event wins (i.e., the right event is discarded).
values.type: Signal.Stream.Stream a -> Signal.Stream.Stream a -> Signal.Stream.Stream a

values.name: mergeMany
values.comment:
Merge many streams into one. This is useful when you are merging more than
two streams. When multiple events come in at the same time, the left-most
event wins, just like with `merge`.

    type Action = MouseMove (Int,Int) | TimeDelta Float | Click

    actions : Stream Action
    actions =
        mergeMany
            [ map MouseMove Mouse.position
            , map TimeDelta (fps 40)
            , map (always Click) Mouse.clicks
            ]

values.name: never
values.comment:
A stream that never gets an update. This is useful when defining functions
like `mergeMany` which needs to be defined even when no streams are given.

    mergeMany : List (Stream a) -> Stream a
    mergeMany streams =
        List.foldr merge never streams

values.name: sample
values.comment:
Useful for augmenting a stream with information from a signal.
For example, if you are operating on a time delta but want to take the current
keyboard state into account.

    inputs : Stream ({ x:Int, y:Int }, Time)
    inputs =
        sample (,) Keyboard.arrows (fps 60)

Now we get events exactly with the `(fps 60)` stream, but they are augmented
with which arrows are pressed at the moment.
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Stream.Stream b -> Signal.Stream.Stream c

values.name: timestamp
values.comment:
Add a timestamp to any stream. Timestamps increase monotonically. When you
create `(timestamp Mouse.x)`, an initial timestamp is produced. The timestamp
updates whenever `Mouse.x` updates.

Timestamp updates are tied to individual events, so
`(timestamp Mouse.x)` and `(timestamp Mouse.y)` will always have the same
timestamp because they rely on the same underlying event (`Mouse.position`).

values.name: toSignal
values.comment:
Convert a stream of values into a signal that updates whenever an event
comes in on the stream.

    url : Signal String

    url =
        toSignal "waiting.gif" imageStream

    constant : a -> Signal a

    constant value =
        toSignal value Stream.never

docs.name: Signal.Time

aliases.name: Time
aliases.comment: Just re-exporting the `Time` type from the `Time` module

values.name: delay
values.comment:
A re-export of [Time.delay](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/1.0.0/Time#delay). 

Delay a signal by a certain amount of time. So `(delay second
Mouse.clicks)` will update one second later than any mouse click.

values.name: dropWithin
values.comment:
Drops all but the first update of a flurry of updates (a stutter).
The stutter is defined as updates that happen with max. the given time
in between. 

The first update of the given signal is sent through. Then the given
delay is waited. If no other updates arrive during that time, then next
update will be sent through. Any update that arrives within the given
time of the last update is dropped. 

    noDoubleClicks = dropWithin (300 * milliseconds) Mouse.clicks

Also known to some areas as an "immediate" `debounce` function.

values.name: limitRate
values.comment:
Limits the given signal to output a maximum of one message within
the given time period.

After an update of the given signal, for the given period subsequent
updates are dropped. The original update that started this dropping is
kept. 

    throttledMouseClicks = limitRate 60 Mouse.clicks

Also known in some areas as a `throttle` function.

values.name: relativeTime
values.comment:
Turns absolute time signal to time relative to the start of the
program. 

    let tick = Time.every Time.second
    in  Signal.foldp ((+) 1) 0 tick == 
          relativeTime tick ~> Time.inSeconds >> round

values.name: settledAfter
values.comment:
Gives the last update of a flurry of updates (a stutter) after has
settled* for the given time. The stutter is defined as updates that
happen within the given time. * Where settled the signal gets no further
updates for some time, it's **not** relating to the value changes of the
signal. 

After every update of the given signal, the given delay is waited. If no
other updates arrived during that time, the update is sent through. If a
new update arrives within the given time, the previous update is dropped
and the waiting is restarted. So `debounce`-ing a signal that keeps up
the flurry of updates all the time results in a signal that never
updates. 

    tooltip : Signal Bool
    tooltip = 
      merge (always False <~ Mouse.position) 
            (always True <~ (Mouse.position
                            |> settledAfter (500 * Time.millisecond)))

Also known in some areas as a `debounce` function.

values.name: since
values.comment:
A re-export of [Time.since](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/1.0.0/Time#since). 

Takes a time `t` and any signal. The resulting boolean signal is true
for time `t` after every event on the input signal. So ``(second `since`
Mouse.clicks)`` would result in a signal that is true for one second
after each mouse click and false otherwise.

values.name: startTime
values.comment: The timestamp of the start of the program.

values.name: timestamp
values.comment:
A re-export of [Time.timestamp](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/1.0.0/Time#timestamp). 

Add a timestamp to any signal. Timestamps increase monotonically. When
you create `(timestamp Mouse.x)`, an initial timestamp is produced. The
timestamp updates whenever `Mouse.x` updates.

Timestamp updates are tied to individual events, so `(timestamp
Mouse.x)` and `(timestamp Mouse.y)` will always have the same timestamp
because they rely on the same underlying event (`Mouse.position`).

docs.name: Signal.Fun
docs.comment:
Some utility functions for signals of functions. The question is:
Why are you dealing with signals of functions? Are you sure you want
this? It can be used to harm testability and separation of concerns,
which are endangered species and it's illegal to harm them! So please be
careful.

@docs scan, premap, postmap, bimap

values.name: bimap
values.comment:
Compose the given functions before and after every function that
comes through the signal respectively.
values.type: (a -> b) -> (c -> d) -> Signal.Fun.SF b c -> Signal.Fun.SF a d

values.name: postmap
values.comment:
Compose the given function after every function that comes through
the signal.
values.type: (c -> d) -> Signal.Fun.SF b c -> Signal.Fun.SF b d

values.name: premap
values.comment:
Compose the given function before every function that comes through
the signal.
values.type: (a -> b) -> Signal.Fun.SF b c -> Signal.Fun.SF a c

values.name: scan
values.comment:
Takes a starting value for a state; applies each new function coming
in to calculate the new state.
values.type: a -> Signal.Fun.SF a a -> Signal.Signal a

docs.name: Signal.Extra

values.comment:
An alias for `Signal.map`. A prettier way to apply a function to the current value
of a signal.

    main : Signal Html
    main =
      view <~ model

    model : Signal Model

    view : Model -> Html

values.name: andMap
values.comment:
Apply a signal of functions to another signal. Like `Task.andMap`, this
provides a way to combine several signals together into a data type that's
easier to extend than `map2`, `map3`, etc.

    type alias User =
        { name : String
        , age : Int
        , numberOfPosts : Int
        }

    userSignal : Signal User
    userSignal = User
        `Signal.map` nameSignal
        `andMap` ageSignal
        `andMap` numberOfPostsSignal
values.type: Signal.Signal (a -> b) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: applyMany
values.comment:
Apply functions in a signal to the current value of many signals.
The result is reevaluated whenever any signal changes.
values.type: Signal.Signal (List a -> b) -> List (Signal.Signal a) -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: combine
values.comment:
Combine a list of signals into a signal of lists. We have

      combine = mapMany identity

Also, whenever you are in a situation where you write something like

      Signal.map f (combine signals)

you are better off directly using `mapMany f signals`.

values.name: delayRound
values.comment:
Instead of delaying for some amount of time, delay for one round,
where a round is initiated by outside event to the Elm program.  
This may not be be very useful yet. Let the package author know if you
find a good use!  
Also known to `delay` in E-FRP.

values.name: deltas
values.comment:
A signal of each change to the provided signal, as a tuple of old
and new values.

The initial value of the tuple is the initial value of the provided signal,
duplicated. Thereafter, the first part of the tuple is the old value of the
provided signal, and the second part is the new value.

values.name: fairMerge
values.comment:
A function that merges the events of two signals without bias
(unlike `Signal.merge`). It takes a resolution function for the
(usually rare) case that the signals update in the same "round".

    fairMerge (\l r -> l) == merge
values.type: (a -> a -> a) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: filter
values.comment: Filter a signal of optional values, discarding `Nothing`s.

values.name: filterFold
values.comment: Apply a fold that may fail, ignore any non-changes.
values.type: (a -> b -> Maybe.Maybe b) -> b -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: foldp'
values.comment:
`foldp'` is slighty more general than `foldp` in that you can base
the initial value of the state on the initial value of the input value. 

    foldp f b s == foldp' f (always b) s
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> (a -> b) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: foldps
values.comment:
Like `foldp`, but with a hidden state

    foldp f b i ==
      let d a = (a,a) -- doubling function
      in foldps (\a b -> f a b |> d) (d b) i
values.type: (a -> s -> ( b, s )) -> ( b, s ) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: foldps'
values.comment: Like `foldp'`, but with a hidden state
values.type: (a -> s -> ( b, s )) -> (a -> ( b, s )) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: keepIf
values.comment: The old name for `Signal.filter`, which doesn't confuse you with what the `Bool` value means.
values.type: (a -> Bool) -> a -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: keepThen
values.comment:
Like `keepWhen`, but when the filter signal turn `False`, the output
changes back to the base value.
values.type: Signal.Signal Bool -> a -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: keepWhen
values.comment:
The good old `keepWhen` filter that keeps events from the `Signal a` as long as the
`Signal Bool` is true.
values.type: Signal.Signal Bool -> a -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: keepWhenI
values.comment:
`keepWhen` but always keeps the initial value rather than trying to
filter it.
values.type: Signal.Signal Bool -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: mapMany
values.comment:
Apply a function to the current value of many signals. The
function is reevaluated whenever any signal changes. A typical use case:

      mapMany (flow down) [sig_elem1, sig_elem2, sig_elem3]

Note how this is nicer (and more extendable) than the equivalent:

      Signal.map3 (\e1 e2 e3 -> flow down [e1, e2, e3]) sig_elem1 sig_elem2 sig_elem3

Also, `mapMany List.maximum : List (Signal comparable) -> Signal (Maybe comparable)`
gives a signal that always carries `Just` the maximum value from all its
input signals, unless the input signal list is empty, in which case the returned
signal is equivalent to `constant Nothing`.
values.type: (List a -> b) -> List (Signal.Signal a) -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: mergeMany
values.comment:
Merge each Signal in the given list into a given original Signal. This works
like Signal.mergeMany, except that it does not crash when given an empty list.

    type Update =
        MouseMove (Int,Int) | TimeDelta Float | Click


    updates : Signal Update
    updates =
        mergeMany
            (MouseMove Mouse.position)
            [ map TimeDelta (fps 40)
            , map (always Click) Mouse.clicks
            ]
values.type: Signal.Signal a -> List (Signal.Signal a) -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: passiveMap2
values.comment:
Apply a function to the current value of two signals. The second signal is
mapped passively -- that is, changes to the second signal do not force the
function to re-evaluate. However, when the first signal changes, the function
is re-evaluated with the current value of both signals.

This is equivalent to Signal.map2, except that Signal.map2 re-evaluates the
function when either Signal changes.
values.type: (a -> b -> result) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b -> Signal.Signal result

values.name: runBuffer
values.comment:
A running buffer of the given size (`n`) of the given signal. 
The list of at most `n` of the last values on the input signal. Starts
with an empty list. Adds new values to the *end* of the list! So you get
a list with time going from left to right. 

    ((==) [1,2,3,4,5]) <~ runBuffer 5 (count (Time.every second))

values.name: runBuffer'
values.comment: Same as `runBuffer` but with an initial buffer.
values.type: List a -> Int -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal (List a)

values.name: sampleWhen
values.comment:
A combination of `Signal.sampleOn` and `keepWhen`. When the
first signal becomes `True`, the most recent value of the second signal
will be propagated.  
[Before Elm 0.12](
https://github.com/elm-lang/elm-compiler/blob/master/changelog.md#012)
 this was the standard behaviour of `keepWhen`.
values.type: Signal.Signal Bool -> a -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: switchSample
values.comment: Same as the previous, but samples the signal it switches to.
values.type: Signal.Signal Bool -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: switchWhen
values.comment:
Switch between two signals. When the first signal is `True`, use the
 second signal, otherwise use the third.
values.type: Signal.Signal Bool -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: unzip
values.comment:
Unzip a signal of pairs to a pair of signals. 

    unzip Mouse.position == (Mouse.x, Mouse.y)
values.type: Signal.Signal ( a, b ) -> ( Signal.Signal a, Signal.Signal b )

values.name: unzip3
values.type: Signal.Signal ( a, b, c ) -> ( Signal.Signal a, Signal.Signal b, Signal.Signal c )

values.name: unzip4
values.type: Signal.Signal ( a, b, c, d ) -> ( Signal.Signal a , Signal.Signal b , Signal.Signal c , Signal.Signal d )

values.name: withPassive
values.comment:
Intended to be paired with Signal's `(<~)` operator, `withPassive` makes it
possible for many signals to be passively mapped. For example, the
following two declarations are equivalent:

    main : Signal Element
    main =
      scene <~ Mouse.position `withPassive` Window.dimensions

    main : Signal Element
    main =
      passiveMap2 scene Mouse.position Window.dimensions

You can use this pattern to passively map as many signals as you want, by using
`withPassive` many times.

The function will only be re-evaluated when the signal mapped with `(<~)`
changes. This is unlike the (otherwise equivalent) Signal `(~)` operator, since
that operator re-evaluates the function whenever any of the input signals change.

If you want the function to be re-evaluated when some signals change but not
others, then you can combine the Signal `(~)` operator and `withPassive`, putting
`(~)` first. For instance:

    main : Signal Element
    main =
        scene <~ Mouse.position ~ Window.dimensions `withPassive` anotherSignal

In this example, the `scene` function will take three parameters, and will be called
whenever either of the first two parameters changes. The third parameter will
be the value of `anotherSignal`, but changes to `anotherSignal` will not cause
the function to be re-evaluated.
values.type: Signal.Signal (a -> b) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: zip
values.comment:
Zip two signals into a signal of pairs.

    zip Mouse.x Mouse.y == Mouse.position
values.type: Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b -> Signal.Signal ( a, b )

values.name: zip3
values.type: Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b -> Signal.Signal c -> Signal.Signal ( a, b, c )

values.name: zip4
values.type: Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b -> Signal.Signal c -> Signal.Signal d -> Signal.Signal ( a, b, c, d )

values.comment:
An alias for `andMap`. Intended to be paired with the `(<~)` operator, this
makes it possible for many signals to flow into a function. Think of it as a
fancy alias for `mapN`.  For example, the following declarations are equivalent:

    main : Signal Element
    main =
      scene <~ Window.dimensions ~ Mouse.position

    main : Signal Element
    main =
      map2 scene Window.dimensions Mouse.position

You can use this pattern for as many signals as you want by using `(~)` a bunch
of times, so you can go higher than `map5` if you need to.
values.type: Signal.Signal (a -> b) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b

values.comment:
The `(<~)` operator, but flipped. Doesn't play well with the other
two!

    Mouse.x ~> toFloat >> sqrt >> round
            >> isEven >> not
            >> asText

docs.name: Signal.Discrete

aliases.name: EventSource
aliases.comment:
At some point in the future Elm will probably support something like
this:

    type alias EventSource = Signal _

That is, `EventSource` will become an alias for any `Signal a` where we
hide the `a` part.  
Until then, there is the `es` function to create an EventSource

values.name: es
values.comment: Simple way to make an event signal from any signal

values.name: folde
values.comment:
`foldp` on an `EventSource`.

    toggleOnEnter = folde not False <| whenChangeTo True Keyboard.enter

values.name: whenChange
values.comment: Fires when the value of the input signal changes.

values.name: whenChangeTo
values.comment:
Fires when the value of the input signal changes to the given value.

    spacebarPress = whenChangeTo True Keyboard.spacebar

values.name: whenEqual
values.comment:
Fires when the value of the input signal is equal to the given
value.

**NB:** Repeated updates to the same value will make the `EventSource`
fire repeatedly.  
See also: [`whenChangeTo`](#whenChangeTo). 

    Mouse.clicks == whenEqual True Mouse.isDown

docs.name: Combine.Num

values.name: digit
values.comment: Parse a digit.

values.name: float
values.comment: Parse a float.

values.name: int
values.comment: Parse an integer.

values.name: sign
values.comment:
Parse a numeric sign, returning `1` for positive numbers and `-1`
for negative numbers.

docs.name: Combine.Char

values.name: anyChar
values.comment:
Parse any character.

    parse anyChar "a" ==
      (Ok 'a', { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse anyChar "" ==
      (Err ["expected any character"], { input = "", position = 0 })

values.name: char
values.comment:
Parse an exact character match.

    parse (char 'a') "a" ==
      (Ok 'a', { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse (char 'a') "b" ==
      (Err ["expected 'a'"], { input = "b", position = 0 })

values.name: crlf
values.comment: Parse a `\r\n` sequence, returning a `\n` character.

values.name: digit
values.comment: Parse any base 10 digit.

values.name: eol
values.comment: Parse an end of line character or sequence, returning a `\n` character.

values.name: hexDigit
values.comment: Parse any base 16 digit.

values.name: lower
values.comment: Parse any lowercase character.

values.name: newline
values.comment: Parse a `\n` character.

values.name: noneOf
values.comment:
Parse a character that is not in the given list.

    parse (noneOf ['a', 'b']) "c" ==
      (Ok 'c', { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse (noneOf ['a', 'b']) "a" ==
      (Err ["expected none of ['a','b']"], { input = "a", position = 0 })

values.name: octDigit
values.comment: Parse any base 8 digit.

values.name: oneOf
values.comment:
Parse a character from the given list.

    parse (oneOf ['a', 'b']) "a" ==
      (Ok 'a', { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse (oneOf ['a', 'b']) "c" ==
      (Err ["expected one of ['a','b']"], { input = "c", position = 0 })

values.name: satisfy
values.comment:
Parse a character matching the predicate.

    parse (satisfy ((==) 'a')) "a" ==
      (Ok 'a', { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse (satisfy ((==) 'a')) "b" ==
      (Err ["could not satisfy predicate"], { input = "b", position = 0 })

values.name: space
values.comment: Parse a space character.

values.name: tab
values.comment: Parse a `\t` character.

values.name: upper
values.comment: Parse any uppercase character.

docs.name: Combine.Infix

values.comment:
Join two parsers, ignoring the result of the one on the left.

    unprefix : Parser String
    unprefix = string ">" *> while ((==) ' ') *> while ((/=) ' ')

    parse unprefix "> a" == (Ok "a", { input = "", position = 3 })
values.type: Combine.Parser x -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser res

values.comment: Variant of `Combine.map` that ignores the Parser's result.
Synonym for `Combine.map`.

Join two parsers, ignoring the result of the one on the right.

    unsuffix : Parser String
    unsuffix = regex "[a-z]" <* regex "[!?]"

    parse unsuffix "a!" == (Ok "a", { input = "", position = 2 })
values.type: Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser x -> Combine.Parser res

values.comment: Synonym for `Combine.andMap`.
values.type: Combine.Parser (res -> res') -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser res'

values.comment:
Variant of `Combine.mapError` that replaces the Parser's error
with a List of a single string.

    parse (string "a" <?> "gimme an 'a'") "b" ==
      (Err ["gimme an 'a'"], { input = "b", position = 0 })
Synonym for `or`.
values.type: Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser res

docs.name: Combine

aliases.name: Context
aliases.comment: The contex over which `Parser`s operate.

types.name: Parser
types.comment:
The Parser type.

At their core, `Parser`s simply wrap functions from a `Context` to a
tuple of a `Result res` and a new `Context`.

values.name: andMap
values.comment:
Sequence two parsers.

    import Maybe
    import Result
    import String

    num : Parser Int
    num = (Maybe.withDefault 0 << Result.toMaybe << String.toInt) `map` regex "[0-9]+"

    sum : Parser Int
    sum = (+) `map` (num <* string "+") `andMap` num

    parse sum "1+2" ==
      (Ok 3, { input = "", position = 3 })
values.type: Combine.Parser (a -> res) -> Combine.Parser a -> Combine.Parser res

values.name: andThen
values.comment:
Sequence two parsers, passing the result of the first parser to a
function that returns the second parser. The value of the second
parser is returned on success.

    import Combine.Num exposing (int)

    choosy : Parser String
    choosy =
      int
        `andThen` \x -> if x % 2 == 0
                        then string " is even"
                        else string " is odd"

    parse choosy "1 is odd" ==
      (Ok " is odd", { input = "", position = 8 })

    parse choosy "1 is even" ==
      (Err ["expected \" is odd\""], { input = " is even", position = 1 })
values.type: Combine.Parser res -> (res -> Combine.Parser res') -> Combine.Parser res'

values.name: app
values.comment: Unwrap a parser so it can be applied to a context.
values.type: Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Context -> ( Combine.Result res, Combine.Context )

values.name: between
values.comment:
Parse something between two other parsers.

The parser

    between (string "(") (string ")") (string "a")

is equivalent to the parser

    string "(" *> string "a" <* string ")"
values.type: Combine.Parser left -> Combine.Parser right -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser res

values.name: bimap
values.comment: Transform both the result and error message of a parser.
values.type: (res -> res') -> (List String -> List String) -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser res'

values.name: braces
values.comment: Parse something between braces `{}`.

values.name: brackets
values.comment: Parse something between square brackets `[]`.

values.name: chainl
values.comment:
Parse one or more occurences of `p` separated by `op`, recursively
apply all functions returned by `op` to the values returned by `p`. See
the `examples/Calc.elm` file for an example.
values.type: Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser (res -> res -> res) -> Combine.Parser res

values.name: chainr
values.comment:
Similar to `chainl` but functions of `op` are applied in
right-associative order to the values of `p`.
values.type: Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser (res -> res -> res) -> Combine.Parser res

values.name: choice
values.comment:
Choose between a list of parsers.

    parse (choice [string "a", string "b"]) "a" ==
      (Ok "a", { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse (choice [string "a", string "b"]) "b" ==
      (Ok "b", { input = "", position = 1 })

values.name: count
values.comment: Parse `n` occurences of `p`.

values.name: end
values.comment:
Fail when the input is not empty.

    parse end "" == (Ok (), { input = "", position = 0 })
    parse end "a" == (Err ["expected end of input"], { input = "a", position = 0 })

values.name: fail
values.comment: Fail without consuming any input.

values.name: many
values.comment:
Apply a parser until it fails and return a list of the results.

    parse (many (string "a")) "aaab" ==
      (Ok ["a", "a", "a"], { input = "b", position = 3 })

    parse (many (string "a")) "" ==
      (Ok [], { input = "", position = 0 })

values.name: many1
values.comment:
Parse at least one result.

    parse (many1 (string "a")) "a" ==
      (Ok ["a"], { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse (many1 (string "a")) "" ==
      (Err ["expected \"a\""], { input = "", position = 0 })

values.name: manyTill
values.comment:
Apply parser `p` zero or more times until parser `end`
succeeds. On success, the list of `p`'s results is returned.

    string "<!--" *> manyTill anyChar (string "-->")
values.type: Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser end -> Combine.Parser (List res)

values.name: map
values.comment:
Transform the result of a parser.

    parse (map String.toUpper (string "a")) "a" ==
      (Ok "A", { input = "", position = 1 })

values.name: mapError
values.comment:
Transform the error of a parser.

    parse (mapError (\_ -> ["bad input"]) (string "a")) "b" ==
      (Err ["bad input"], { input = "b", position = 0 })
values.type: (List String -> List String) -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser res

values.name: maybe
values.comment:
Wrap the return value into a `Maybe`. Returns `Nothing` on failure.

    parse (maybe (string "a")) "a" ==
      (Ok (Just "a"), { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse (maybe (string "a")) "b" ==
      (Ok Nothing, { input = "b", position = 0 })

values.name: optional
values.comment:
Return a default value when the given parser fails.

    letterA : Parser String
    letterA = optional "a" (string "a")

    parse letterA "a" == (Ok "a", { input = "", position = 1 })
    parse letterA "b" == (Ok "a", { input = "b", position = 0 })

values.name: or
values.comment:
Choose between two parsers.

    parse (string "a" `or` string "b") "a" ==
      (Ok "a", { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse (string "a" `or` string "b") "b" ==
      (Ok "b", { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse (string "a" `or` string "b") "c" ==
      (Err ["expected \"a\"", "expected \"b\""], { input = "c", position = 0 })
values.type: Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser res

values.name: parens
values.comment: Parse something between parentheses.

values.name: parse
values.comment:
Parse a string.

    import Combine.Num exposing (int)

    parse int "123" ==
      (Ok 123, { input = "", position = 3 })

    parse int "abc" ==
      (Err ["expected an integer"], { input = "abc", position = 0 })
values.type: Combine.Parser res -> String -> ( Combine.Result res, Combine.Context )

values.name: primitive
values.comment:
Construct a new primitive Parser.

If you find yourself reaching for this function often consider opening
a [Github issue](https://github.com/Bogdanp/elm-combine/issues) with
the library to have your custom Parsers included in the standard
distribution.

values.name: rec
values.comment:
Defer a parser's evaluation.

    type E = ETerm String | EList (List E)

    whitespace : Parser String
    whitespace = regex "[ \t\r\n]*"

    term : Parser E
    term = ETerm `map` (whitespace *> regex "[a-zA-Z]+" <* whitespace)

    list : Parser E
    list = rec (\() -> EList `map` (string "(" *> many (term `or` list) <* string ")"))

    parse list "" ==
      (Err ["expected \"(\""], { input = "", position = 0 })

    parse list "()" ==
      (Ok (EList []), { input = "", position = 2 })

    parse list "(a (b c))" ==
      (Ok (EList [ETerm "a", EList [ETerm "b", ETerm "c"]]), { input = "", position = 9 })

values.name: regex
values.comment:
Parse a Regex match.

Regular expressions must match from the beginning of the input and their
subgroups are ignored. A `^` is added implicitly to the beginning of
every pattern unless one already exists.

    parse (regex "a+") "aaaaab" ==
      (Ok "aaaaa", { input = "b", position = 5 })

values.name: sepBy
values.comment:
Parser zero or more occurences of one parser separated by another.

    parse (sepBy (string ",") (string "a")) "b" ==
      (Ok [], { input = "b", position = 0 })

    parse (sepBy (string ",") (string "a")) "a,a,a" ==
      (Ok ["a", "a", "a"], { input = "", position = 5 })

    parse (sepBy (string ",") (string "a")) "a,a,b" ==
      (Ok ["a", "a"], { input = ",b", position = 3 })
values.type: Combine.Parser x -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser (List res)

values.name: sepBy1
values.comment: Parse one or more occurences of one parser separated by another.
values.type: Combine.Parser x -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser (List res)

values.name: sepEndBy
values.comment:
Parse zero or more occurences of one parser separated and
optionally ended by another.

    parse (sepEndBy (string ",") (string "a")) "a,a,a," ==
      (Ok ["a", "a", "a"], { input = "", position = 6 })
values.type: Combine.Parser x -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser (List res)

values.name: sepEndBy1
values.comment:
Parse one or more occurences of one parser separated and
optionally ended by another.

    parse (sepEndBy1 (string ",") (string "a")) "" ==
      (Err ["expected \"a\""], { input = "", position = 0 })

    parse (sepEndBy1 (string ",") (string "a")) "a" ==
      (Ok ["a"], { input = "", position = 1 })

    parse (sepEndBy1 (string ",") (string "a")) "a," ==
      (Ok ["a"], { input = "", position = 2 })
values.type: Combine.Parser x -> Combine.Parser res -> Combine.Parser (List res)

values.name: sequence
values.comment:
Run a list of parsers in sequence, accumulating the results.

    parse (sequence [string "a", string "b"]) "ab" ==
      (Ok ["a", "b"], { input = "", position = 2 })

    parse (sequence [string "a", string "b"]) "ac" ==
      (Err ["expected \"b\"", { input = "c", position = 1 })

values.name: skip
values.comment: Apply a parser and skip its result.

values.name: skipMany
values.comment: Apply a parser and skip its result many times.

values.name: skipMany1
values.comment: Apply a parser and skip its result at least once.

values.name: string
values.comment:
Parse an exact string match.

    parse (string "hello") "hello world" ==
      (Ok "hello", { input = " world", position = 5 })

    parse (string "hello") "goodbye" ==
      (Err ["expected \"hello\""], { input = "goodbye", position = 0 })

values.name: succeed
values.comment:
Return a value without consuming any input.

    parse (succeed 1) "a" ==
      (Ok 1, { input = "a", position = 0 })

values.name: while
values.comment:
Consume input while the predicate matches.

    parse (while ((/=) ' ')) "test 123" ==
      (Ok "test", { input = " 123", position = 4 })

docs.name: Generate

types.name: Generator
types.comment:
Generators are lists whose transformations are applied lazily as
items are requested.  This makes is so that expressions like:

    import Generate as G

    G.fromList [1, 2, 3]
      |> G.map ((+) 1)
      |> G.filter (\x -> x % 2 == 0)
      |> G.map toString
      |> G.toList

Only end up iterating through the list once while still providing the
same results as their List module counterparts.

values.name: all
values.comment:
Determine if all of the Generator's elements match the predicate.

    > fromList [2, 4, 6] |> all (\x -> x % 2 == 0)
    True : Bool

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> all (\x -> x % 2 == 0)
    False : Bool

values.name: any
values.comment:
Determine if any of the Generator's elements match the predicate.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> any (\x -> x % 2 == 0)
    True : Bool

    > fromList [1, 3, 5] |> any (\x -> x % 2 == 0)
    False : Bool

values.name: drop
values.comment:
Drop the first `n` elements from a Generator.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> drop 1 |> toList
    [2, 3] : List number

*Note*: This function is applied to the *original* list:

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> filter ((/=) 1) |> drop 1 |> toList
    [2, 3] : List number
values.type: Int -> Generate.Generator a b -> Generate.Generator a b

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Filter the elements of a Generator.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> filter (flip (>) 1) |> toList
    [2, 3] : List number
values.type: (b -> Bool) -> Generate.Generator a b -> Generate.Generator a b

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Fold a Generator from the left.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> foldl (::) []
    [3, 2, 1] : List number
values.type: (b -> c -> c) -> c -> Generate.Generator a b -> c

values.name: foldr
values.comment:
Fold a Generator from the right.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> foldr (::) []
    [1, 2, 3] : List number
values.type: (b -> c -> c) -> c -> Generate.Generator a b -> c

values.name: fromList
values.comment:
Construct a Generator from a List.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3]
    Generator { items = [1,2,3], transform = <function> }
      : Generate.Generator number number

values.name: length
values.comment:
Compute the length of a Generator.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> length
    3 : Int

values.name: map
values.comment:
Transform the elements of a Generator.


    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> map ((+) 1) |> toList
    [2, 3, 4] : List number
values.type: (b -> c) -> Generate.Generator a b -> Generate.Generator a c

values.name: next
values.comment:
Get the next element in the generator after transforming it.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> filter ((/=) 1) |> next
    (Just 2, Generator { items = [3], transform = <function> })
      : ( Maybe.Maybe number, Generate.Generator number number )

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> filter ((==) 5) |> next
    (Nothing, Generator { items = [], transform = <function> })
      : ( Maybe.Maybe number, Generate.Generator number number )
values.type: Generate.Generator a b -> ( Maybe.Maybe b, Generate.Generator a b )

values.name: product
values.comment:
Compute the product of the Generator's elements.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> product
    6 : number

values.name: remove
values.comment:
Remove elements that match the given predicate from the Generator.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> remove (\x -> x % 2 == 0) |> toList
    [1, 3] : List number
values.type: (b -> Bool) -> Generate.Generator a b -> Generate.Generator a b

values.name: reverse
values.comment: Reverse a Generator's elements.
values.type: Generate.Generator a b -> Generate.Generator a b

values.name: singleton
values.comment:
Construct a Generator from a single value.

    > singleton 1
    Generator { items = [1], transform = <function> }
      : Generate.Generator number number

values.name: sum
values.comment:
Compute the product of the Generator's elements.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> sum
    6 : number

values.name: take
values.comment:
Take the first `n` elements from a Generator.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> take 1 |> toList
    [1] : List number

*Note*: This function is applied to the *original* list:

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> filter ((/=) 1) |> take 1 |> toList
    [] : List number
values.type: Int -> Generate.Generator a b -> Generate.Generator a b

values.name: toList
values.comment:
Construct a List from a Generator.

    > fromList [1, 2, 3] |> toList
    [1, 2, 3] : List number

docs.name: Route.QueryString
docs.comment:
This module exposes functions for working with query strings.

You can manipulate query strings:

    empty
      |> add "a" "hello"
      |> add "a" "goodbye"
      |> add "b" "1"
      |> render

And you can parse and extract their parameters:

    let
      qs = parse "?a=1&a=2&a=test&b=hello"
      a = many int qs
      b = one string qs |> Maybe.withDefault "goodbye"
    in
      (a, b)

## Types
@docs QueryString

## Constructing QueryStrings
@docs parse, empty

## Manipulating parameters
@docs render, add, remove, filter

## Extracting parameters
@docs all, one, many

### Parsers
@docs string, int

types.name: QueryString
types.comment: Represents a parsed query string.

values.name: add
values.comment:
Add a value to a key.

    > parse "?a=1&b=a&a=c" |> add "a" "2" |> render
    "?a=2&a=1&a=c&b=a" : String

    > parse "?a=1&b=a&a=c" |> add "d" "hello" |> render
    "?a=1&a=c&b=a&d=hello" : String

values.name: all
values.comment:
Retrieve all of the values for a given key.

    > parse "?a=1&a=2" |> all "a"
    ["1","2"] : List String

    > parse "?a=1&a=2" |> all "b"
    [] : List String

values.name: empty
values.comment: Construct an empty QueryString.

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Filter a key's values.

    > parse "?a=1&b=a&a=c" |> filter "a" ((==) "1") |> render
    "?a=1&b=a" : String

values.name: int
values.comment: A Parser that accepts any integer.

values.name: many
values.comment:
Retrieve zero or more values for some key. Values are funneled
through the given parser before being returned.

    > parse "?a=1&a=c&a=2" |> many int "a"
    [1,2] : List Int
values.type: Combine.Parser a -> String -> Route.QueryString.QueryString -> List a

values.name: one
values.comment:
Retrieve a single value for a given key. Values are funneled through
the given parser before being returned.

    > parse "?a=1&a=2" |> one string "a"
    Just "2" : Maybe.Maybe String

    > parse "?a=1&a=2" |> one int "a"
    Just 2 : Maybe.Maybe Int

    > parse "?a=1&a=c" |> one int "a"
    Just 1 : Maybe.Maybe Int
values.type: Combine.Parser a -> String -> Route.QueryString.QueryString -> Maybe.Maybe a

values.name: parse
values.comment:
Turn a String into a QueryString. The initial `?` is optional.

    > parse ""
    QueryString (Dict.fromList []) : Route.QueryString.QueryString

    > parse "?a=1&b=c&a=2"
    QueryString (Dict.fromList [("a",["1","2"]),("b",["c"])])
        : Route.QueryString.QueryString

    > parse "a=1&b=c&a=2"
    QueryString (Dict.fromList [("a",["1","2"]),("b",["c"])])
        : Route.QueryString.QueryString

values.name: remove
values.comment:
Remove a key.

    > parse "?a=1&b=a&a=c" |> remove "a" |> render
    "?b=a" : String

    > parse "?a=1&b=a&a=c" |> remove "c" |> render
    "?a=1&a=c&b=a" : String

values.name: render
values.comment:
Render a QueryString to a String.

    > parse "?a=1&b=a&a=c" |> render
    "?a=1&a=c&b=a" : String

values.name: string
values.comment: A Parser that accepts any string.

docs.name: Route

types.name: Route
types.comment:
Routes represent concrete parsers for paths. Routes can be combined
and they keep track of their path components in order to provide
automatic reverse routing.

types.name: Router
types.comment:
A Router is, at its core, a List of Routes.

    sitemap = router [routeA, routeB]

values.comment:
A synonym for `route`.

    type Sitemap
      = HomeR ()

    homeR : Route Sitemap
    homeR = HomeR := static ""

A synonym for `prefix`.

    type Sitemap
      = UserR Int

    userR = UserR := "users" <//> int
    sitemap = router [userR]

    > match sitemap "/users/"
    Nothing : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match sitemap "/users/1"
    Just (UserR 1) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

A synonym for `and`.

    type Sitemap
      = AddR (Int, Int)

    addR = AddR := int </> int
    sitemap = router [addR]

    > match sitemap "/1/2"
    Just (AddR (1,2)) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap
values.type: Route.Route a -> Route.Route b -> Route.Route ( a, b )

values.comment:
A synonym for `suffix`.

    type Sitemap
      = UserEmailsR Int
      = UserEmailsR' (Int, ())

    userEmailsR = UserEmailsR := "users" <//> int <> "emails"
    userEmailsR' = UserEmailsR' := "users" <//> int </> static "emails"
    sitemap = router [userEmailsR, userEmailsR']

    > match sitemap "/users/1/emails"
    Just (UserEmailsR 1) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match sitemap "/users/1/emails-static"
    Just (UserEmailsR' (1,())) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

values.name: and
values.comment:
Compose two Routes.

    type Sitemap
      = AddR (Int, Int)

    addR = AddR := int `and` int
    sitemap = router [addR]

    > match sitemap "/1/2"
    Just (AddR (1,2)) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap
values.type: Route.Route a -> Route.Route b -> Route.Route ( a, b )

values.name: child
values.comment:
Routers may be nested. This function is useful in situations
where you want to split your routes into multiple types while still
maintaining a single top-level "site map".

    type AdminSitemap
      = AdminHomeR ()
      | AdminUsersR ()

    adminHomeR = AdminHomeR := static "admin"
    adminUsersR = AdminHomeR := "admin" <//> static "users"
    adminSitemap = router [adminHomeR, adminUsersR]

    type Sitemap
      = HomeR ()
      | BlogR ()
      | AdminR AdminSitemap

    homeR = HomeR := static ""
    blogR = BlogR := static "blog"
    sitemap = router [homeR, blogR, child AdminR adminSitemap]

See `examples/Reuse.elm` for a more advanced use case of this.

values.name: custom
values.comment:
Create a Route with a custom Parser.

    import Combine exposing (..)
    import Combine.Infix exposing (..)

    type Category
      = Snippet
      | Post

    type Sitemap
      = CategoryR Category

    categoryR = CategoryR := "categories" <//> custom categoryParser
    sitemap = router [categoryR]

    > match sitemap "/categories/a"
    Nothing : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match sitemap "/categories/Post"
    Just (CategoryR Post) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match sitemap "/categories/Snippet"
    Just (CategoryR Snippet) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

See `examples/Custom.elm` for a complete example.

values.name: int
values.comment:
A Route that matches any integer.

    type Sitemap
      = UserR Int

    userR = UserR := "users" <//> int
    sitemap = router [userR]

    > match sitemap "/users/a"
    Nothing : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match sitemap "/users/1"
    Just (UserR 1) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match sitemap "/users/-1"
    Just (UserR -1) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

values.name: match
values.comment:
Given a Router and an arbitrary String representing a path, this
function will return the first Route that matches that path.

    type Sitemap
      = HomeR ()
      | UsersR ()
      | UserR Int

    homeR = HomeR := static ""
    usersR = UsersR := static "users"
    usersR = UserR := "users" <//> int
    sitemap = router [homeR, userR, usersR]

    > match siteMap "/a"
    Nothing : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match siteMap "/"
    Just (HomeR ()) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match siteMap "/users"
    Just (UsersR ()) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match siteMap "/users/1"
    Just (UserR 1) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match siteMap "/users/1"
    Just (UserR 1) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

values.name: prefix
values.comment:
Prefix a `Route` with a string.

    type Sitemap
      = UserR Int

    userR = UserR := prefix "users" int
    sitemap = router [userR]

    > match sitemap "/users/"
    Nothing : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match sitemap "/users/1"
    Just (UserR 1) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

values.name: reverse
values.comment:
Render a path given a route and a list of route components.

    type Sitemap
      = HomeR ()
      | UsersR ()
      | UserR Int

    homeR = HomeR := static ""
    usersR = UsersR := static "users"
    usersR = UserR := "users" <//> int
    sitemap = router [homeR, userR, usersR]

    > reverse homeR []
    "/"

    > reverse usersR []
    "/users"

    > reverse userR ["1"]
    "/users/1"

If you are willing to write some boilerplate, this function can be used
to construct a reasonably-safe reverse routing function specific to your
application:

    render : Sitemap -> String
    render r =
      case r of
        HomeR () -> reverse homeR []
        UsersR () -> reverse usersR []
        UserR uid -> reverse userR [toString uid]

    > render (HomeR ())
    "/"

    > render (UsersR ())
    "/users"

    > render (UserR 1)
    "/users/1"

This function will crash at runtime if there is a mismatch between the
route and the list of arguments that is passed in. For example:

    > reverse deepR []
    Error: Ran into a `Debug.crash` in module `Route`

    This was caused by the `case` expression between lines 145 and 175.
    One of the branches ended with a crash and the following value got through:

        ([],[CInt,CInt,CInt])

    The message provided by the code author is:

        'reverse' called with an unexpected number of arguments

    > reverse deepR ["a"]
    Error: Ran into a `Debug.crash` in module `Route`

    This was caused by the `case` expression between lines 171 and 176.
    One of the branches ended with a crash and the following value got through:

        Err ("could not convert string 'a' to an Int")

    The message provided by the code author is:

        could not convert string 'a' to an Int in a call to 'reverse'

values.name: route
values.comment:
Declare a Route.

    type Sitemap
      = HomeR ()

    homeR : Route Sitemap
    homeR = route HomeR (static "")

values.name: router
values.comment:
Construct a Router from a list of Routes.

    type Sitemap
      = HomeR ()
      | BlogR ()

    homeR = HomeR := static ""
    blogR = BlogR := static "blog"
    sitemap = router [homeR, blogR]

values.name: static
values.comment:
Create a Route that matches a static String.

    type Sitemap
      = BlogR ()

    blogR = BlogR := static "blog"
    sitemap = router [blogR]

    > match sitemap "/blog"
    Just (BlogR ()) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

values.name: string
values.comment:
A Route that matches any string.

    type Sitemap
      = PostR String

    postR = PostR := "posts" <//> string
    sitemap = router [postR]

    > match sitemap "/posts/"
    Nothing : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match sitemap "/posts/hello-world/test"
    Nothing : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match sitemap "/posts/hello-world"
    Just (PostR "hello-world") : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

values.name: suffix
values.comment:
Suffix a `Route` with a string. This can be used in place
of `static` when there are static path components at the end of a
path.

    type Sitemap
      = UserEmailsR Int
      = UserEmailsR' (Int, ())

    userEmailsR = UserEmailsR := suffix "emails" (prefix "users" int)
    userEmailsR' = UserEmailsR' := prefix "users" int `and` static "emails-static"
    sitemap = router [userEmailsR, userEmailsR']

    > match sitemap "/users/1/emails"
    Just (UserEmailsR 1) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

    > match sitemap "/users/1/emails-static"
    Just (UserEmailsR' (1,())) : Maybe.Maybe Sitemap

docs.name: Cardinal
docs.comment:
Cardinal Numbers
(maybe this is the wrong name)
A number that can either be finite or infinite

@docs Cardinal, toCardinal, withDefault, withDefaults, map

types.name: Cardinal
types.comment: Cardinal number can be Positive or Negative Infinity

values.name: map
values.comment: Not a Functor, but still mappable

values.name: withDefault

Get the value out of `Cardinal` providing a default for the infinite cases.
First argument is the default for the `PosInfinity` case, the second is for `NegInfinity`

docs.name: Nearly
docs.comment: @docs nearly, (~=)

values.name: nearly
values.comment:
Nearly is used to curry an epsillon into a fuzzy equality.
For example:

```
True == let toThreePlaces = nearly 0.0001
        in 0.1234588 `toThreePlaces` 0.1234565
```

Pre-baked fuzzy equality, with `1.0e-5` as epsillon.
```
(~=) = nearly 1.0e-5
```

docs.name: Sprite
docs.comment:
A few simple things for Sprite rendering with elm-html.

Usage is intended to be via the `sprite` function generating
styles for `Html.Attributes.style`. For example

```
node
    "sprite"
    [ style (sprite s) ]
    []
```

@docs Sprite, Dope, sprite, advance, advanceClamp

aliases.name: Dope
aliases.comment: The ordered frame cordinates representing an animation

aliases.name: Sprite
aliases.comment: A sprite sheet
aliases.type: { a | sheet : String, rows : Int, columns : Int, size : ( Int, Int ), frame : Int, dope : Sprite.Dope }

values.name: advance
values.comment: Move the sprite forward one frame, such that it will loop when it reaches the end

values.name: advanceClamp
values.comment: Move the sprite forward one frame, such that it will stop when it reaches the end

values.name: sprite
values.comment:
Process a sprite into styles for application with
`elm-html`. Styles place the sprite sheet as a `background-image`
and animate by altering the `background-position`. `height`, `width`
are used for sizing, along with `display:block` for custom nodes.

docs.name: Flex

types.name: Alignment
types.comment:
The `Alignment` type specifies all the values possible for the `alignItems`
and `justifyConteent` mixins.

  - Start: Content is left-aligned.
  - Center: Content is center-aligned.
  - End: Content is right-aligned.
  - Stretch: Content-width is stretched to fill up the space.
  - Surround: Extra space is devided into equal spaces around the content.

types.name: Direction
types.comment:
The `Direction` type specifies all the direction values possible for the
`flexDirection` mixin.

  - Horizontal: Default value. The flexible items are displayed horizontally, as a row.
  - Vertical: The flexible items are displayed vertically, as a column.
  - HorizontalReverse: Same as `Horizontal`, but in reverse order.
  - verticalReverse: Same as `Vertical`, but in reverse order.

types.name: WrapValue
types.comment:
The `WrapValue` type specifies all the wrapping values possible for the
`wrap` mixin.

  - Wrap: Specifies that the flexible items will wrap if necessary.
  - NoWrap: Default value. Specifies that the flexible items will not wrap.
  - WrapReverse: Specifies that the flexible items will wrap, if necessary, in reverse order.

values.name: alignItems
values.comment:
The `alignItems` mixin specifies the default alignment for items inside
the flexible container.

values.name: alignSelf
values.comment:
The `alignSelf` mixin specifies the alignment for the selected item inside
the flexible container.

values.name: basis
values.comment: The `basis` mixin specifies the initial length of a flexible item.

values.name: direction
values.comment: The `direction` mixin specifies the direction of the flexible items.

values.name: display
values.comment: Displays an element as an block-level flex container.

values.name: flex
values.comment:
The `flex` mixin specifies the length of the item, relative to the rest of
the flexible items inside the same container.

It's a style shorthand for flexGrow, flexShrink and flexBasis
values.type: Float -> Float -> String -> List ( String, String )

values.name: flow
values.comment:
The `flow` mixin specifies how much the item will grow relative to the rest
of the flexible items inside the same container.

values.name: grow
values.comment:
The `grow` mixin specifies how much the item will grow relative to the rest
of the flexible items inside the same container.

values.name: justifyContent
values.comment:
The `justifyContent` mixin aligns the flexible container's items when the
items do not use all available space on the main-axis.

values.name: order
values.comment:
The `order` mixin specifies the order of a flexible item relative to the
rest of the flexible items inside the same container.

values.name: shrink
values.comment:
The `shrink` mixin specifies how the item will shrink relative to the rest
of the flexible items inside the same container.

values.name: wrap
values.comment: The `wrap` mixin specifies whether the flexible items should wrap or not.

docs.name: Array.MultiDim
docs.comment:
A class for multi-dimensional arrays, which stores the number of coordinates
at type-level.

Internally, the array is represented as a 1D array, so lookups
should be quite fast. However, we provide a safe, clean
interface for multi-dimensional lookups and updates.

To create an array, use a safe-list with the array dimensions:

    import List.SafeList exposing (cons, null)
    --Creates a 4x6x2 array of zeroes
    myArray =
      repeat (4 `cons` 6 `cons` 2 `cons` null ) 0

Accesses and updates use SafeList as well:

    import List.SafeList exposing (cons, null)
    updatedArray =
      case get (3 `cons` 1 `cons` 1 `cons` null ) myArray of
        Nothing -> myArray
        Just x ->
          set (3 `cons` 1 `cons` 1 `cons` null ) (2*x) myArray

If you ever give the wrong number of coordinates, you get a type error:

    --Won't compile
    updatedArray =
      case get (3 `cons` 1 `cons` 1 `cons` null ) myArray of
        Nothing -> myArray
        Just x ->
          set (3 `cons` 1 `cons` 1 `cons` null ) (2*x) myArray

We don't yet support any operations which change the size of the array,
such as push or append. For operations like `foldl` and `foldr`,
use the `toFlatArray` function, then the corresponding functions
on Array.Array.

#The Array type and creation functions
@docs MultiDim, repeat, initialize

#Get array info
@docs inBounds, dims

#Access and update
@docs get, set

#Convting to flat List or Array
@docs toIndexedList, toFlatArray

#Mapping functions
@docs map, indexedMap

types.name: MultiDim
types.comment: Opaque type for `n`-dimensional arrays containing type `a`

values.name: dims
values.comment: Get the dimensions of an array
values.type: Array.MultiDim.MultiDim a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList Int n

values.name: get
values.comment:
Return Just the element if all given coordinates
are within the array's bounds. Otherwise, return nothing.
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList Int n -> Array.MultiDim.MultiDim a n -> Maybe.Maybe a

values.name: inBounds
values.comment:
Given array dimensions, and coordinates,
determine if the coordinates are in bounds for the dimensions.
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList Int n -> List.SafeList.SafeList Int n -> Bool

values.name: indexedMap
values.comment:
Apply a function on every element in an array,
with access to the coordinates of each element.
values.type: (List.SafeList.SafeList Int n -> a -> b) -> Array.MultiDim.MultiDim a n -> Array.MultiDim.MultiDim b n

values.name: initialize
values.comment:
Given a SafeList of array dimensions,
and a function to generate an element for each coordinate,
create a new array with the given elements
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList Int n -> (List.SafeList.SafeList Int n -> a) -> Array.MultiDim.MultiDim a n

values.name: map
values.comment: Apply a function on every element in an array
values.type: (a -> b) -> Array.MultiDim.MultiDim a n -> Array.MultiDim.MultiDim b n

values.name: repeat
values.comment:
Given a SafeList [n1, n2, ...] of array dimensions,
create an n1 x n2 x ... multi-dimensional array
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList Int n -> a -> Array.MultiDim.MultiDim a n

values.name: set
values.comment:
Set the element at the given coordinates, if they all
are within the array's bounds. Otherwise, return the original array.
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList Int n -> a -> Array.MultiDim.MultiDim a n -> Array.MultiDim.MultiDim a n

values.name: toFlatArray
values.comment:
Convert this array to a 1-dimensional array
with elements in lexigraphical order

values.name: toIndexedList
values.comment:
Generate a list of the array's elements,
paired with their coordinates.
values.type: Array.MultiDim.MultiDim a n -> List ( List.SafeList.SafeList Int n, a )

docs.name: List.SafeList
docs.comment:
This module provides a form of list which encode their length
in their type, using the TypeNats library. For example:

    someLength3 : List.SafeList Int (OnePlus (OnePlus (OnePlus (Zero))) )
    someLength3 = 2 `cons` 3 `cons` 4 `cons` null

List whose length doesn't match their type are forbidden.
For example:

    --Gives type mismatch
    badLength3 : SafeList Int (OnePlus (OnePlus  (Zero)) )
    badLength3 = 2 `cons` 3 `cons` 4 `cons` null

Because Elm doesn't have GADTs or DataKinds, it's impossible
to pattern match on SafeLists. Instead, we provide an "uncons"
function, which splits a list which we know to be non-empty
into its head and tail.

For example:

    sumFirstLast =
      let
        (h1, t1) = uncons someLength3
        (_, t2) = uncons t1
        (h3, t3) = uncons t2
        tailCheck : SafeList Int Zero
        tailCheck = t3
      in
        h1 + h3

This notation is awkward, so it's assumed this library
will be used on small lists only.


As well, many functions on List.List have been ported over,
though filter, foldl and foldr are notably absent, as they
do not preserve the length of the list.

Because Elm is not a higher-kinded language, it is not generally
possible to use this library when you don't know your list size in advance,
unless only generic functions like `map` are used.

# Our main type and pseudo-constructors
@docs SafeList, null, cons

# In lieu of pattern matching:
@docs uncons, toList, fromList

# The usual map functions
@docs map, map2, map3, map4, map5, unzip

# Length-preserving fold-like functions
@docs mapl, mapr, reverseMapr, scanl

# Functions for non-empty lists
@docs maximum, minimum, head, tail, last

# Utility functions
@docs  member, reverse, all, any

#Length-preserving sorting functions
@docs sort, sortBy, sortWith

types.name: SafeList
types.comment:
A list with length encoded in its type,
supporting a restricted set of operations.

values.name: cons
values.comment:
Given a new element and a list of length n, make a list of length n+1.
Has the same infix precedence as (::)
values.type: a -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList a (TypeNat.OnePlus n)

values.name: fromList
values.comment:
Given a some SafeList, try to convert
a normal list into a SafeList of the same length
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List b -> Maybe.Maybe (List.SafeList.SafeList b n)

values.name: head
values.comment: SafeList way to get the first element of a list

values.name: last
values.comment: SafeList way to get the last element of a list

values.name: map
values.comment: Works as List.map
values.type: (a -> b) -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList b n

values.name: map2
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList b n -> List.SafeList.SafeList c n

values.name: map3
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d) -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList b n -> List.SafeList.SafeList c n -> List.SafeList.SafeList d n

values.name: map4
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e) -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList b n -> List.SafeList.SafeList c n -> List.SafeList.SafeList d n -> List.SafeList.SafeList e n

values.name: map5
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f) -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList b n -> List.SafeList.SafeList c n -> List.SafeList.SafeList d n -> List.SafeList.SafeList e n -> List.SafeList.SafeList f n

values.name: mapl
values.comment:
Given a mapping function and an initial context value,
traverse the list left to right, applying our map function with the previously
computed context as argument.
General folds don't preserve the length of a list, so we use
this restricted form of a fold.
values.type: (( a, c ) -> ( b, c )) -> c -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList b n

values.name: mapr
values.comment:
Given a mapping function and an initial context value,
traverse the list right to left, applying our map function with the previously
computed context as argument.
General folds don't preserve the length of a list, so we use
this restricted form of a fold.
values.type: (( a, c ) -> ( b, c )) -> c -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList b n

values.name: maximum
values.comment:
Given a list of comparable containing at least one element,
  return its largest element

values.name: member
values.comment: Length-preserving list functions, identical to operations on List.List

values.name: minimum
values.comment:
Given a list of comparable containing at least one element,
return its smallest element

values.name: null
values.comment: A list of length 0

values.name: reverse
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n

values.name: reverseMapr
values.comment:
Like mapr, but the resulting elements are in reverse order.
Generally faster than mapr, use this when order doesn't matter.
values.type: (( a, c ) -> ( b, c )) -> c -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList b n

values.name: scanl
values.comment:
Just like List.scanl, except we now have a guarantee that we increase the list lenght
by exactly one, since we always put our initial value in the list.
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList b (TypeNat.OnePlus n)

values.name: sort
values.comment: Just like List.sort, but with a guarantee that length is preserved
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList comparable n -> List.SafeList.SafeList comparable n

values.name: sortBy
values.comment: Sort based on comparable representatives
values.type: (a -> comparable) -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n

values.name: sortWith
values.comment: Sort based on an arbitrary comparison of elements
values.type: (a -> a -> Basics.Order) -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n

values.name: tail
values.comment: SafeList way to remove the first element of a list
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList a (TypeNat.OnePlus n) -> List.SafeList.SafeList a n

values.name: toList
values.comment: Drop type-level information about this list

values.name: uncons
values.comment: Split a non-empty list into a head and a tail
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList a (TypeNat.OnePlus n) -> ( a, List.SafeList.SafeList a n )

values.name: unzip
values.type: List.SafeList.SafeList ( a, b ) n -> ( List.SafeList.SafeList a n, List.SafeList.SafeList b n )

docs.name: TypeNat
docs.comment:
Easy to remember names for type-level natural numbers.
These are intended only to be used as "phantom types:"
that is, there are no values of type `Zero` or `OnePlus a`.
Instead, they should be arguments to other type constructors.

Use this to represent natural numbers at the type level.
For example:

    OnePlus (OnePlus (OnePlus Zero)) -- 3

Elm doesn't have DataKinds, so please don't do anything silly like
`OnePlus (OnePlus (OnePlus (List (Int, Int))))`
i.e. please only give another TypeNat as the argument to
OnePlus.

@docs Zero, OnePlus

types.name: OnePlus
types.comment:
A phantom type constructor to increment a TypeNat,
creating a larger TypeNat.

types.name: Zero
types.comment: A phantom type for 0, our base TypeNat.

docs.name: Time.Extra

values.name: everyWhen
values.comment:
Same as the `Time.every` function,
but you can turn it on and off.

values.name: fromFps
values.comment:
Converts a number of ticks per second
into the corresponding interval between to ticks.

values.name: timestamps
values.comment: Extract the timestamps of the updates of the given signal.

values.name: toFps
values.comment: Get the FPS corresponding to a given time between to frames.

docs.name: Path.Url

values.comment: Operator Version of 'combine'

values.name: addExtension
values.comment:
Add an extension, even if there is already one there, equivalent to `<.>`.

    addExtension "/directory/path" "ext" == "/directory/path.ext"
    addExtension "file.txt" "bib" == "file.txt.bib"
    addExtension "file." ".bib" == "file..bib"
    addExtension "file" ".bib" == "file.bib"
    addExtension "/" "x" == "/.x"
    Valid x => takeFileName (addExtension (addTrailingPathSeparator x) "ext") == ".ext"
    Windows: addExtension "\\\\share" ".txt" == "\\\\share\\.txt"

values.name: addTrailingPathSeparator
values.comment:
Add a trailing file path separator if one is not already present.

    hasTrailingPathSeparator (addTrailingPathSeparator x)
    hasTrailingPathSeparator x ==> addTrailingPathSeparator x == x
    Posix:    addTrailingPathSeparator "test/rest" == "test/rest/"

values.name: combine
values.comment:
Combine two paths, if the second path starts with a path separator then it returns the second.

    Valid x => combine (takeDirectory x) (takeFileName x) `equalFilePath` x

Combined:

    Posix:   combine "/" "test" == "/test"
    Posix:   combine "home" "bob" == "home/bob"
    Posix:   combine "x:" "foo" == "x:/foo"
    Windows: combine "C:\\foo" "bar" == "C:\\foo\\bar"
    Windows: combine "home" "bob" == "home\\bob"

values.name: dropExtension
values.comment:
Remove last extension, and the "." preceding it.

    dropExtension "/directory/path.ext" == "/directory/path"
    dropExtension x == fst (splitExtension x)

values.name: dropExtensions
values.comment:
Drop all extensions.

    dropExtensions "/directory/path.ext" == "/directory/path"
    dropExtensions "file.tar.gz" == "file"
    not <| hasExtension <| dropExtensions x
    not <| any isExtSeparator <| takeFileName <| dropExtensions x

values.name: dropFileName
values.comment:
Drop the filename. Unlike `takeDirectory`, this function will leave
a trailing path separator on the directory.

    dropFileName "/directory/file.ext" == "/directory/"
    dropFileName x == fst (splitFileName x)

values.name: dropTrailingPathSeparator
values.comment:
Remove any trailing path separators

    dropTrailingPathSeparator "file/test/" == "file/test"
              dropTrailingPathSeparator "/" == "/"
    Windows:  dropTrailingPathSeparator "\\" == "\\"

values.name: extSeparator
values.comment:
File extension character

    extSeparator == '.'

values.name: hasExtension
values.comment:
Does the given filename have an extension?

    hasExtension "/directory/path.ext" == True
    hasExtension "/directory/path" == False
    ull (takeExtension x) == not (hasExtension x)

values.name: hasTrailingPathSeparator
values.comment:
Is an item either a directory or the last character a path separator?

    hasTrailingPathSeparator "test" == False
    hasTrailingPathSeparator "test/" == True

values.name: isExtSeparator
values.comment:
Is the character an extension character?

    isExtSeparator a == (a == extSeparator)

values.name: isPathSeparator
values.comment:
Rather than using `== pathSeparator`, use this. Test if somethin is a path separator.

    isPathSeparator a == (a `elem` pathSeparators)

values.name: joinPath
values.comment:
Join path elements back together.

    joinPath ["/","directory/","file.ext"] == "/directory/file.ext"
    Valid x => joinPath (splitPath x) == x
    joinPath [] == ""
    Posix: joinPath ["test","file","path"] == "test/file/path"

values.name: pathSeparator
values.comment:
The character that separates directories. In the case where more than
one character is possible, `pathSeparator` is the 'ideal' one.

    Windows: pathSeparator == '\\'
    Posix:   pathSeparator ==  '/'
    isPathSeparator pathSeparator

values.name: pathSeparators
values.comment:
The list of all possible separators.

    Windows: pathSeparators == ['\\', '/']
    Posix:   pathSeparators == ['/']
    pathSeparator `elem` pathSeparators

values.name: replaceBaseName
values.comment:
Set the base name.

    replaceBaseName "/directory/other.ext" "file" == "/directory/file.ext"
    replaceBaseName "file/test.txt" "bob" == "file/bob.txt"
    replaceBaseName "fred" "bill" == "bill"
    replaceBaseName "/dave/fred/bob.gz.tar" "new" == "/dave/fred/new.tar"
    Valid x => replaceBaseName x (takeBaseName x) == x

values.name: replaceDirectory
values.comment:
Set the directory, keeping the filename the same.

    replaceDirectory "root/file.ext" "/directory/" == "/directory/file.ext"
    Valid x => replaceDirectory x (takeDirectory x) `equalFilePath` x

values.name: replaceExtension
values.comment:
Set the extension of a file, overwriting one if already present, equivalent to `-<.>`.

    replaceExtension "/directory/path.txt" "ext" == "/directory/path.ext"
    replaceExtension "/directory/path.txt" ".ext" == "/directory/path.ext"
    replaceExtension "file.txt" ".bob" == "file.bob"
    replaceExtension "file.txt" "bob" == "file.bob"
    replaceExtension "file" ".bob" == "file.bob"
    replaceExtension "file.txt" "" == "file"
    replaceExtension "file.fred.bob" "txt" == "file.fred.txt"
    replaceExtension x y == addExtension (dropExtension x) y

values.name: replaceFileName
values.comment:
Set the filename.

    replaceFileName "/directory/other.txt" "file.ext" == "/directory/file.ext"
    Valid x => replaceFileName x (takeFileName x) == x

values.name: splitExtension
values.comment:
Split on the extension. `addExtension` is the inverse.

    splitExtension "/directory/path.ext" == ("/directory/path",".ext")
    uncurry (++) (splitExtension x) == x
    Valid x => uncurry addExtension (splitExtension x) == x
    splitExtension "file.txt" == ("file",".txt")
    splitExtension "file" == ("file","")
    splitExtension "file/file.txt" == ("file/file",".txt")
    splitExtension "file.txt/boris" == ("file.txt/boris","")
    splitExtension "file.txt/boris.ext" == ("file.txt/boris",".ext")
    splitExtension "file/path.txt.bob.fred" == ("file/path.txt.bob",".fred")
    splitExtension "file/path.txt/" == ("file/path.txt/","")

values.name: splitExtensions
values.comment:
Split on all extensions.

    splitExtensions "/directory/path.ext" == ("/directory/path",".ext")
    splitExtensions "file.tar.gz" == ("file",".tar.gz")
    uncurry (++) (splitExtensions x) == x
    Valid x => uncurry addExtension (splitExtensions x) == x
    splitExtensions "file.tar.gz" == ("file",".tar.gz")

values.name: splitFileName
values.comment:
Operations on a filepath, as a list of directories

Split a filename into directory and file. `combine` is the inverse.
The first component will often end with a trailing slash.

    splitFileName "/directory/file.ext" == ("/directory/","file.ext")
    Valid x => isValid (fst (splitFileName x))
    splitFileName "file/bob.txt" == ("file/", "bob.txt")
    splitFileName "file/" == ("file/", "")
    splitFileName "bob" == ("", "bob")
    Posix:   splitFileName "/" == ("/","")

values.name: splitPath
values.comment:
Split a path by the directory separator.

    splitPath "/directory/file.ext" == ["/","directory/","file.ext"]
    concat (splitPath x) == x
    splitPath "test//item/" == ["test//","item/"]
    splitPath "test/item/file" == ["test/","item/","file"]
    splitPath "" == []
    Windows: splitPath "c:\\test\\path" == ["c:\\","test\\","path"]
    Posix:   splitPath "/file/test" == ["/","file/","test"]

values.name: takeBaseName
values.comment:
Get the base name, without an extension or path.

    takeBaseName "/directory/file.ext" == "file"
    takeBaseName "file/test.txt" == "test"

    takeBaseName "" == ""
    takeBaseName "test" == "test"
    takeBaseName (addTrailingPathSeparator x) == ""
    takeBaseName "file/file.tar.gz" == "file.tar"

values.name: takeDirectory
values.comment:
Get the directory name, move up one level.

              takeDirectory "/directory/other.ext" == "/directory"
              takeDirectory x `isPrefixOf` x || takeDirectory x == "."
              takeDirectory "foo" == "."
              takeDirectory "/" == "/"
              takeDirectory "/foo" == "/"
              takeDirectory "/foo/bar/baz" == "/foo/bar"
              takeDirectory "/foo/bar/baz/" == "/foo/bar/baz"
              takeDirectory "foo/bar/baz" == "foo/bar"
    Windows:  takeDirectory "foo\\bar" == "foo"
    Windows:  takeDirectory "foo\\bar\\\\" == "foo\\bar"

values.name: takeExtension
values.comment:
Get the extension of a file, returns "" for no extension, .ext otherwise.

    takeExtension "/directory/path.ext" == ".ext"
    takeExtension x == snd (splitExtension x)
    Valid x => takeExtension (addExtension x "ext") == ".ext"
    Valid x => takeExtension (replaceExtension x "ext") == ".ext"

values.name: takeExtensions
values.comment:
Get all extensions.

    takeExtensions "/directory/path.ext" == ".ext"
    takeExtensions "file.tar.gz" == ".tar.gz"

values.name: takeFileName
values.comment:
Get the file name.

    takeFileName "/directory/file.ext" == "file.ext"
    takeFileName "test/" == ""
    takeFileName x `isSuffixOf` x

    Valid x => takeFileName (replaceFileName x "fred") == "fred"
    Valid x => takeFileName (x </> "fred") == "fred"
    Valid x => isRelative (takeFileName x)
