values.comment: Operator Version of 'combine'

values.name: addExtension
values.comment:
Add an extension, even if there is already one there, equivalent to `<.>`.

    addExtension "/directory/path" "ext" == "/directory/path.ext"
    addExtension "file.txt" "bib" == "file.txt.bib"
    addExtension "file." ".bib" == "file..bib"
    addExtension "file" ".bib" == "file.bib"
    addExtension "/" "x" == "/.x"
    Valid x => takeFileName (addExtension (addTrailingPathSeparator x) "ext") == ".ext"
    Windows: addExtension "\\\\share" ".txt" == "\\\\share\\.txt"

values.name: addTrailingPathSeparator
values.comment:
Add a trailing file path separator if one is not already present.

    hasTrailingPathSeparator (addTrailingPathSeparator x)
    hasTrailingPathSeparator x ==> addTrailingPathSeparator x == x
    Posix:    addTrailingPathSeparator "test/rest" == "test/rest/"

values.name: combine
values.comment:
Combine two paths, if the second path starts with a path separator then it returns the second.

    Valid x => combine (takeDirectory x) (takeFileName x) `equalFilePath` x

Combined:

    Posix:   combine "/" "test" == "/test"
    Posix:   combine "home" "bob" == "home/bob"
    Posix:   combine "x:" "foo" == "x:/foo"
    Windows: combine "C:\\foo" "bar" == "C:\\foo\\bar"
    Windows: combine "home" "bob" == "home\\bob"

values.name: dropExtension
values.comment:
Remove last extension, and the "." preceding it.

    dropExtension "/directory/path.ext" == "/directory/path"
    dropExtension x == fst (splitExtension x)

values.name: dropExtensions
values.comment:
Drop all extensions.

    dropExtensions "/directory/path.ext" == "/directory/path"
    dropExtensions "file.tar.gz" == "file"
    not <| hasExtension <| dropExtensions x
    not <| any isExtSeparator <| takeFileName <| dropExtensions x

values.name: dropFileName
values.comment:
Drop the filename. Unlike `takeDirectory`, this function will leave
a trailing path separator on the directory.

    dropFileName "/directory/file.ext" == "/directory/"
    dropFileName x == fst (splitFileName x)

values.name: dropTrailingPathSeparator
values.comment:
Remove any trailing path separators

    dropTrailingPathSeparator "file/test/" == "file/test"
              dropTrailingPathSeparator "/" == "/"
    Windows:  dropTrailingPathSeparator "\\" == "\\"

values.name: extSeparator
values.comment:
File extension character

    extSeparator == '.'

values.name: hasExtension
values.comment:
Does the given filename have an extension?

    hasExtension "/directory/path.ext" == True
    hasExtension "/directory/path" == False
    ull (takeExtension x) == not (hasExtension x)

values.name: hasTrailingPathSeparator
values.comment:
Is an item either a directory or the last character a path separator?

    hasTrailingPathSeparator "test" == False
    hasTrailingPathSeparator "test/" == True

values.name: isExtSeparator
values.comment:
Is the character an extension character?

    isExtSeparator a == (a == extSeparator)

values.name: isPathSeparator
values.comment:
Rather than using `== pathSeparator`, use this. Test if somethin is a path separator.

    isPathSeparator a == (a `elem` pathSeparators)

values.name: joinPath
values.comment:
Join path elements back together.

    joinPath ["/","directory/","file.ext"] == "/directory/file.ext"
    Valid x => joinPath (splitPath x) == x
    joinPath [] == ""
    Posix: joinPath ["test","file","path"] == "test/file/path"

values.name: pathSeparator
values.comment:
The character that separates directories. In the case where more than
one character is possible, `pathSeparator` is the 'ideal' one.

    Windows: pathSeparator == '\\'
    Posix:   pathSeparator ==  '/'
    isPathSeparator pathSeparator

values.name: pathSeparators
values.comment:
The list of all possible separators.

    Windows: pathSeparators == ['\\', '/']
    Posix:   pathSeparators == ['/']
    pathSeparator `elem` pathSeparators

values.name: replaceBaseName
values.comment:
Set the base name.

    replaceBaseName "/directory/other.ext" "file" == "/directory/file.ext"
    replaceBaseName "file/test.txt" "bob" == "file/bob.txt"
    replaceBaseName "fred" "bill" == "bill"
    replaceBaseName "/dave/fred/bob.gz.tar" "new" == "/dave/fred/new.tar"
    Valid x => replaceBaseName x (takeBaseName x) == x

values.name: replaceDirectory
values.comment:
Set the directory, keeping the filename the same.

    replaceDirectory "root/file.ext" "/directory/" == "/directory/file.ext"
    Valid x => replaceDirectory x (takeDirectory x) `equalFilePath` x

values.name: replaceExtension
values.comment:
Set the extension of a file, overwriting one if already present, equivalent to `-<.>`.

    replaceExtension "/directory/path.txt" "ext" == "/directory/path.ext"
    replaceExtension "/directory/path.txt" ".ext" == "/directory/path.ext"
    replaceExtension "file.txt" ".bob" == "file.bob"
    replaceExtension "file.txt" "bob" == "file.bob"
    replaceExtension "file" ".bob" == "file.bob"
    replaceExtension "file.txt" "" == "file"
    replaceExtension "file.fred.bob" "txt" == "file.fred.txt"
    replaceExtension x y == addExtension (dropExtension x) y

values.name: replaceFileName
values.comment:
Set the filename.

    replaceFileName "/directory/other.txt" "file.ext" == "/directory/file.ext"
    Valid x => replaceFileName x (takeFileName x) == x

values.name: splitExtension
values.comment:
Split on the extension. `addExtension` is the inverse.

    splitExtension "/directory/path.ext" == ("/directory/path",".ext")
    uncurry (++) (splitExtension x) == x
    Valid x => uncurry addExtension (splitExtension x) == x
    splitExtension "file.txt" == ("file",".txt")
    splitExtension "file" == ("file","")
    splitExtension "file/file.txt" == ("file/file",".txt")
    splitExtension "file.txt/boris" == ("file.txt/boris","")
    splitExtension "file.txt/boris.ext" == ("file.txt/boris",".ext")
    splitExtension "file/path.txt.bob.fred" == ("file/path.txt.bob",".fred")
    splitExtension "file/path.txt/" == ("file/path.txt/","")

values.name: splitExtensions
values.comment:
Split on all extensions.

    splitExtensions "/directory/path.ext" == ("/directory/path",".ext")
    splitExtensions "file.tar.gz" == ("file",".tar.gz")
    uncurry (++) (splitExtensions x) == x
    Valid x => uncurry addExtension (splitExtensions x) == x
    splitExtensions "file.tar.gz" == ("file",".tar.gz")

values.name: splitFileName
values.comment:
Operations on a filepath, as a list of directories

Split a filename into directory and file. `combine` is the inverse.
The first component will often end with a trailing slash.

    splitFileName "/directory/file.ext" == ("/directory/","file.ext")
    Valid x => isValid (fst (splitFileName x))
    splitFileName "file/bob.txt" == ("file/", "bob.txt")
    splitFileName "file/" == ("file/", "")
    splitFileName "bob" == ("", "bob")
    Posix:   splitFileName "/" == ("/","")

values.name: splitPath
values.comment:
Split a path by the directory separator.

    splitPath "/directory/file.ext" == ["/","directory/","file.ext"]
    concat (splitPath x) == x
    splitPath "test//item/" == ["test//","item/"]
    splitPath "test/item/file" == ["test/","item/","file"]
    splitPath "" == []
    Windows: splitPath "c:\\test\\path" == ["c:\\","test\\","path"]
    Posix:   splitPath "/file/test" == ["/","file/","test"]

Set the extension of a file, overwriting one if already present, equivalent to `-<.>`.

    replaceExtension "/directory/path.txt" "ext" == "/directory/path.ext"
    replaceExtension "/directory/path.txt" ".ext" == "/directory/path.ext"
    replaceExtension "file.txt" ".bob" == "file.bob"
    replaceExtension "file.txt" "bob" == "file.bob"
    replaceExtension "file" ".bob" == "file.bob"
    replaceExtension "file.txt" "" == "file"
    replaceExtension "file.fred.bob" "txt" == "file.fred.txt"
    replaceExtension x y == addExtension (dropExtension x) y

values.name: replaceFileName
values.comment:
Set the filename.

    replaceFileName "/directory/other.txt" "file.ext" == "/directory/file.ext"
    Valid x => replaceFileName x (takeFileName x) == x

values.name: splitExtension
values.comment:
Split on the extension. `addExtension` is the inverse.

    splitExtension "/directory/path.ext" == ("/directory/path",".ext")
    uncurry (++) (splitExtension x) == x
    Valid x => uncurry addExtension (splitExtension x) == x
    splitExtension "file.txt" == ("file",".txt")
    splitExtension "file" == ("file","")
    splitExtension "file/file.txt" == ("file/file",".txt")
    splitExtension "file.txt/boris" == ("file.txt/boris","")
    splitExtension "file.txt/boris.ext" == ("file.txt/boris",".ext")
    splitExtension "file/path.txt.bob.fred" == ("file/path.txt.bob",".fred")
    splitExtension "file/path.txt/" == ("file/path.txt/","")

values.name: splitExtensions
values.comment:
Split on all extensions.

    splitExtensions "/directory/path.ext" == ("/directory/path",".ext")
    splitExtensions "file.tar.gz" == ("file",".tar.gz")
    uncurry (++) (splitExtensions x) == x
    Valid x => uncurry addExtension (splitExtensions x) == x
    splitExtensions "file.tar.gz" == ("file",".tar.gz")

values.name: splitFileName
values.comment:
Operations on a filepath, as a list of directories

Split a filename into directory and file. `combine` is the inverse.
The first component will often end with a trailing slash.

    splitFileName "/directory/file.ext" == ("/directory/","file.ext")
    Valid x => isValid (fst (splitFileName x))
    splitFileName "file/bob.txt" == ("file/", "bob.txt")
    splitFileName "file/" == ("file/", "")
    splitFileName "bob" == ("", "bob")
    Posix:   splitFileName "/" == ("/","")

values.name: splitPath
values.comment:
Split a path by the directory separator.

    splitPath "/directory/file.ext" == ["/","directory/","file.ext"]
    concat (splitPath x) == x
    splitPath "test//item/" == ["test//","item/"]
    splitPath "test/item/file" == ["test/","item/","file"]
    splitPath "" == []
    Windows: splitPath "c:\\test\\path" == ["c:\\","test\\","path"]
    Posix:   splitPath "/file/test" == ["/","file/","test"]

values.name: takeBaseName
values.comment:
Get the base name, without an extension or path.

    takeBaseName "/directory/file.ext" == "file"
    takeBaseName "file/test.txt" == "test"
    takeBaseName "dave.ext" == "dave"
    takeBaseName "" == ""
    takeBaseName "test" == "test"
    takeBaseName (addTrailingPathSeparator x) == ""
    takeBaseName "file/file.tar.gz" == "file.tar"

values.name: takeDirectory
values.comment:
Get the directory name, move up one level.

              takeDirectory "/directory/other.ext" == "/directory"
              takeDirectory x `isPrefixOf` x || takeDirectory x == "."
              takeDirectory "foo" == "."
              takeDirectory "/" == "/"
              takeDirectory "/foo" == "/"
              takeDirectory "/foo/bar/baz" == "/foo/bar"
              takeDirectory "/foo/bar/baz/" == "/foo/bar/baz"
              takeDirectory "foo/bar/baz" == "foo/bar"
    Windows:  takeDirectory "foo\\bar" == "foo"
    Windows:  takeDirectory "foo\\bar\\\\" == "foo\\bar"

values.name: takeExtension
values.comment:
Get the extension of a file, returns "" for no extension, .ext otherwise.

    takeExtension "/directory/path.ext" == ".ext"
    takeExtension x == snd (splitExtension x)
    Valid x => takeExtension (addExtension x "ext") == ".ext"
    Valid x => takeExtension (replaceExtension x "ext") == ".ext"

values.name: takeExtensions
values.comment:
Get all extensions.

    takeExtensions "/directory/path.ext" == ".ext"
    takeExtensions "file.tar.gz" == ".tar.gz"

values.name: takeFileName
values.comment:
Get the file name.

    takeFileName "/directory/file.ext" == "file.ext"
    takeFileName "test/" == ""
    takeFileName x `isSuffixOf` x
    takeFileName x == snd (splitFileName x)
    Valid x => takeFileName (replaceFileName x "fred") == "fred"
    Valid x => takeFileName (x </> "fred") == "fred"
    Valid x => isRelative (takeFileName x)

docs.name: Notification
docs.comment:
Easily display toast notifications to users. The module defines four common alert levels (success,
info, warning and error) and takes care of managing toast lifecycles.

See the [demo](https://ktorz.github.io/elm-notification) to get a nice overview of the capability.

# Create a notification

To create a notification, just send a `Notification` to the provided signal address. This can be
done either by directly calling `Signal.send` or, by using events subscriber from the `Html.Events`
module.

@docs Notification, success, info, warning, error, address

# Display and run effects

To be able to run and to actually work, notifications need to be added to your view. A `Signal Html`
is available for that purpose as well as a `Signal (Task Effects.Never ())` ready to be plugged in a
port, or merged with on of your application effects signal.

@docs view, task

values.comment: Create a `warning` notification

docs.name: Check.Test
docs.comment:
This module provides integration with
[`elm-test`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/deadfoxygrandpa/elm-test/latest/).

# Convert to Tests
@docs evidenceToTest

values.name: evidenceToTest
values.comment:
Convert elm-check's Evidence into an elm-test Test. You can use elm-test's
runners to view the results of your property-based tests, alongside the results
of unit tests.

docs.name: Check
docs.comment:
A toolkit for writing property-based tests, which take the form of `Claim`s. A
`Claim` is made using the provided domain-specific language (DSL). A single
`Claim` can be written in one of these ways:

1. claim - (string) - that - (actual) - is - (expected) - for - (producer)
2. claim - (string) - true - (predicate) - for - (producer)
3. claim - (string) - false - (predicate) - for - (producer)


For example,

    claim_multiplication_identity =
      claim
        "Multiplying by one does not change a number"
      `that`
        (\n -> n * 1)
      `is`
        identity
      `for`
        int

See the README for more information.

*Warning: The DSL follows a very strict format. Deviating from this format will
yield potentially unintelligible type errors. The following functions have
horrendous type signatures and you are better off ignoring them.*

@docs claim, that, is, for, true, false

# Group Claims
@docs suite

# Check a Claim
@docs quickCheck, check

# Types
@docs Claim

## Evidence
The results of checking a claim are given back in the types defined here. You
can examine them yourself, or see `Check.Test` to convert them into tests to use
with `elm-check`'s runners.
@docs Evidence, UnitEvidence, SuccessOptions, FailureOptions

aliases.name: FailureOptions
aliases.comment:
FailureOptions is the concrete type returned in case evidence was found
disproving a Claim.

FailureOptions contains:
1. the `name` of the claim
2. the minimal `counterExample` which serves as evidence that the claim is false
3. the value `expected` to be returned by the claim
4. the `actual` value returned by the claim
5. the `seed` used in order to reproduce the results
6. the number of checks performed
7. the number of shrinking operations performed
8. the original `counterExample`, `actual`, and `expected` values found prior
to performing the shrinking operations.
aliases.type: { name : String , counterExample : String , actual : String , expected : String , original : { counterExample : String , actual : String , expected : String } , seed : Random.Seed , numberOfChecks : Int , numberOfShrinks : Int }

aliases.name: SuccessOptions
aliases.comment:
SuccessOptions is the concrete type returned in case there is no evidence
found disproving a Claim.

SuccessOptions contains:
1. the `name` of the claim
2. the number of checks performed
3. the `seed` used in order to reproduce the check.
aliases.type: { name : String, seed : Random.Seed, numberOfChecks : Int }

aliases.name: UnitEvidence
aliases.comment:
UnitEvidence is the concrete type returned by checking a single claim.
A UnitEvidence can easily be converted to an assertion or can be considered
as the result of an assertion.

types.name: Claim
types.comment:
A Claim is an object that makes a claim of truth about a system.
A claim is either a function which yields evidence regarding the claim
or a list of such claims.

types.name: Evidence
types.comment: Evidence is the output from checking a claim or multiple claims.

values.name: check
values.comment:
Check a claim and produce evidence.

To check a claim, you need to provide the number of checks to perform, and a
random seed. You can set up a CI server to run through a large number of checks
with a randomized seed.

    aggressiveCheck : Claim -> Evidence
    aggressiveCheck =
      check 2000 (Random.initialSeed 0xFFFF)

values.name: claim
values.type: String -> (a -> b) -> (a -> b) -> Check.Producer.Producer a -> Check.Claim

values.name: false
values.type: ((a -> Bool) -> (a -> Bool) -> Check.Producer.Producer a -> Check.Claim) -> (a -> Bool) -> Check.Producer.Producer a -> Check.Claim

values.name: is
values.type: ((a -> b) -> Check.Producer.Producer a -> Check.Claim) -> (a -> b) -> Check.Producer.Producer a -> Check.Claim

values.name: quickCheck
values.comment:
Quickly check a claim.

This function is very useful when checking claims in local development.
`quickCheck` will perform 100 checks and use `Random.initialSeed 1` as the
random seed.

values.name: suite
values.comment:
Group a list of claims into a suite. This is very useful in order to
group similar claims together.

    suite nameOfSuite listOfClaims

values.name: that
values.type: ((a -> b) -> (a -> b) -> Check.Producer.Producer a -> Check.Claim) -> (a -> b) -> (a -> b) -> Check.Producer.Producer a -> Check.Claim

values.name: true
values.type: ((a -> Bool) -> (a -> Bool) -> Check.Producer.Producer a -> Check.Claim) -> (a -> Bool) -> Check.Producer.Producer a -> Check.Claim

docs.name: Check.Producer

aliases.name: Producer
aliases.comment:
An Producer type is a
[Random](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/latest/Random)
`Generator` paired with a shrinking strategy, or Shrinker. Shrinkers are defined
in
[`elm-shrink`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/NoRedInk/elm-shrink/latest/).
aliases.type: { generator : Random.Generator a, shrinker : Shrink.Shrinker a }

values.name: array
values.comment:
Given a producer of a type, create a producer of an array of that type.
Generates random arrays of values of length between 0 and 10.

values.name: ascii
values.comment: A producer for ASCII char values.

values.name: bool
values.comment: A producer for bool values.

values.name: char
values.comment:
A producer for char values. Generates random ascii chars disregarding the control
characters.

values.name: convert
values.comment:
Convert the output of one producer to another type. This is useful if
you're testing a function that expects a large model record, but you only need
to randomize a few fields. You might do this several different ways for a single
model, so you generate and shrink only the fields relevant to each test.

    type alias Person =
      { first : String, last : String, age : String }

    spy : Producer Person
    spy = map (\age -> Person "James" "Bond" age) .age (rangeInt 0 120)

In order for shrinking to work, you need to pass an inverse function of the
function being mapped.
values.type: (a -> b) -> (b -> a) -> Check.Producer.Producer a -> Check.Producer.Producer b

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Filter the values from a Producer. The resulting Producer will only generate
random test values or shrunken values that satisfy the predicate. The predicate
must be satisfiable.

values.name: float
values.comment: A producer for float values. NaN and Infinity will not be produced.

values.name: func
values.comment:
Given a producer of a return type, create a producer of functions that
return that type. Does not perform any shrinking.

values.name: func3
values.type: Check.Producer.Producer d -> Check.Producer.Producer (a -> b -> c -> d)

values.name: func4
values.type: Check.Producer.Producer e -> Check.Producer.Producer (a -> b -> c -> d -> e)

values.name: func5
values.type: Check.Producer.Producer f -> Check.Producer.Producer (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f)

values.name: int
values.comment: A producer for int values.

values.name: list
values.comment:
Given a producer of a type, create a producer of a list of that type.
Generates random lists of values of length between 0 and 10.

values.name: lowerCaseChar
values.comment: A producer for lowercase char values.

values.name: map
values.comment:
Map a function over an producer. This works exactly like `convert`,
except it does not require an invderse function, and consequently does no
shrinking.

values.name: maybe
values.comment: Given a producer of a type, create a producer of a maybe for that type.

values.name: order
values.comment: A producer for order values.

values.name: percentage
values.comment:
A producer for percentage values. Generates random floats between `0.0` and
`1.0`.

values.name: rangeFloat
values.comment:
A producer for float values within between a given minimum and maximum
value, inclusive. Shrunken values will also be within the range.

values.name: rangeInt
values.comment:
A producer for int values within between a given minimum and maximum value,
inclusive. Shrunken values will also be within the range.

values.name: result
values.comment:
Given producers for an error type and a success type, createa a producer for
a result.
values.type: Check.Producer.Producer error -> Check.Producer.Producer value -> Check.Producer.Producer (Result.Result error value)

values.name: string
values.comment:
A producer for string values. Generates random printable ascii strings whose
length is between 0 and 10.

values.name: tuple
values.comment: Turn a tuple of producers into a producer of tuples.
values.type: ( Check.Producer.Producer a, Check.Producer.Producer b ) -> Check.Producer.Producer ( a, b )

values.name: tuple3
values.comment: Turn a 3-tuple of producers into a producer of 3-tuples.
values.type: ( Check.Producer.Producer a , Check.Producer.Producer b , Check.Producer.Producer c ) -> Check.Producer.Producer ( a, b, c )

values.name: tuple4
values.comment: Turn a 4-tuple of producers into a producer of 4-tuples.
values.type: ( Check.Producer.Producer a , Check.Producer.Producer b , Check.Producer.Producer c , Check.Producer.Producer d ) -> Check.Producer.Producer ( a, b, c, d )

values.name: tuple5
values.comment: Turn a 5-tuple of producers into a producer of 5-tuples.
values.type: ( Check.Producer.Producer a , Check.Producer.Producer b , Check.Producer.Producer c , Check.Producer.Producer d , Check.Producer.Producer e ) -> Check.Producer.Producer ( a, b, c, d, e )

values.name: unicode
values.comment: A producer for unicode char values.

values.name: unit
values.comment:
A producer for the unit value. Unit is a type with only one value, commonly
used as a placeholder.

values.name: upperCaseChar
values.comment: A producer for uppercase char values.

docs.name: Json.Decode.Pipeline
docs.comment:
## Design Principles

* Introduce functions that work well with the [`(|>)`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/3.0.0/Basics#|>) operator
* Don't introduce any custom infix operators
* Don't introduce any functions that are intended to be called using backticks

@docs required, requiredAt, optional, optionalAt, hardcoded, custom, resolveResult, decode

values.name: custom
values.comment:
Run the given decoder and feed its result into the pipeline at this point.

Consider this example.

    import Json.Decode exposing (int, string, at, Decoder)
    import Json.Decode.Pipeline exposing (decode, required, custom)


    type alias User =
      { id : Int
      , name : String
      , email : String
      }


    userDecoder : Decoder User
    userDecoder =
      decode User
        |> required "id" int
        |> custom (at [ "profile", "name" ])
        |> required "email" string


    result : Result String User
    result =
      Json.Decode.decodeString
        userDecoder
        """
          {
            "id": 123,
            "email": "sam@example.com",
            "profile": {"name": "Sam"}
          }
        """
    -- Ok { id = 123, name = "Sam", email = "sam@example.com" }
values.type: Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder (a -> b) -> Json.Decode.Decoder b

values.name: decode
values.comment:
Begin a decoding pipeline. This is a synonym for [Json.Decode.succeed](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/3.0.0/Json-Decode#succeed),
intended to make things read more clearly.

    import Json.Decode exposing (int, string, float, Decoder)
    import Json.Decode.Pipeline exposing (decode, required, optional)


    type alias User =
      { id : Int
      , email : String
      , name : String
      }


    userDecoder : Decoder User
    userDecoder =
      decode User
        |> required "id" int
        |> required "email" string
        |> optional "name" string ""

values.name: hardcoded
values.comment:
Rather than decoding anything, use a fixed value for the next step in the
pipeline. `harcoded` does not look at the JSON at all.

    import Json.Decode exposing (int, string, Decoder)
    import Json.Decode.Pipeline exposing (decode, required)


    type alias User =
      { id : Int
      , email : String
      , followers : Int
      }


    userDecoder : Decoder User
    userDecoder =
      decode User
        |> required "id" int
        |> required "email" string
        |> hardcoded 0


    result : Result String User
    result =
      Json.Decode.decodeString
        userDecoder
        """
          {"id": 123, "email": "sam@example.com"}
        """
    -- Ok { id = 123, email = "sam@example.com", followers = 0 }

values.name: optional
values.comment:
Decode a field that may or may not be present. If the field is present,
use the specified decoder on it. If the field is not present, successfully
decode to the given fallback value.

    import Json.Decode exposing (int, string, Decoder)
    import Json.Decode.Pipeline exposing (decode, required, optional)


    type alias User =
      { id : Int
      , name : String
      , email : String
      }


    userDecoder : Decoder User
    userDecoder =
      decode User
        |> required "id" int
        |> optional "name" string "blah"
        |> required "email" string


    result : Result String User
    result =
      Json.Decode.decodeString
        userDecoder
        """
          {"id": 123, "email": "sam@example.com" }
        """
    -- Ok { id = 123, name = "blah", email = "sam@example.com" }
values.type: String -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> a -> Json.Decode.Decoder (a -> b) -> Json.Decode.Decoder b

values.name: optionalAt
values.comment: Decode an optional nested field.
values.type: List String -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> a -> Json.Decode.Decoder (a -> b) -> Json.Decode.Decoder b

values.name: required
values.comment:
Decode a required field.

    import Json.Decode exposing (int, string, Decoder)
    import Json.Decode.Pipeline exposing (decode, required)


    type alias User =
      { id : Int
      , name : String
      , email : String
      }


    userDecoder : Decoder User
    userDecoder =
      decode User
        |> required "id" int
        |> required "name" string
        |> required "email" string


    result : Result String User
    result =
      Json.Decode.decodeString
        userDecoder
        """
          {"id": 123, "email": "sam@example.com", "name": "Sam"}
        """
    -- Ok { id = 123, name = "Sam", email = "sam@example.com" }
values.type: String -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder (a -> b) -> Json.Decode.Decoder b

values.name: requiredAt
values.comment: Decode a required nested field.
values.type: List String -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder (a -> b) -> Json.Decode.Decoder b

values.name: resolveResult
values.comment:
Convert a `Decoder (Result x a)` into a `Decoder a`. Useful when you want
to perform some custom processing just before completing the decoding operation.

    import Json.Decode exposing (int, string, float, Decoder)
    import Json.Decode.Pipeline exposing
      (decode, required, resolveResult)


    type alias User =
      { id : Int
      , email : String
      }


    userDecoder : Decoder User
    userDecoder =
      let
        -- asResult gets run *after* all the
        -- (|> required ...) steps are done.
        asResult Int -> String -> Int -> Result String User
        asResult id email version =
          if version > 2 then
            Ok (User id email)
          else
            Err "This JSON is from a deprecated source. Please upgrade!"
      in
        decode asResult
          |> required "id" int
          |> required "email" string
          |> required "version" int -- version is part of asResult,
          |> resolveResult          -- but it is not a part of User


    result : Result String User
    result =
      Json.Decode.decodeString
        userDecoder
        """
          {"id": 123, "email": "sam@example.com", "version": 1}
        """
    -- Err "This JSON is from a deprecated source. Please upgrade!"

docs.name: Lazy.List

aliases.name: LazyList
aliases.comment: Lazy List type.

types.name: LazyListView
types.comment:
Analogous to `List` type. This is the actual implementation type for the
`LazyList` type. This type is exposed to the user if the user so wishes to
do pattern matching or understand how the list type works. It is not
recommended to work with this type directly. Try working solely with the
provided functions in the package.

values.comment: Alias for `append`. Analogous to `++` for lists.
values.type: Lazy.List.LazyList a -> Lazy.List.LazyList a -> Lazy.List.LazyList a

values.comment: Alias for `cons`. Analogous to `::` for lists.

values.name: andMap
values.comment:
Known as `mapN` in some circles. Allows you to apply `map` in cases
where then number of arguments are greater than 5.
values.type: Lazy.List.LazyList (a -> b) -> Lazy.List.LazyList a -> Lazy.List.LazyList b

values.name: andThen
values.comment: Chain list producing operations.
values.type: Lazy.List.LazyList a -> (a -> Lazy.List.LazyList b) -> Lazy.List.LazyList b

values.name: append
values.comment: Append a list to another list.
values.type: Lazy.List.LazyList a -> Lazy.List.LazyList a -> Lazy.List.LazyList a

values.name: cons
values.comment: Add a value to the front of a list.

values.name: cycle
values.comment:
Take a list and repeat it ad infinitum. This cycles a finite list
by putting the front after the end of the list. This results in a no-op in
the case of an infinite list.

values.name: drop
values.comment: Drop at most `n` many values from a list.

values.name: dropIf
values.comment: Drop all elements in a list that satisfy the given predicate.

values.name: dropWhile
values.comment: Drop elements from a list as long as the predicate is satisfied.

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty list.

values.name: flatMap
values.comment: Map then flatten.
values.type: (a -> Lazy.List.LazyList b) -> Lazy.List.LazyList a -> Lazy.List.LazyList b

values.name: flatten
values.comment:
Flatten a list of lists into a single list by appending all the inner
lists into one big list.

values.name: foldl
values.comment: Analogous to `List.foldl`. Is an alias for `reduce`.
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> Lazy.List.LazyList a -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment: Analogous to `List.foldr`.
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> Lazy.List.LazyList a -> b

values.name: fromArray
values.comment: Convert an array to a lazy list.

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert a normal list to a lazy list.

values.name: repeat
values.comment:
Repeat a value ad infinitum.
Be careful when you use this. The result of this is a truly infinite list.
Do not try calling `reduce` or `toList` on an infinite list as it'll never
finish computing. Make sure you then filter it down to a finite list with `head`
or `take` or something.

docs.name: Rails

types.name: Error
types.comment: The kinds of errors a Rails server may return.

values.name: always
values.comment: Returns a decoder suitable for passing to `fromJson`, which uses the same decoder for both success and failure responses.

values.name: csrfToken
values.comment:
If there was a `<meta name="csrf-token">` tag in the page's `<head>` when
    elm-rails loaded, returns the value its `content` attribute had at that time.

    Rails expects this value in the `X-CSRF-Token` header for non-`GET` requests as
    a [CSRF countermeasure](http://guides.rubyonrails.org/security.html#csrf-countermeasures).

values.name: decoder
values.comment: Returns a decoder suitable for passing to `fromJson`.
values.type: Json.Decode.Decoder value -> Json.Decode.Decoder error -> Rails.ResponseDecoder error value

values.name: fromJson
values.comment:
Think `Http.fromJson`, but with additional effort to parse a non-20x response as JSON.

  * If the status code is in the 200 range, try to parse with the given `decoder.success`.
    * If parsing fails, return an `Http.UnexpectedPayload` wrapped in `HttpError`
  * If the status code is outside the 200 range, try to parse with the given `decoder.success`.
    * If parsing fails, return an `Http.BadResponse` wrapped in `HttpError`
values.type: Rails.ResponseDecoder error value -> Task.Task Http.RawError Http.Response -> Task.Task (Rails.Error error) value

values.name: get
values.comment:
Send a GET request to the given URL. You also specify how to decode the response.

    import Json.Decode (list, string)

    hats : Task (Error (List String)) (List String)
    hats =
      get (decoder (list string) (succeed ())) "http://example.com/hat-categories.json"
values.type: Rails.ResponseDecoder error value -> String -> Task.Task (Rails.Error error) value

values.name: post
values.comment:
Send a POST request to the given URL. You also specify how to decode the response.

  import Json.Decode (list, string)
  import Http

  hats : Task (Error (List String)) (List String)
  hats =
    post (decoder (list string) (succeed ())) "http://example.com/hat-categories.json" Http.empty
values.type: Rails.ResponseDecoder error value -> String -> Http.Body -> Task.Task (Rails.Error error) value

values.name: send
values.comment:
Utility for working with Rails. Wraps Http.send, passing an Authenticity Token along with the type of request. Suitable for use with `fromJson`:

    import Dict
    import Json.Decode (list, string)
    import Json.Encode as Encode
    import Http

    hats : HatStyle -> Task (Error (List String)) (List String)
    hats style =

      let
        payload =
          Encode.object
            [ ( "style", encodeHatStyle style ) ]

        body =
          Http.string (Encode.encode 0 payload)

        success =
          list string

        failure =
          Dict.fromList [ ("style", HatStyle) ]
            |> Rails.Decode.errors
      in
        send "POST" url body
          |> fromJson (decoder success failure)
values.type: String -> String -> Http.Body -> Task.Task Http.RawError Http.Response

docs.name: Rails.Decode

aliases.name: ErrorList
aliases.comment:
ErrorList is a type alias for
a list of fields to String, where `field` is expected to be a type for matching
errors to
```

type Field = Name | Password

decode : ErrorList Field

```

values.name: errors
values.comment:
Decodes errors passed from rails formatted as

`{ errors: {errorName: ["Error String"] } }`.

This function takes a Dict that is a map of all the fields you need decoded. It should be formatted
nest

Dict.fromList
    [ ( "school", School )
    , ( "school.name", SchoolName )
    , ( "school.address", SchoolAddress )
    , ( "school.city", City )
    , ( "school.state", State )
    , ( "school.zip", Zip )
    , ( "school.country", Country )
    ]

docs.name: Random.String

values.name: anyCapitalizedEnglishWord
values.comment:
Generate a random capitalized word with english characters of random length
between 1 34.
Aside: 34 was picked as a maximum as "supercalifragilisticexpialidocious"
is considered the longest commonly used word and is 34 character long.
Longer words do occur, especially in scientific contexts. In which case, consider
using `rangeLengthEnglishWord` for more granular control.

values.name: anyEnglishWord
values.comment:
Generate a random lowercase word with english characters of random length
between 1 34.
Aside: 34 was picked as a maximum as "supercalifragilisticexpialidocious"
is considered the longest commonly used word and is 34 character long.
Longer words do occur, especially in scientific contexts. In which case, consider
using `rangeLengthEnglishWord` for more granular control.

values.name: capitalizedEnglishWord
values.comment:
Generate a random capitalized word with english characters of a given length.
Note: This just generates a random string using the letters in english, so there
are no guarantees that the result be an actual english word.

values.name: englishWord

Generate a random lowercase word with english characters of a given length.
Note: This just generates a random string using the letters in english, so there
are no guarantees that the result be an actual english word.

values.name: ok
values.comment: Generate an ok result from a random generator of values

values.name: result
values.comment:
Generate an ok result or an error result with 50-50 chance

This is simply implemented as follows:

    result errorGenerator okGenerator =
      frequency
        [ (1, error errorGenerator)
        , (1, ok okGenerator)
        ] (ok okGenerator)

If you want to generate results with a different frequency, tweak those
numbers to your bidding in your own custom generators.
values.type: Random.Generator error -> Random.Generator value -> Random.Generator (Result.Result error value)

docs.name: Random.Signal

values.name: application
values.comment:
Generate a random run of an application that follows the Elm Architecture.
Here, the Elm Architecture is interpreted as follows:

    initialModel : model
    actions : Signal action
    update : action -> model -> model
    view : model -> view -- where view is usually Element or Html

    main =
      Signal.map view
        (Signal.foldp update initialModel actions)


How to use:

    applicationGenerator =
      application initialModel actionGenerator update view

    main =
      generate applicationGenerator
values.type: model -> Random.Generator action -> (action -> model -> model) -> (model -> view) -> Random.Generator view

values.name: constant
values.comment: Generates constant signals.

values.name: generate
values.comment: Generate a signal from a random generator that updates 60 times per second.

values.name: generateEvery
values.comment:
Generate a signal from a random generator that updates every
given number of milliseconds.

values.name: randomSeed
values.comment:
Generate a random seed that updates 60 times per second.
Note: The seed uses the current Unix time.

values.name: randomSeedEvery
values.comment: Generate a random seed that updates every given timestep.

values.name: run
values.comment:
Create a running signal from an application that follows the Elm Architecture.
This is analogous to `application` and works better as it avoids issues with
`Random.Extra.reduce`.

How to use:

    main =
      run initialModel actionGenerator update view
values.type: model -> Random.Generator action -> (action -> model -> model) -> (model -> view) -> Signal.Signal view

values.name: frequency
values.comment:
Create a generator that chooses a generator from a tuple of generators
based on the provided likelihood. The likelihood of a given generator being
chosen is its likelihood divided by the sum of all likelihood. A default
generator must be provided in the case that the list is empty or that the
sum of the likelihoods is 0. Note that the absolute values of the likelihoods
is always taken.
values.type: List ( Float, Random.Generator a ) -> Random.Generator a -> Random.Generator a

values.comment:
Convert a generator into a generator that only generates values
that satisfy a given predicate.
Note that if the predicate is unsatisfiable, the generator will not terminate.

values.name: map2

Apply a constraint onto a generator and returns both the input to

Choose between two generators with a 50-50 chance.
Useful for merging two generators that cover different areas of the same type.

docs.name: Shrink

aliases.name: Shrinker
aliases.comment:
Shrinker type.
A shrinker is a function that takes a value and returns a list of values that
are in some sense "smaller" than the given value. If there are no such values
conceptually, then the shrinker should just return the empty list.

values.name: andMap
values.comment:
Apply a lazy list of functions on a lazy list of values.
    andMap = Lazy.List.map2 (<|)
This is useful in order to compose shrinkers, especially when used in
conjunction with `andMap`.
values.type: Lazy.List.LazyList (a -> b) -> Lazy.List.LazyList a -> Lazy.List.LazyList b

values.name: array
values.comment:
Array shrinker constructor.
Takes a shrinker of values and returns a shrinker of Arrays.

values.name: atLeastChar
values.comment:
Construct a shrinker of chars which considers the given char to
be most minimal.

values.name: atLeastFloat
values.comment:
Construct a shrinker of floats which considers the given float to
be most minimal.

values.name: atLeastInt
values.comment:
Construct a shrinker of ints which considers the given int to
be most minimal.

values.name: bool
values.comment: Shrinker of bools.

values.name: char
values.comment: Shrinker of chars.

values.name: character
values.comment:
Shrinker of chars which considers the empty space as the most
minimal char and omits the control key codes.

Equivalent to:

    atLeastChar (Char.fromCode 32)

values.name: convert
values.comment:
Convert a Shrinker of a's into a Shrinker of b's using two inverse functions.

If you use this function as follows:

    shrinkerB = f g shrinkerA

Make sure that

    `f(g(x)) == x` for all x

Or else this process will generate garbage.
values.type: (a -> b) -> (b -> a) -> Shrink.Shrinker a -> Shrink.Shrinker b

values.name: dropIf
values.comment:
Filter out the results of a shrinker. The resulting shrinker
will only throw away shrinks which satisfy the given predicate.

values.name: float
values.comment: Shrinker of floats.

values.name: int
values.comment: Shrinker of integers.

values.name: keepIf
values.comment:
Filter out the results of a shrinker. The resulting shrinker
will only produce shrinks which satisfy the given predicate.

values.name: lazylist
values.comment:
Lazy List shrinker constructor. (must be finite)
Takes a shrinker of values and returns a shrinker of Lazy Lists.

values.name: list
values.comment:
List shrinker constructor.
Takes a shrinker of values and returns a shrinker of Lists.

values.name: map
values.comment:
Re-export of `Lazy.List.map`
This is useful in order to compose shrinkers, especially when used in
conjunction with `andMap`.
Example:
    type alias Vector =
      { x : Float
      , y : Float
      , z : Float
      }
    vector : Shrinker Float
    vector {x,y,z} =
      Vector
        `map`    float x
        `andMap` float y
        `andMap` float z

values.name: maybe
values.comment:
Maybe shrinker constructor.
Takes a shrinker of values and returns a shrinker of Maybes.

values.name: merge
values.comment: Merge two shrinkers.
values.type: Shrink.Shrinker a -> Shrink.Shrinker a -> Shrink.Shrinker a

values.name: noShrink
values.comment: Empty shrinker. Always returns the empty list.

values.name: order
values.comment: Shrinker of Order.

values.name: result
values.comment:
Result shrinker constructor.
Takes a shrinker of errors and a shrinker of values and returns a shrinker
of Results.
values.type: Shrink.Shrinker error -> Shrink.Shrinker value -> Shrink.Shrinker (Result.Result error value)

values.name: string
values.comment:
Shrinker of strings. Considers the empty string to be the most
minimal string and the space to be the most minimal char.

Equivalent to:

    convert String.fromList String.toList (list character)

values.name: tuple
values.comment:
2-Tuple shrinker constructor.
Takes a tuple of shrinkers and returns a shrinker of tuples.
values.type: ( Shrink.Shrinker a, Shrink.Shrinker b ) -> Shrink.Shrinker ( a, b )

values.name: tuple3
values.comment:
3-Tuple shrinker constructor.
Takes a tuple of shrinkers and returns a shrinker of tuples.
values.type: ( Shrink.Shrinker a, Shrink.Shrinker b, Shrink.Shrinker c ) -> Shrink.Shrinker ( a, b, c )

values.name: tuple4
values.comment:
4-Tuple shrinker constructor.
Takes a tuple of shrinkers and returns a shrinker of tuples.
values.type: ( Shrink.Shrinker a , Shrink.Shrinker b , Shrink.Shrinker c , Shrink.Shrinker d ) -> Shrink.Shrinker ( a, b, c, d )

values.name: tuple5
values.comment:
5-Tuple shrinker constructor.
Takes a tuple of shrinkers and returns a shrinker of tuples.
values.type: ( Shrink.Shrinker a , Shrink.Shrinker b , Shrink.Shrinker c , Shrink.Shrinker d , Shrink.Shrinker e ) -> Shrink.Shrinker ( a, b, c, d, e )

values.name: void
values.comment: Shrink the empty tuple. Equivalent to `noShrink`.

docs.name: String.Extra

values.name: capitalize
values.comment:
Capitalize or uncapitalize the given string.

    capitalize True "foo"
    -- "Foo"

    capitalize False "BAR"
    -- "bAR"

values.name: isWhitespace
values.comment:
Returns True iff the given String is 1 or more whitespace characters,
and nothing else.

(Whitespace is defined as the regular expression `\s` matcher.)

    isWhitespace ""   == False
    isWhitespace " "  == True
    isWhitespace "  " == True
    isWhitespace " x" == False
    isWhitespace "x " == False

values.name: pluralize
values.comment:
Given a number, a singular string, and a plural string, returns the number
followed by a space, followed by either the singular string if the number was 1,
or the plural string otherwise.

    pluralize "elf" "elves" 2 == "2 elves"
    pluralize "elf" "elves" 1 == "1 elf"
    pluralize "elf" "elves" 0 == "0 elves"

values.comment: Update function for using the NoRedInk/elm-api-components pattern

values.name: defaultConfig
values.comment: Default configuration for SweetPoll

values.type: SweetPoll.Config data -> ( SweetPoll.Model data , Testable.Effects.Effects (SweetPoll.Action data) )

values.name: update

docs.name: Task.Extra

values.name: broadcast
values.comment: Sends a value to a list of addresses at once.

values.name: computeLazyAsync
values.comment: Compute a lazy value asynchronously and send the result to an address.

values.name: delay
values.comment: Delay a task by a given amount of time in milliseconds.
values.type: Time.Time -> Task.Task error value -> Task.Task error value

values.name: intercept
values.comment:
Intercept the values computed by a task by sending them to appropriate
an address. The address accepts a Result such as to capture both successful
values and error values. The intercepted task will simply `succeed` on success
with the successful value and `fail` on failure with the error thus making
the interception process feel as though the task is unaffected.
values.type: Signal.Address (Result.Result error value) -> Task.Task error value -> Task.Task error value

values.name: interceptError
values.comment:
Intercept the error value computed by a task by sending it to the given address.
The result task will just `fail` after being sent to the address thus making
the interception process feel as though the task is unaffected.
values.type: Signal.Address error -> Task.Task error value -> Task.Task error value

values.name: interceptSuccess
values.comment:
Intercept the successful value computed by a task by sending it to the given address.
The result task will just `succeed` after being sent to the address thus making
the interception process feel as though the task is unaffected.
values.type: Signal.Address value -> Task.Task error value -> Task.Task error value

values.name: loop
values.comment:
Runs a task repeatedly every given milliseconds.

    loop 1000 myTask -- Runs `myTask` every second
values.type: Time.Time -> Task.Task error value -> Task.Task error ()

values.name: optional
values.comment:
Similar to `Task.sequence`.
The difference with `Task.sequence` is that it doesn't return an `error` if
any individual task fails. If an error is encountered, then this function will
march on and perform the next task ignoring the error.
values.type: List (Task.Task x value) -> Task.Task y (List value)

values.name: parallel
values.comment:
Analogous to `Task.sequence`.
Schedule a list of tasks to be performed in parallel as opposed to in series
as is the case with `Task.sequence`.

*Note that there is no guarantee that the tasks will be performed or complete
in the order you have stated. This is why you may use the returned `ThreadID`
for re-ordering or consider integrating a sorting mechanism within your program.*
values.type: List (Task.Task error value) -> Task.Task error (List Task.ThreadID)

docs.name: StartApp
docs.comment:
This module helps you start your application in a typical Elm workflow.
It assumes you are following [the Elm Architecture][arch] and using
[elm-effects][]. From there it will wire everything up for you!

**Be sure to [read the Elm Architecture tutorial][arch] to learn how this all
works!**

[arch]: https://github.com/evancz/elm-architecture-tutorial
[elm-effects]: http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/evancz/elm-effects/latest

# Start your Application
@docs start, Config, App

aliases.name: App
aliases.comment:
An `App` is made up of a couple signals:

  * `model` — a signal representing the current model. Generally you
    will not need this one, but it is there just in case. You will know if you
    need this.

  * `tasks` — a signal of tasks that need to get run. Your app is going
    to be producing tasks in response to all sorts of events, so this needs to
    be hooked up to a `port` to ensure they get run.
aliases.type: { model : Signal.Signal model , tasks : Signal.Signal (Task.Task Effects.Never ()) , address : Signal.Address action }

aliases.name: Config
aliases.comment:
The configuration of an app follows the basic model / update / view pattern
that you see in every Elm program.

The `init` transaction will give you an initial model and create any tasks that
are needed on start up.

The `update` describe how to step over the model based on requests coming in

The `inputs` field is for any external signals you might need. If you need to
get values from JavaScript, they will come in through a port as a signal which
you can pipe into your app as one of the `inputs`.
aliases.type: { init : ( model, Effects.Effects action ) , update : action -> model -> ( model, Effects.Effects action ) , inputs : List (Signal.Signal action) }

values.name: start
values.comment:
Start an application. It requires a bit of wiring once you have created an
`App`. It should pretty much always look like this:

    app =
        start { init = init, update = update, inputs = [] }

    port tasks : Signal (Task.Task Never ())
    port tasks =
        app.tasks

So once we start the `App` we feed the resulting
tasks into a `port` that will run them all.
values.type: StartApp.Config model action -> StartApp.App model action

docs.name: Constructive.Combinators
docs.comment:
# Composing Viewers

@docs viewFocus, viewList, viewMaybe, viewArray

values.name: viewArray
values.comment:
Transform a viewer for a `model` into a viewer for an `Array` of `model`s,
with updates to individual array items automatically reflected in the entire
array.

Because it produces an `Array view`, it often makes sense to transform the
result of this function into a list, and use it as the body of a `div` or `span`
when `view` is `Html`.

    viewCounterArray : Viewer Html Never (Array Int)
    viewCounterArray address counters =
        div [] (Array.toList (viewArray viewCounter address counters))
values.type: Constructive.Action.Viewer view other model -> Constructive.Action.Viewer (Array.Array view) other (Array.Array model)

values.name: viewFocus
values.comment:
Transform a viewer for a child into a viewer for a parent, given a
[`Focus`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/evancz/focus/latest/) from the
parent to the child.  Replacements of the child model are automatically
reflected as replacements of the parent model:

    type CounterPair = CounterPair Int Int

    viewCounterPair : Viewer Html Never CounterPair
    viewCounterPair address pair =
      div []
        [ focusView left viewCounter address pair
        , focusView right viewCounter address pair
        ]

    -- Focus boilerplate

    left : Focus CounterPair Int
    left = Focus.create
        (\CounterPair l _ -> l)
        (\f (CounterPair l r) -> (f l, r))

    right : Focus CounterPair Int
    right = Focus.create
        (\CounterPair _ r -> r)
        (\f (CounterPair l r) -> (l, f r))
values.type: Focus.Focus big small -> Constructive.Action.Viewer view other small -> Constructive.Action.Viewer view other big

values.name: viewList
values.comment:
Transform a viewer for a `model` into a viewer for `List` of `model`s,
with updates to invidual list items automatically reflected in the entire list.

Because it produces a `List view`, it often makes sense to use the result of
this function as the body of a `div` or `span` when `view` is `Html`.

    viewCounters : Viewer Html Never (List Int)
    viewCounters address counters =
        div [] (viewList viewCounter address counters)
values.type: Constructive.Action.Viewer view other model -> Constructive.Action.Viewer (List view) other (List model)

values.name: viewMaybe
values.comment:
Transform a viewer for a `model` into a viewer for a `Maybe model`,
automatically wrapping replacement values in `Just`

Because it produces a `Maybe view`, this function should generally be used
in conjunction with `Maybe.withDefault`:

    viewMaybe viewStreetMap address currentLocation
      |> Maybe.withDefault (text "Location data not available")
values.type: Constructive.Action.Viewer view other model -> Constructive.Action.Viewer (Maybe.Maybe view) other (Maybe.Maybe model)

docs.name: Constructive.Action
docs.comment:
A standard interface for representing and working with actions in
elm-constructive.  The basic idea is that an elm-constructive action is
generally just a simple wrapper around a complete replacement model, rather than
instructions for how to modify the model.

Actions represented in this way can take full advantage of elm-constructive's
view composition combinators.  Non-replacement actions can be represented within
this framework as well, but they will simply be "along for the ride," and will
not benefit from any combinators or composition features.

# Types and definitions

@docs Action, Viewer, Never

# Transforming actions

@docs interceptOthers, interceptReplacements, mapReplacements

# Working with `Never`

@docs extractReplacementModel

aliases.name: Viewer
aliases.comment:
The basic unit of view logic in elm-constructive.  A view function takes a
`model`, produces a `view` for that model (usually `Html`), and wires up that
`view` to send `Actions` to a particular `Address`.

    viewCounter : Viewer Html Never Int

    viewSharableCounter : Viewer Html Share Int
    
    viewToggleButton : Viewer Html Never Bool

types.name: Action
types.comment:
Action types which may consist of a new replacement `model`, or some
`other` action.

Use `Replace` actions to represent direct modification to the model:

    -- A simple counter
    viewCounter address count =
      div []
        [ button [ onClick address (Replace (count + 1)) ] [ text "+" ]
        , button [ onClick address (Replace (count - 1)) ] [ text "-" ]
        , text (toString count)
        ]

Sometimes, one needs to send an action which cannot be represented as a
replacement model.  You can represent these with the `Other` tag:

    -- A counter whose value can be shared on social media

    type Share = ShareOnFacebook Int | ShareOnTwitter Int

    viewShareableCounter : Signal.Address (Action Share Int) -> Int -> Html
    viewShareableCounter address count =
      div []
        [ button [ onClick address (Replace (count + 1)) ] [ text "+" ]
        , button [ onClick address (Replace (count - 1)) ] [ text "-" ]
        , text (toString count)
        , button
          [ onClick address (Other (ShareOnFacebook count)) ]
          [ text "Share your counter on facebook!" ]
        , button
          [ onClick address (Other (ShareOnTwitter count)) ]
          [ text "Share your counter on twitter!" ]
        ]

Action types which only make use of `Replace` should use `Never` as their
`other` type:

    viewToggleButton : Signal.Address (Action Never Bool) -> Bool -> Html
    viewToggleButton address flag =
      if flag
        then button [ onClick address (Replace False) ] [ text "ON" ]
        else button [ onClick address (Replace True) ] [ text "OFF" ]

types.name: Never
types.comment:
An "uninhabited" type with no values.  This is useful for representing that
an `Action` type consists only of `Replace` actions, and has no `Other` actions.

    viewToggleButton : Viewer Html Never Bool

values.name: extractReplacementModel
values.comment:
Extract the replacement model from an `Action` which is guaranteed to be a
`Replace` action (i.e., from an `Action` where `other` is `Never`).

    extractReplcementModel (Replace "foo") == "foo"

values.name: interceptOthers
values.comment:
Flatmap a function over actions with the `Other` tag, leaving `Replace`
actions unchanged.

    interceptOthers (\ClearList -> Replace []) (Other ClearList) == Replace []

    interceptOthers (\ClearList -> Replace []) (Replace [1,2,3]) == Replace [1,2,3]

This is useful for having a child view produce an `Other` action which is then
transformed by the parent view into a `Replace` action for the parent model.

Partial applications of `interceptOthers` are designed to work well with
`Signal.forwardTo`
values.type: (other1 -> Constructive.Action.Action other2 model) -> Constructive.Action.Action other1 model -> Constructive.Action.Action other2 model

values.name: interceptReplacements
values.comment:
Flatmap a function over actions with the `Replace` tag, leaving `Other`
actions unchanged.

    interceptReplacements (\newModel -> Replace (Just newModel)) (Replace "foo") == Replace (Just "foo")

    interceptReplacements (\newModel -> Replace (Just newModel)) (Other ClearAll) == Other ClearAll

Partial applications of `interceptReplacements` are designed to work well with
`Signal.forwardTo`

Although the transformation function can technically produce either an `Other`
action or a `Replace` action, in practice one usually wants it to return a
`Replace` action.  For most purposes, you should therefore use `mapReplacements`
instead, which is like `interceptReplacements`, except that it always transforms
`Replace` actions into `Replace` actions.
values.type: (model1 -> Constructive.Action.Action other model2) -> Constructive.Action.Action other model1 -> Constructive.Action.Action other model2

values.name: mapReplacements
values.comment:
Map a function over the new models of `Replace` actions, leaving `Other`
actions unchanged.

    mapReplacements Just (Replace "foo") == Replace (Just "foo")

    mapReplacements Just (Other ClearAll) == Other ClearAll

Partial applications of `mapReplacements` are designed to work well with
`Signal.forwardTo`
values.type: (model1 -> model2) -> Constructive.Action.Action other model1 -> Constructive.Action.Action other model2

docs.name: Dict.Extra

values.name: groupBy
values.type: (a -> comparable) -> List a -> Dict.Dict comparable (List a)

values.name: removeWhen
values.comment:
Keep elements which fails to satisfy the predicate.
    This is functionaly equivalent to `Dict.filter (not << predicate) dict`.

    removeWhen (\c v -> v == 1) Dict.fromList [("Mary", 1), ("Jack", 2), ("Jill", 1)] == Dict.fromList [("Jack", 2)]
values.type: (comparable -> v -> Bool) -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v

docs.name: ElmFire.Auth
docs.comment:
Elm bindings to Firebase Authentication.

Note that all tasks in this module refer to a entire Firebase, not a specific path within a Firebase.
Therefore, only the root of the `Location` parameter is relevant.

# Getting Authentication Status
@docs Authentication, getAuth, subscribeAuth, unsubscribeAuth

# Perform Authentication
@docs Identification, authenticate, unauthenticate,
  asAnonymous, withPassword, withOAuthPopup, withOAuthRedirect,
  withOAuthAccessToken, withOAuthCredentials, withCustomToken

# Options
@docs Options, rememberDefault, rememberSessionOnly, rememberNone

# User Management
@docs UserOperation, userOperation,
  createUser, removeUser, changeEmail, changePassword, resetPassword

aliases.name: Authentication
aliases.comment: Authentication data. See Firebase doc for details.
aliases.type: { uid : String , provider : String , token : String , expires : Date.Date , auth : Json.Encode.Value , specifics : Json.Encode.Value }

aliases.name: Options
aliases.comment:
Optional authentication parameters

All providers allow option `remember` to specify the presistency of authentication.

Specific provider may accept additional options. See Firebase docs.

types.name: Identification
types.comment: Identification options to authenticate at a Firebase

types.name: UserOperation
types.comment: Specification of a user management operation

values.name: asAnonymous
values.comment: Identify as a anonymous, temporary guest

values.name: authenticate

values.name: changeEmail
values.comment:
UserOperation: Change the email address of a user identity.

values.name: changePassword

values.name: getAuth

values.name: rememberDefault
values.comment:
Option for default persistence:
Sessions are persisted for as long as it is configured in the Firebase's dashboard.

values.name: rememberNone
values.comment:
Option for no persistence:
No persistent authentication data is used. End authentication as soon as the page is closed.

values.name: rememberSessionOnly
values.comment:
Option for session only persistence:
Persistence is limited to the lifetime of the current window.

Perform a user management operation at a Firebase

Operation `createUser` returns a `Just uid` on success,

values.comment: Identify with email and password

docs.name: ElmFire

aliases.name: Error
aliases.comment: Errors reported from Firebase or ElmFire

aliases.name: Snapshot
aliases.comment:
Message about a received value.

- `subscription` can be used to correlate the response to the corresponding query.
- `value` is a Json value (and `null` when the queried location doesn't exist).
- `existing` is `False` iff there is no value at the location, which can only occur in `valueChanged`-queries
- `reference` points to the queried location
- `key` is relevant particular for child queries and specifies the key of the data.
- `prevKey` specifies the key of previous child (or Nothing for the first child), revealing the ordering. It's always Nothing for valueChanged queries.
- `priority` returns the given priority of the data.
aliases.type: { subscription : ElmFire.Subscription , key : String , reference : ElmFire.Reference , existing : Bool , value : Json.Encode.Value , prevKey : Maybe.Maybe String , priority : ElmFire.Priority , intern_ : ElmFire.SnapshotFB }

types.name: Action
types.comment: Possible return values for update functions of a transaction

types.name: AuthErrorType
types.comment: Errors reported from Authentication Module

types.name: Cancellation
types.comment: Message about cancelled query

types.name: ErrorType
types.comment: Type of errors reported from Firebase or ElmFire

types.name: LimitOptions
types.comment: Type to specify limiting the size of the query result set. Used within an ordered query

types.name: Location
types.comment:
A Firebase location, which is an opaque type
that represents a literal path into a firebase.

A location can be constructed or obtained from
- an absolute path by `fromUrl`
- relative to another location by `sub`, `parent`, `root`, `push`
- a reference by `location`

Locations are generally unvalidated until their use in a task.
The constructor functions are pure.

types.name: OrderOptions
types.comment: Type to specify ordering, filtering and limiting of queries

types.name: Priority
types.comment:
Each existing location in a Firebase may be attributed with a priority,
which can be a number or a string.

Priorities can be used for filtering and sorting entries in a query.

types.name: Query
types.comment: A query specification: event type, possibly ordering with filtering and limiting

types.name: RangeOptions
types.comment: Type to specify filtering options for the use within an ordered query

types.name: Reference
types.comment:
A Firebase reference, which is an opaque type that represents an opened path.

References are returned from many Firebase tasks as well as in query results.

types.name: Subscription
types.comment: Unique opaque identifier for running subscriptions

values.comment: Build a query with event type "child added"

values.name: childChanged
values.comment: Build a query with event type "child changed"

values.name: childMoved
values.comment: Build a query with event type "child moved"

values.name: childRemoved
values.comment: Build a query with event type "child removed"

values.name: endAt
values.comment:
Filter the ordered results to end at a given value.

The type of the value depends on the order criterium

values.name: equalTo
values.comment:
Filter the ordered results to equal a given value.

The type of the value depends on the order criterium

values.name: exportValue
values.comment:
Exports the entire contents of a Snapshot as a JavaScript object.

This is similar to .value except priority information is included (if available),
making it suitable for backing up your data.

values.name: fromUrl
values.comment:
Construct a new location from a full Firebase URL.

    loc = fromUrl "https://elmfire.firebaseio-demo.com/foo/bar"

values.name: goOffline
values.comment:
Manually disconnect the client from the server
and disables automatic reconnection.

values.name: goOnline
values.comment:
Manually reestablish a connection to the server
and enables automatic reconnection.

values.name: key
values.comment:
Get the key of a reference.

The last token in a Firebase location is considered its key.
It's the empty string for the root.

values.name: limitToFirst
values.comment: Limit the result set of an ordered query to the first certain number of children.

values.name: limitToLast
values.comment: Limit the result set of an ordered query to the last certain number of children.

values.name: location
values.comment:
Obtain a location from a reference.

    reference = location loc

values.name: noLimit
values.comment: Don't limit the number of children in the result set of an ordered query

values.name: noOrder
values.comment: Don't order results

values.name: noRange
values.comment: Don't filter the ordered results

values.name: onDisconnectCancel
values.comment: Cancels all previously queued operations for this location and all children.

values.name: onDisconnectRemove
values.comment: Queue a `remove` operation on the server that get executed as soon as the client disconnects.

values.name: onDisconnectSet
values.comment: Queue a `set` operation on the server that get executed as soon as the client disconnects.

values.name: onDisconnectSetWithPriority
values.comment: Queue a `setWithPriority` operation on the server that get executed as soon as the client disconnects.

values.name: onDisconnectUpdate
values.comment: Queue a `update` operation on the server that get executed as soon as the client disconnects.

values.name: once
values.comment:
Query a Firebase location for exactly one event of the specified type

On success the tasks results in the desired Snapshot.
It results in an error if either the location is invalid
or you have no permission to read this data.

The third parameter specifies the event to listen to:
`valueChanged`, `childAdded`, `childChanged`, `childRemoved` or `childMoved`.
Additionally, this parameter can also specify ordering, filtering and limiting of the query (see below).

The first parameter specifies the event to listen to:
`valueChanged`, `childAdded`, `childChanged`, `childRemoved` or `childMoved`.
Additionally, this parameter may also specify ordering, filtering and limiting of the query (see below).

The second parameter specifies the location to be queried.

values.name: open
values.comment:
Actually open a location, which results in a reference
(if the location is valid).

It's generally not necessary to explicitly open a constructed location.
It can be used to check the location and to cache Firebase references.

The task fails if the location construct is invalid.

    openTask =
      (open <| sub user <| fromUrl "https://elmfire.firebaseio-demo.com/users")
      `andThen` (\ref -> Signal.send userRefCache.address (user, ref))

values.name: orderByChild
values.comment:
Order results by the value of a given child
(or deep child, as documented [here](https://www.firebase.com/blog/2015-09-24-atomic-writes-and-more.html))

values.name: orderByKey
values.comment: Order results by key

values.name: orderByPriority
values.comment: Order results by priority (and maybe secondary by key)
values.type: ElmFire.RangeOptions ( ElmFire.Priority, Maybe.Maybe String ) -> ElmFire.LimitOptions -> ElmFire.OrderOptions

values.name: orderByValue
values.comment: Order results by value

values.name: parent
values.comment:
Construct the parent location from a child location.

    loc2 = parent loc1

values.name: push
values.comment:
Construct a new child location using a to-be-generated key.

A unique key is generated whenever the location is used in one of the tasks,
notably `open` or `set`.
Keys are prefixed with a client-generated timestamp so that a resulting list
will be chronologically-sorted.

You may `open` the location or use `set` to actually generate the key
and get its name.

    set val (push loc) `andThen` (\ref -> ... key ref ...)

values.name: range
values.comment:
Filter the ordered results to start at a given value and to end at another value.

The type of the value depends on the order criterium

values.name: remove
values.comment:
Delete a Firebase location.

The task completes with a reference to the deleted location when
synchronization to the Firebase servers has completed.
The task may result in an error if the location is invalid
or you have no permission to remove this data.

values.name: root
values.comment:
Construct the root location from descendant location

    loc2 = root loc1

values.name: serverTimeStamp
values.comment:
A placeholder value for auto-populating the current timestamp
(time since the Unix epoch, in milliseconds) by the Firebase servers

values.name: set
values.comment:
Write a Json value to a Firebase location.

The task completes with a reference to the changed location when
synchronization to the Firebase servers has completed.
The task may result in an error if the location is invalid
or you have no permission to write this data.

values.name: setPriority
values.comment: Set a priority for the data at a Firebase location.

values.name: setWithPriority
values.comment: Write a Json value to a Firebase location and specify a priority for that data.
values.type: Json.Encode.Value -> ElmFire.Priority -> ElmFire.Location -> Task.Task ElmFire.Error ElmFire.Reference

values.name: startAt
values.comment:
Filter the ordered results to start at a given value.

The type of the value depends on the order criterium

values.name: sub
values.comment:
Construct a location for the descendant at the specified relative path.

    locUsers = sub "users" loc

values.name: subscribe
values.comment:
Query a Firebase location by subscription

On success the task returns a Subscription,
which can be used to match the corresponding responses
and to unsubscribe the query.

The query results are reported via running a supplied task.

The first parameter is a function used to construct that task from a response.

The second parameter is a function used to construct a task that is run
when the query gets canceled.

The third parameter specifies the event to listen to:
`valueChanged`, `childAdded`, `childChanged`, `childRemoved` or `childMoved`.
Additionally, this parameter may also specify ordering, filtering and limiting of the query (see below).

The fourth parameter specifies the location to be queried.
values.type: (ElmFire.Snapshot -> Task.Task x a) -> (ElmFire.Cancellation -> Task.Task y b) -> ElmFire.Query -> ElmFire.Location -> Task.Task ElmFire.Error ElmFire.Subscription

values.name: subscribeConnected
values.comment: Subscribe to connection state changes
values.type: (Bool -> Task.Task x a) -> ElmFire.Location -> Task.Task ElmFire.Error ElmFire.Subscription

values.name: subscribeServerTimeOffset
values.comment: Subscribe to server time offset
values.type: (Time.Time -> Task.Task x a) -> ElmFire.Location -> Task.Task ElmFire.Error ElmFire.Subscription

values.name: toKeyList
values.comment: Convert a snapshot's children into a list of its keys

values.name: toPairList
values.comment: Convert a snapshot's children into a list of key-value-pairs

values.name: toSnapshotList
values.comment:
Convert a snapshot's children into a list of snapshots

Ordering of the children is presevered.
So, if the snapshot results from a ordered valueChanged-query
then toSnapshotList allows for conserving this ordering as a list.

values.name: toUrl
values.comment: Get the url of a reference.

values.name: toValueList
values.comment: Convert a snapshot's children into a list of its values

values.name: transaction
values.comment:
Transaction: Atomically modify the data at a location

First parameter is a function which will be passed the current data stored at this location (or Nothing if the location contains no data).
The function returns an Action, which is either Set Value, or Abort, or Remove.
The second parameter specifies the location at which the transaction should be performed.
The third parameter denotes whether intermediate states are reported to local query subscriptions (True) or suppressed (False).

On success the task returns a tuple:
Its first element indicates whether the transaction was commited (True) or aborted (False).
Regardless, the second element is a Snapshot containing the resulting data at that location.
values.type: (Maybe.Maybe Json.Encode.Value -> ElmFire.Action) -> ElmFire.Location -> Bool -> Task.Task ElmFire.Error ( Bool, ElmFire.Snapshot )

values.name: unsubscribe
values.comment: Cancel a query subscription

values.name: update
values.comment:
Write the children in a Json value to a Firebase location.

This will overwrite only children present in the first parameter
and will leave others untouched.

It is also possible to do atomic multi-location updates as documented [here](https://www.firebase.com/blog/2015-09-24-atomic-writes-and-more.html).

values.name: valueChanged
values.comment: Build a query with event type "value changed"

docs.name: ElmFire.Op

aliases.name: Config
aliases.comment:
The target of all operations is described in a configuration record:

- `location`: Pointer to the Firebase path (e.g. `ElmFire.fromUrl "https://.../..."`).
- `orderOptions`: Filter and limit elements according to a given order. Use `ElmFire.noOrder` if not needed.
- `encoder`: Function to convert Elm values into JSON values according to the Firebase's schema.
- `decoder`: A Json.Decoder used to convert a JSON value from the Firebase into the corresponding Elm value.

Decoding errors are silently ignored in all operations (if they need the decoder at all).
aliases.type: { location : ElmFire.Location , orderOptions : ElmFire.OrderOptions , encoder : v -> Json.Decode.Value , decoder : Json.Decode.Decoder v }

Perform the operation for each affected element in parallel.

docs.name: ElmFire.Dict

aliases.name: Config
aliases.comment:
Each query target is described by a configuration:

- `location`: Pointer to the Firebase path, e.g. `ElmFire.fromUrl "https://.../..."`.
- `orderOptions`: Filter and limit elements according to a given order. Use `ElmFire.noOrder` if not needed.
- `encoder`: Function to convert Elm values into JSON values according to the Firebase's schema.
  `encoder` is used only in module `ElmFire.Op`, but is present here because the type `Config` is shared between these two modules.
- `decoder`: A Json.Decoder used to convert a JSON value from the Firebase into the corresponding Elm value.

Decoding errors are reported as the special `Delta` value `Undecodable String String`.
They are silently ignored in all other functions of this module.
aliases.type: { location : ElmFire.Location , orderOptions : ElmFire.OrderOptions , encoder : v -> Json.Decode.Value , decoder : Json.Decode.Decoder v }

values.comment: Integrate a signal of deltas, returning a signal of dictionaries.

values.name: mirror
values.comment:
Convenience function that combines subscribing to and integrating of deltas.
It returns a 2-tuple:

- First element is a task to subscribe to the Firebase updates. It needs to be executed to initiate
  the subscritpion. The task's result is another task that can be uses for unsubscribing.
- Second element is a signal of the dictionary that consecutively mirrors the Firebase collection.
values.type: ElmFire.Dict.Config v -> ( Task.Task ElmFire.Error (Task.Task ElmFire.Error ()) , Signal.Signal (Dict.Dict String v) )

values.name: subscribeDelta
values.comment:
Get the initial state from the Firebase and subscribe to subsequent updates.
The resulting deltas are sent to a given mailbox.

The resulting task needs to be executed in order to initiate the subscription.

Its success-result is a task that may be executed later to unsubscribe again.
values.type: Signal.Address (ElmFire.Dict.Delta v) -> ElmFire.Dict.Config v -> Task.Task ElmFire.Error (Task.Task ElmFire.Error ())

values.name: update
values.comment: Update a dictionary by applying a single given delta.
values.type: ElmFire.Dict.Delta v -> Dict.Dict String v -> Dict.Dict String v
