values.name: dequeue
values.comment:
Dequeues an element of the end of a queue, and also returns thel
element in O(1) amortized
values.type: Queue.Queue a -> ( Maybe.Maybe a, Queue.Queue a )

values.name: enqueue
values.comment: Enqueue an element on a queue in O(1)

values.name: foldl
values.comment: Fold across a queue back ot front
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> Queue.Queue a -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment: Fold across a queue front ot back
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> Queue.Queue a -> b

values.name: fromList
values.comment: converts a queue into a list

values.name: init
values.comment: Creates an empty queue

values.name: length
values.comment: Get the length(number of elements) in the queue in O(1)

values.name: map
values.comment:
maps from a queue of type a to a queue containing elements of type
b

values.name: toList
values.comment: converts a list into a queue

docs.name: Lazy

types.name: Lazy
types.comment: A wrapper around a value that will be lazily evaluated.

values.name: andThen
values.comment:
Lazily chain together lazy computations, for when you have a series of
steps that all need to be performed lazily. This can be nice when you need to
pattern match on a value, for example, when appending lazy lists:

    type List a = Empty | Node a (Lazy (List a))

    cons : a -> Lazy (List a) -> Lazy (List a)
    cons first rest =
        Lazy.map (Node first) rest

    append : Lazy (List a) -> Lazy (List a) -> Lazy (List a)
    append lazyList1 lazyList2 =
        lazyList1
          `andThen` \list1 ->
              case list1 of
                Empty ->
                  lazyList2

                Node first rest ->
                  cons first (append rest list2))

By using `andThen` we ensure that neither `lazyList1` or `lazyList2` are forced
before they are needed. So as written, the `append` function delays the pattern
matching until later.
values.type: Lazy.Lazy a -> (a -> Lazy.Lazy b) -> Lazy.Lazy b

values.name: apply
values.comment:
Lazily apply a lazy function to a lazy value. This is pretty rare on its
own, but it lets you map as high as you want.

    map3 f a b == f `map` a `apply` b `apply` c

It is not the most beautiful, but it is equivalent and will let you create
`map9` quite easily if you really need it.
values.type: Lazy.Lazy (a -> b) -> Lazy.Lazy a -> Lazy.Lazy b

values.name: force
values.comment:
Force the evaluation of a lazy value. This means we only pay for the
computation when we need it. Here is a rather contrived example.

    lazySum : Lazy Int
    lazySum =
        lazy (\() -> List.sum [1..1000000])

    sums : (Int, Int, Int)
    sums =
        (force lazySum, force lazySum, force lazySum)

We are forcing this computation three times. The cool thing is that the first
time you `force` a value, the result is stored. This means you pay the cost on
the first one, but all the rest are very cheap, basically just looking up a
value in memory.

values.name: lazy
values.comment:
Delay the evaluation of a value until later. For example, maybe we will
need to generate a very long list and find its sum, but we do not want to do
it unless it is absolutely necessary.

    lazySum : Lazy Int
    lazySum =
        lazy (\() -> sum [1..1000000])

Now we only pay for `lazySum` if we actually need it.

values.name: map
values.comment:
Lazily apply a function to a lazy value.

    lazySum : Lazy Int
    lazySum =
        map List.sum (lazy (\() -> [1..1000000]))

The resulting lazy value will create a big list and sum it up when it is
finally forced.

values.name: map2
values.comment:
Lazily apply a function to two lazy values.

    lazySum : Lazy Int
    lazySum =
        lazy (\() -> List.sum [1..1000000])

    lazySumPair : Lazy (Int, Int)
    lazySumPair =
        map2 (,) lazySum lazySum
values.type: (a -> b -> result) -> Lazy.Lazy a -> Lazy.Lazy b -> Lazy.Lazy result

values.name: map3
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> result) -> Lazy.Lazy a -> Lazy.Lazy b -> Lazy.Lazy c -> Lazy.Lazy result

values.name: map4
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> result) -> Lazy.Lazy a -> Lazy.Lazy b -> Lazy.Lazy c -> Lazy.Lazy d -> Lazy.Lazy result

values.name: map5
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> result) -> Lazy.Lazy a -> Lazy.Lazy b -> Lazy.Lazy c -> Lazy.Lazy d -> Lazy.Lazy e -> Lazy.Lazy result

docs.name: Color.Mixing
docs.comment:
@docs Factor, lighten, darken, saturate, desaturate, fade, fadeIn, fadeOut,  mix, spin, tint, shade

@docs average, difference, exclusion, hardlight, multiply, negation, overlay, screen, softlight

aliases.name: Factor
aliases.comment: A Float that should be between 0.0 and 1.0

values.name: average
values.comment: Compute the average of two colors on a per-channel (RGB) basis.

values.name: darken
values.comment: Decrease the lightness of a color.

values.name: desaturate
values.comment: Decrease the saturation of a color in the HSL color space by an absolute amount.

values.name: difference
values.comment: Subtracts the second color from the first color on a channel-by-channel basis. Negative values are inverted. Subtracting black results in no change; subtracting white results in color inversion.

values.name: exclusion
values.comment: A similar effect to difference with lower contrast.

values.name: fade
values.comment: Set the absolute transparency of a color.

values.name: fadeIn
values.comment: Decrease the transparency of a color, making it more opaque.

values.name: fadeOut
values.comment: Increase the transparency of a color, making it less opaque.

values.name: hardlight
values.comment: The same as overlay but with the color roles reversed.

values.name: lighten
values.comment: Increase the lightness of a color.

values.name: mix
values.comment: Mix two colors together in variable proportion. Opacity is included in the calculations.

values.name: multiply
values.comment: Multiply two colors. Corresponding RGB channels from each of the two colors are multiplied together then divided by 255. The result is a darker color.

values.name: negation
values.comment: Do the opposite effect to difference.

values.name: overlay
values.comment:
Combines the effects of both multiply and screen. Conditionally make light channels lighter and dark channels darker.

__Note:__ The results of the conditions are determined by the first color parameter.

values.name: saturate
values.comment: Increase the saturation of a color in the HSL color space by an absolute amount.

values.name: screen
values.comment: Do the opposite of `multiply`. The result is a brighter color.

values.name: shade
values.comment: Mix color with black in variable proportion.  Same as calling `mix` with black.

values.name: softlight
values.comment: Similar to overlay but avoids pure black resulting in pure black, and pure white resulting in pure white.

values.name: spin
values.comment: Rotate the hue angle of a color in either direction.

values.name: tint
values.comment: Mix color with white in variable proportion. Same as calling `mix` with white.

docs.name: Html.Animation

types.name: Action
types.comment:
Actions to be run on an animation.
You won't be constructing this type directly, though it may show up in your type signatures.

To start animations you'll be using the `animate`, `queue`, and `stagger` functions

types.name: Animation
types.comment: An Animation of CSS properties.

values.name: add
values.comment: Animate a StyleProperty by adding to its existing value

values.name: andThen
values.comment:
Append another keyframe.  This is used for multistage animations.  

For example, to cycle through colors, we'd use the following:

      UI.animate
              |> UI.props
                  [ BackgroundColor
                        UI.toRGBA 100 100 100 1.0
                  ]
          |> UI.andThen -- create a new keyframe
              |> UI.duration (1*second)
              |> UI.props
                  [ BackgroundColor
                        UI.toRGBA 178 201 14 1.0
                  ]
          |> UI.andThen
              |> UI.props
                  [ BackgroundColor
                        UI.toRGBA 58 40 69 1.0
                  ]
          |> UI.on model.style

values.name: animate
values.comment:
Begin describing an animation.  This animation will cleanly interrupt any animation that is currently running.

      UI.animate
         |> UI.duration (0.4*second)
         |> UI.props
             [ Left (UI.to 0) Px
             , Opacity (UI.to 1)
             ]
         |> UI.on model.style

values.name: delay
values.comment:
Specify a delay.  
If not specified, the default is 0.

     UI.animate
         |> UI.duration (0.4*second)
         |> UI.delay (0.5*second)
         |> UI.props
             [ Left (UI.to 0) Px
             , Opacity (UI.to 1)
             ]
         |> UI.on model.style

values.name: duration
values.comment:
Specify a duration.  This is ignored unless an easing is specified as well!  This is because spring functions (the default), have dynamically created durations.

If an easing is specified but no duration, the default duration is 350ms.

     UI.animate
         |> UI.easing (\x -> x)  -- linear easing
         |> UI.duration (0.4*second)
         |> UI.props
             [ Left (UI.to 0) Px
             , Opacity (UI.to 1)
             ]
         |> UI.on model.style

values.name: easing
values.comment: Specify an easing function.  It is expected that values should match up at the beginning and end.  So, f 0 == 0 and f 1 == 1.  The default easing is sinusoidal in-out.

values.name: forwardTo
values.comment:
This function is used to handle the boilerplate of forwarding animation updates, and can be used in place of `on`.

To use this function, you'll need to supply a getter and a setter function for getting and setting the style model.

So, for a model like the following

    type alias Model = { style : UI.Animation }

Add an action to your Action type to capture the UI.Actions.

    type Action 
          = Hide
          | Animate UI.Action


Create a specialized version of `forwardTo`.

    onModel = 
      UI.forwardTo
          Animate -- The action that captures UI.Action 
          .style -- style getter
          (\w style -> { w | style = style }) -- style setter

Then, in your update function would look something like 


      Hide ->
        UI.animate
            |> UI.duration (5*second)
            |> UI.props
                [ Opacity (UI.to 0)
                ]
            |> onModel model

      Animate uiAction ->
        onModel model uiAction
values.type: (Html.Animation.Action -> b) -> (a -> Html.Animation.Animation) -> (a -> Html.Animation.Animation -> a) -> a -> Html.Animation.Action -> ( a, Effects.Effects b )

values.name: forwardToAll
values.comment:
Like `forwardToIndex`, except it applies an update to every member of the list.
It has the same set up as `forwardToIndex`, except:

You'll need two helper functions

  onWidget = 
    UI.forwardToIndex
        Animate
        .style -- widget style getter
        (\w style -> { w | style = style }) -- widget style setter
                                      
  onAllWidgets = 
      UI.forwardToAll 
          Animate
          .style -- widget style getter
          (\w style -> { w | style = style }) -- widget style setter



And your update function will look like the following

    Hide ->
      let 
        (widgets, fx) = 
            UI.animate
               |> UI.delay ((i * 0.05) * second)
               |> UI.spring UI.wobbly
               |> UI.props 
                   [ Left (UI.to -70) Px
                   ] 
              |> onAllWidgets model.widgets 
              -- apply an update to all widgets

      in
        ( { model | widgets = widgets }
        , fx )

    
    -- But, in animate, you only need to forwad to a widget based on index
    Animate i action ->
      let
        (widgets, fx) = 
            onWidget i model.widgets action
      in
        ( { model | widgets = widgets }
        , fx )
values.type: (Int -> Html.Animation.Action -> b) -> (a -> Html.Animation.Animation) -> (a -> Html.Animation.Animation -> a) -> List a -> Html.Animation.Action -> ( List a, Effects.Effects b )

values.name: forwardToIndex
values.comment:
Forward style updates to a specific element in a list that has a Animation model.

For a model like the following

    type alias Model = { widgets : List Widget }

    type alias Widget =
              { style : UI.Animation
              }
  
    type Action 
          = Hide
          | Animate Int UI.Action -- where Int is the index of the widget we are animating

Create a specialized version of `forwardToIndex`.

    onWidget = 
      UI.forwardToIndex
          Animate
          .style -- widget style getter
          (\w style -> { w | style = style }) -- widget style setter

And in your update function:

    Hide ->
      let
        (widgets, fx) =
            UI.animate
                |> UI.duration (5*second)
                |> UI.props
                    [ Opacity (UI.to 0)
                    ]
                |> onWidget i model.widgets
                -- Where i is the index of the widget to update.
      in
        ( { model | widgets = widgets }
        , fx ) -- FX has already been `Effects.map`ped to Animate

    Animate i action ->
      let
        (widgets, fx) = 
            onWidget i model.widgets action
      in
        ( { model | widgets = widgets }
        , fx )
values.type: (Int -> Html.Animation.Action -> b) -> (a -> Html.Animation.Animation) -> (a -> Html.Animation.Animation -> a) -> Int -> List a -> Html.Animation.Action -> ( List a, Effects.Effects b )

values.name: fromColor
values.comment: Specify an initial Color-based property using a Color from the elm core Color module.
values.type: Color.Color -> (Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Core.Static) -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Core.Static

values.name: gentle
values.comment: A spring preset.

values.name: hsl
values.comment: Specify an initial Color-based property using hsl
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> (Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Core.Static) -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Core.Static

values.name: hsla
values.comment: Specify an initial Color-based property using hsla
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> Float -> (Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Core.Static) -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Core.Static

values.name: init
values.comment:
Create an initial style for your init model.

__Note__ All properties that you animate must be present in the init or else that property won't be animated.

values.name: minus
values.comment: Animate a StyleProperty by subtracting to its existing value

values.name: noWobble
values.comment: A spring preset.  Probably should be your initial goto for using springs.

values.name: on
values.comment:
Apply an update to a Animation model.  This is used at the end of constructing an animation.
However, you'll have an overall cleaner syntax if you use `forwardTo` to prepare a custom version of `on`.

     UI.animate
         |> UI.duration (0.4*second)
         |> UI.props
             [ Left (UI.to 0) Px 
             , Opacity (UI.to 1)
             ]
         |> UI.on model.style

values.name: props
values.comment:
Specify the properties that should be animated

     UI.animate
         |> UI.duration (0.4*second)
         |> UI.props
             [ Left (UI.to 0) Px
             , Opacity (UI.to 1)
             ]
         |> UI.on model.style

values.name: queue
values.comment:
The same as `animate` but instead of interrupting the current animation, this will queue up after the current animation is finished.

      UI.queue
         |> UI.duration (0.4*second)
         |> UI.props
             [ Left (UI.to 0) Px
             , Opacity (UI.to 1)
             ]
         |> UI.on model.style

values.name: render
values.comment:
Render into concrete css that can be directly applied to 'style' in elm-html

    div [ style (UI.render widget.style) ] [ ]

values.name: rgb
values.comment: Specify an initial Color-based property using rgb
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> (Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Core.Static) -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Core.Static

values.name: rgba
values.comment: Specify an initial Color-based property using rgba
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> Float -> (Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Core.Static -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Core.Static) -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Core.Static

values.name: set
values.comment:
Apply a style immediately.  This takes a list of static style properties, meaning the no `UI.to` functions, only concrete numbers and values.


    UI.animate
         |> UI.duration (0.4*second)
         |> UI.props
             [ Opacity (UI.to 1)
             ]
      |> UI.andThen
         |> UI.set
             [ Display None
             ]
         |> UI.on model.style

values.name: spring
values.comment:
Animate based on spring physics.  

You'll need to provide both a stiffness and a dampness to this function.

__Note:__ This will cause both `duration` and `easing` to be ignored as they are now controlled by the spring.

     UI.animate
         -- |> UI.spring UI.noWobble -- set using a UI preset
         |> UI.spring 
                { stiffness = 400
                , damping = 28
                }
         |> UI.props
             [ Left (UI.to 0) Px
             , Opacity (UI.to 1)
             ]
         |> UI.on model.style

values.name: stagger
values.comment:
Can be used to stagger animations on a list of widgets.

     UI.stagger
        (\i ->
           UI.animate
             -- The delay is staggered based on list index
             |> UI.delay (i * 0.05 * second) 
             |> UI.duration (0.3 * second)
             |> UI.props
                 [ Left (UI.to 200) Px
                 ]
          |> UI.andThen
             |> UI.delay (2.0 * second)
             |> UI.duration (0.3 * second)
             |> UI.props
                 [ Left (UI.to -50) Px
                 ]
        )
        |> forwardToAllWidgets model.widgets

values.name: stay
values.comment: Keep an animation where it is!  This is useful for stacking transforms.

values.name: stiff
values.comment: A spring preset.

values.name: to
values.comment: Animate a StyleProperty to a value.

values.name: toColor
values.comment: Animate a color-based property, given a color from the Color elm module.

values.name: toHSL
values.comment: Animate a color-based style property to an hsl color. Note: this leaves the alpha channel where it is.
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> Html.Animation.ColorProperty -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Dynamic

values.name: toHSLA
values.comment: Animate a color-based style property to an hsla color.
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> Float -> Html.Animation.ColorProperty -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Dynamic

values.name: toRGB
values.comment:
Animate a color-based style property to an rgb color.  Note: this leaves the alpha channel where it is.

     UI.animate
            |> UI.props
                [ BackgroundColor
                      UI.toRGB 100 100 100
                ]
            |> UI.on model.style
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> Html.Animation.ColorProperty -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Dynamic

values.name: toRGBA
values.comment:
Animate a color-based style property to an rgba color.

       UI.animate
            |> UI.props
                [ BackgroundColor
                    UI.toRGBA 100 100 100 1.0
                ]
            |> UI.on model.style
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> Float -> Html.Animation.ColorProperty -> Html.Animation.Properties.StyleProperty Html.Animation.Dynamic

values.name: update
values.comment:
Update an animation.  This will probably only show up once in your code.
See any of the examples at [https://github.com/mdgriffith/elm-html-animation](https://github.com/mdgriffith/elm-html-animation)

values.name: wobbly
values.comment: A spring preset.

docs.name: Html.Animation.Properties

types.name: Angle
types.comment: Units representing angles.

types.name: DisplayMode
types.comment:
A Display value used for the display property.
A display mode is not animated but can be set using Html.Animation.set

types.name: Length
types.comment: Units representing length.

types.name: StyleProperty
types.comment: All currently animatable properties.

docs.name: Multiset
docs.comment:
A Multiset is a mapping from comparable keys to Int counts. What makes a
Multiset special is that you never have to worry about Maybe values; instead
you'll get zero. This simplifies the insert and query functions.

Multisets do not store counts of zero explicitly, so don't expect them in `map`,
`filter`, `counts`, and the like. You should equate multisets with the given
`equals` function and not the built-in `(==)`. Multisets support negative
counts.

**NOTICE:** This package is being renamed `mgold/elm-multiset`, lowercase, for compatibility.

# Definition
@docs Multiset

# Create
@docs empty, singleton, fromList, fromAssocList

# Update
@docs add, remove, set, update

# Query
@docs get, equals, keys, counts, toList

# Transform
@docs map, map2, foldl, foldr, filter, partition

aliases.name: Multiset
aliases.comment:
A Multiset is a wrapper around
[Dict](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/latest/Dict), but you
should treat the type as opaque  except when you're trying to solve type
inference errors.

values.name: add
values.comment: Add a key to the multiset, incrementing its count by one.

values.name: counts
values.comment: Get all of the counts in a multiset.

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty multiset.

values.name: equals
values.comment:
Equate two multisets. You should use this function instead of `(==)`, which
equates the tree representation rather than the abstract container. You can also
use this function and `empty` for empty checking.

    empty `equals` (fromAssocList [("foo", 0)]) == True
    empty `equals` singleton "bar" == False
    (fromList [1,2,1]) `equals` (fromList [1,1,2]) == True

values.name: filter
values.comment: Keep a key-count pair when it satisfies a predicate.
values.type: (comparable -> Int -> Bool) -> Multiset.Multiset comparable -> Multiset.Multiset comparable

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Fold over the key-count pairs in a dictionary, in order from lowest key to
highest key.
values.type: (comparable -> Int -> b -> b) -> b -> Multiset.Multiset comparable -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment:
Fold over the key-count pairs in a dictionary, in order from highest key to
lowest key.
values.type: (comparable -> Int -> b -> b) -> b -> Multiset.Multiset comparable -> b

values.name: fromAssocList
values.comment:
Convert an association list of key-count pairs into a multiset. It is safe
to have some counts be zero (but it's pointless to hard-code any zeroes).

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert a list of keys into a multiset, counting repeats.

values.name: get
values.comment: Get the count of a key, which may be zero.

values.name: keys
values.comment: Get all of the keys in a multiset.

values.name: map
values.comment:
Map over a multiset, changing the counts of the keys. It is safe to return
zero.
values.type: (comparable -> Int -> Int) -> Multiset.Multiset comparable -> Multiset.Multiset comparable

values.name: map2
values.comment:
Map over two multisets, producing a new multiset. It is safe to return zero.
You can use this function to add two multisets: `map2 (always (+))`. Similar
approaches will substract or find the max or min of multisets.
values.type: (comparable -> Int -> Int -> Int) -> Multiset.Multiset comparable -> Multiset.Multiset comparable -> Multiset.Multiset comparable

values.name: partition
values.comment:
Partition a dictionary according to a predicate. The first dictionary
contains all key-count pairs which satisfy the predicate, and the second
contains the rest.
values.type: (comparable -> Int -> Bool) -> Multiset.Multiset comparable -> ( Multiset.Multiset comparable, Multiset.Multiset comparable )

values.name: remove
values.comment: Remove a key from the multiset, decrementing its count by one.

values.name: set
values.comment: Set the count of a key to a new integer, regardness of what it used to be.
values.type: comparable -> Int -> Multiset.Multiset comparable -> Multiset.Multiset comparable

values.name: singleton
values.comment: Create a multiset containing the key once.

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert a multiset into an association list of key-count pairs.

values.name: update
values.comment:
Update the count of a comparable using the given function. It is safe to
return zero.
values.type: comparable -> (Int -> Int) -> Multiset.Multiset comparable -> Multiset.Multiset comparable

docs.name: Animation
docs.comment:
A library for animating between two `Float` values. For example, animate a panel's width from 100px to 300px over 2
seconds, or make a button spin and grow on hover. Everything is a pure function (no signals or tasks), so you can use it
easily within your architecture. You can also inspect animations to determine if they are still running and for how
long, and even smoothly retarget a different destination midflight.

The library encapsulates a 3-stage animation pipeline:

* **Timekeeping:** You are expected to maintain a running clock. If you are using `elm-effects`, request `Effects.tick`
    with an action to store the clock in the model. Otherwise, use `Time.fps` or `AnimationFrame.frame`, which provide
    time *deltas* that you will have to sum either in your model or with using `Signal.foldp (+) 0`. However obtained,
    this clock is used to create an animation and again to obtain the current value. You can also specify a delay and
    the duration for your animation.

* **Easing:** An easing function is what makes an animation come alive with acceleration and sometimes even elasticity.
    When setting the easing function for your animation, I recommend [Dan's
    library](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/Dandandan/Easing/latest/Easing#easing-functions). (Dan also has your
    back if you need to interpolate pairs or colors with the output of this library.)

* **Interpolation:** It wouldn't be very useful is all animations went from 0 to 1 (the default), would it? You can
    specify values to animate `from` and `to`. Furthermore, you can set the average speed (distance between these two
    values per milisecond) instead of a duration.

Once you have your value at the current time, you can render it to any frontend you choose: Collage, Element, Html,
[Turtles](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/mgold/elm-turtle-graphics/latest)...

## Basic Usage
`animation` creates an animation starting at the given time (usually the current time). `animate` takes the current time
and an animation, and produces the current value. Animations go through three phases (not related to the three stages of
rendering): they are scheduled, they run, and then they are done.

````elm
import Animation exposing (..)
import Time exposing (second)

myAnim = animation 0 |> from 100 |> to 300 |> duration (4*second) |> delay (1*second)
List.map (\t -> animate (t*second) myAnim) [0..6]
-- [100, 100, 129.29, 200, 270.71, 300, 300]
````

Notice that the value remains constant during the delay and after the animation is done. You can also use `static` to
create animations of constant value. By using these two degenerate cases, you ought to be able to keep animations in
your model without worrying about when they aren't actually animating.

# Create
@docs animation, static

# Run
@docs animate

# Modify
## Settings
You may set an animation's duration or speed but not both, since one determines the other.
@docs duration, speed, delay, ease, from, to

## Interruptions
@docs undo, retarget

# Inspect
## Equality
@docs equals

## Lifecycle
@docs isScheduled, isRunning, isDone

## Physics
@docs timeElapsed, timeRemaining, velocity

## Settings
@docs getStart, getDuration, getSpeed, getDelay, getEase, getFrom, getTo

# The Animation Type
@docs Animation

types.name: Animation
types.comment: An Animation is an opaque type that represents a time-varying number (floating point value).

values.name: animate
values.comment: Produce the value of an animation at a given time.

values.name: animation
values.comment:
Create an animation that begins at the given time. By default, animations have no delay, last 750ms, and interpolate
between 0 and 1 with a sinusoidal easing function. All of these can be changed.

values.name: delay
values.comment:
Set the delay of an animation to the time specified. An animation will not start until after the delay. The default
delay is 0. Note that the `Time` argument is _not_ the current running time but the delay to be set.

values.name: duration
values.comment:
Set the duration of an animation to the time specified. Note that the `Time` argument is _not_ the current running
time but the duration to be set.

values.name: ease
values.comment:
Set the easing function of an animation. It is expected that `f 0 == 0` and `f 1 == 1`. The default is a sinusoidal
in-out.

values.name: equals
values.comment:
Equality on animations. Compared to `(==)` (which should not be used), this
function handles the conversion of speed and duration, and start and delay. It
also samples the easing functions, which may produce false positives (but
usually not in practice).

    -- These are True
    animation 0 `equals` animation 0
    (animation 0 |> delay 10) `equals` animation 10
    (animation 0 |> duration 1000) `equals` (animation 0 |> speed 0.001)

    -- These are False
    static 0 `equals` animation 0
    (animation 0 |> from -1) `equals` animation 0
    (animation 0 |> ease identity) `equals` animation 0

values.name: from
values.comment: Set the initial value of an animation. The default is 0.

values.name: getDelay
values.comment: Get the delay of the animation.

values.name: getDuration
values.comment: Get the duration of the animation, not counting delay.

values.name: getEase
values.comment: Get the easing function of the animation.

values.name: getFrom
values.comment: Get the initial value of the animation.

values.name: getSpeed
values.comment: Get the average speed of the animation.

values.name: getStart
values.comment:
Get the start time of the animation, not accounting for delay. For animations created with `animate`, this is the
argument that was passed. For interrupted animations, this is when the interruption occured.

values.name: getTo
values.comment: Get the final value of the animation.

values.name: isDone
values.comment: Determine if an animation is done, meaning that it has arrived at its final value.

values.name: isRunning
values.comment: Determine if an animation is running, meaning that it is currently changing value.

values.name: isScheduled
values.comment: Determine if an animation is scheduled, meaning that it has not yet changed value.

values.name: retarget
values.comment:
Change the `to` value of a running animation, without an abrupt change in velocity. The easing function will be
retained (but you can change it with `ease`). The animation will retain its average speed (but not necessarily
duration). If you retarget multiple animations at once (e.g. x and y), you will need to sync their durations (perhaps to
the `timeRemaining` in the old animations).

If the retargeted animation is still scheduled, the `to` value is replaced. If it's already done, `from` becomes the
old `to`, `to` and `start` are set to the values provided, and the delay is set to zero. If the old and new `to` values
are the same, the animation is unchanged.

values.name: speed
values.comment:
Set the _average_ speed of an animation. Speed is the rate at which the animation progresses between the `from` and
`to` values per milisecond. Most easing functions will deviate from the average speed. You do not need to worry about
the sign. It is safe to alter the `from` and `to` values after setting speed.

values.name: static
values.comment: Create a static animation that is always the given value.

values.name: timeElapsed
values.comment:
Get the time elapsed since the animation started playing (after the end of delay). Will be zero for animations that
are still scheduled, and is not bounded for animations that are already done.

values.name: timeRemaining
values.comment:
Get the time that the animation has yet to play (or be delayed) before becoming done. Will be zero for animations
that are already done.

values.name: to
values.comment:
Set the final value of an animation. The default is 1.

For animations that are already running, use `retarget`.

values.name: undo
values.comment:
Run an animation in reverse from its current state, beginning immediately (even if the animation was delayed or has
been done for a while).

Usually you don't want to undo an animation that has been retargeted; just retarget it again. Similarly, undoing an
undone animation is frequently not what you want.

values.name: velocity
values.comment:
Get the _current_ velocity of the animation, aproximated by looking 10ms forwards and backwards (the central
difference). The velocity may be negative.

docs.name: Date.Format
docs.comment:
Format strings for dates.

@docs format, formatISO8601

values.name: format
values.comment:
Use a format string to format a date. See the
[README](https://github.com/mgold/elm-date-format/blob/master/README.md) for a
list of accepted formatters.

values.name: formatISO8601
values.comment:
Formats a UTC date acording to
[ISO-8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601). This is commonly used to
send dates to a server. For example: `2016-01-06T09:22:00Z`.

docs.name: List.Nonempty

types.name: Nonempty
types.comment:
The Nonempty type. If you have both a head and tail, you can construct a
nonempty list directly. Otherwise use the helpers below instead.

values.comment:
Infix cons. Note that you cannot use this for pattern matching. Be sure to add `exposing ((:::))` to your import.

    4 ::: Nonempty 3 [2,1] == Nonempty 4 [3,2,1]

values.name: all
values.comment: Determine if all elements satisfy the predicate.

values.name: andMap
values.comment:
Map over an arbitrary number of nonempty lists.

    map2 (,) xs ys == map (,) xs `andMap` ys
    head (map (,,) xs `andMap` ys `andMap` zs) == (head xs, head ys, head zs)
values.type: List.Nonempty.Nonempty (a -> b) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b

values.name: any
values.comment: Determine if any elements satisfy the predicate.

values.name: append
values.comment: Append two nonempty lists together. `(++)` is _not_ supported.
values.type: List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a

values.name: concat
values.comment: Flatten a nonempty list of nonempty lists into a single nonempty list.

values.name: concatMap
values.comment:
Map a given function onto a nonempty list and flatten the resulting nonempty lists. If you're chaining, you can
define `andThen = flip concatMap`.
values.type: (a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b

values.name: cons
values.comment: Add another element as the head of the list, pushing the previous head to the tail.

values.name: dedup
values.comment:
Remove _adjacent_ duplicate elements from the nonempty list.

    dedup (Nonempty 1 [2, 2, 1]) == Nonempty 1 [2, 1]

values.name: dropTail
values.comment: Replace the tail with the empty list while leaving the head alone.

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Filter a nonempty list. If all values are filtered out, return the singleton list containing the default value
provided. If any value is retained, the default value is not used. If you want to deal with a Maybe instead, use
`toList >> List.filter yourPredicate >> fromList`.

    filter isEven 0 (Nonempty 7 [2, 5]) == fromElement 2
    filter isEven 0 (Nonempty 7 []) == fromElement 0
values.type: (a -> Bool) -> a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Reduce a nonempty list from the left with a base case.

    foldl (++) "" (Nonempty "a" ["b", "c"]) == "cba"
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> b

values.name: foldl1
values.comment:
Reduce a nonempty list from the left _without_ a base case. As per Elm convention, the first argument is the current
element and the second argument is the accumulated value. The function is first invoked on the _second_ element, using
the first element as the accumulated value, except for singleton lists in which has the head is returned.

    foldl1 (++) (Nonempty "a" ["b", "c"]) == "cba"
    foldl1 (++) (fromElement "a") == "a"

    findMe = 42
    minimizeMe n = abs (n-findMe)
    nearest = foldl1 (\a b -> if minimizeMe a < minimizeMe b then a else b) (Nonempty 10 [20,30,40,50,60])
    nearest == 40

values.name: fromElement
values.comment: Create a singleton list with the given element.

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Create a nonempty list from an ordinary list, failing on the empty list.

values.name: get
values.comment:
Get the item at the specified index. The head has index 0. Indices are modulused by the length so out-of-range
errors can't happen. This means that negative indices are supported, e.g. -1 to get the last element.

values.name: head
values.comment: Return the head of the list.

values.name: indexedMap
values.comment: Same as `map` but the function is also applied to the index of each element (starting at zero).
values.type: (Int -> a -> b) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b

values.name: isSingleton
values.comment: Determine if the nonempty list has exactly one element.

values.name: length
values.comment: Find the length of the nonempty list.

values.name: map
values.comment: Map a function over a nonempty list.

values.name: map2
values.comment: Map a function over two nonempty lists.
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty c

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if an element is present in the nonempty list.

values.name: pop
values.comment:
Pop and discard the head, or do nothing for a singleton list. Useful if you
want to exhaust a list but hang on to the last item indefinitely.

    pop (Nonempty 3 [2,1]) == Nonempty 2 [1]
    pop (Nonempty 1 []) == Nonempty 1 []

values.name: replaceHead
values.comment: Exchange the head element while leaving the tail alone.

values.name: replaceTail
values.comment: Exchange the tail for another while leaving the head alone.
values.type: List a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a

values.name: reverse
values.comment: Reverse a nonempty list.

values.name: sample
values.comment: Create a random generator that returns a value of the nonempty list chosen uniformly at random.

values.name: scanl
values.comment:
Like `foldl`, but keep each intermediate value. For example, scan addition to create the cumulative sum up to each
element. The head of the new nonempty list is always the base case provided, and the length increases by 1.

    scanl (++) "" (Nonempty "a" ["b", "c"]) == Nonempty "" ["a","ba","cba"]
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b

values.name: scanl1
values.comment:
Like `foldl1`, but keep each intermediate value. The head and length are not changed.

This example starts with the number of ways to roll exactly index _i_ on two six-sided dice (the probability density
function), and turns it into the number of ways to roll at least _i_ (the cumulative density function).

    dicePDF = Nonempty 0 [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,5,4,3,2,1]
    diceCDF = scanl1 (+) dicePDF
    diceCDF == Nonempty 0 [0,1,3,6,10,15,21,26,30,33,35,36]
values.type: (a -> a -> a) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a

values.name: sort
values.comment: Sort a nonempty list of comparable things, lowest to highest.

values.name: sortBy
values.comment: Sort a nonempty list of things by a derived property.

values.name: sortWith
values.comment: Sort a nonempty list of things by a custom comparison function.
values.type: (a -> a -> Basics.Order) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a

values.name: tail
values.comment: Return the tail of the list.

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert to an ordinary list.

values.name: uniq
values.comment:
Remove _all_ duplicate elements from the nonempty list, with the remaining elements ordered by first occurrence.

    uniq (Nonempty 1 [2, 2, 1]) == Nonempty 1 [2]

docs.name: Random.PCG.Interop
docs.comment:
Provides a function to create a PCG seed from a seed in the core library.
This is useful for library writers who need a splittable or most robust PRNG but
don't want to require client code to use the PCG implementation.

```elm
import Random
import Random.PCG
import Random.PCG.Interop as Random.PCG
```

@docs fission

values.name: fission
values.comment:
Use the core library's random seed to produce a PCG random seed.

It seems that the package website doesn't show modules in type annotations, so here it is in full:

    fission : Random.Seed -> (Random.PCG.Seed, Random.Seed)

docs.name: Random.PCG
docs.comment:
Generate psuedo-random numbers and values, by constructing
[generators](#Generator) for them. There are a bunch of basic generators like
[`bool`](#bool) and [`int`](#int) that you can build up into fancier generators
with functions like [`list`](#list) and [`map`](#map).

You run a `Generator` by calling the [`generate`](#generate) function, which
also takes a random [`Seed`](#Seed), and passes back a new seed. You should
never use the same seed twice because you will get the same result! If you need
random values over time, you should store the most recent seed in your model. If
you have many separate models, you can give them all [independent
seeds](#independentSeed).

This is an implementation of [PCG](http://www.pcg-random.org/) by M. E. O'Neil,
and is not cryptographically secure.

# Getting Started
@docs initialSeed2, generate

# Basic Generators
@docs Generator, bool, int, float, oneIn

# Combining Generators
@docs pair, list, maybe, choice

# Custom Generators
@docs constant, map, map2, map3, map4, map5, andMap, andThen, filter

# Working With Seeds
@docs Seed, initialSeed, independentSeed, fastForward, toJson, fromJson, split

# Constants
@docs maxInt, minInt

types.name: Generator
types.comment:
A `Generator` is like a recipe for generating certain random values. So a
`Generator Int` describes how to generate integers and a `Generator String`
describes how to generate strings.

types.name: Seed
types.comment:
A `Seed` is the source of randomness in the whole system. It hides the
current state of the random number generator.

Generators, not seeds, are the primary data structure for generating random
values. Generators are much easier to chain and combine than functions that take
and return seeds. Creating and managing seeds should happen "high up" in your
program.

values.name: andMap
values.comment:
Map over any number of generators.

    randomPerson : Generator Person
    randomPerson =
      person `map` genFirstName
          `andMap` genLastName
          `andMap` genBirthday
          `andMap` genPhoneNumber
          `andMap` genAddress
          `andMap` genEmail
values.type: Random.PCG.Generator (a -> b) -> Random.PCG.Generator a -> Random.PCG.Generator b

values.name: andThen
values.comment:
Chain random operations by providing a callback that accepts a
randomly-generated value. The random value can be used to drive more randomness.

The argument order matches `andThen`s from core, but requires the use of `flip`
to match `map` or work with `|>` chains.

This example shows how we can use `andThen` to generate a list of random values
*and* random length. Then we use `map` to apply a stateless function to that
list. Assume we already have `genName : Generator String` defined.

    authors : Generator String
    authors =
      int 1 5 -- number of authors
      |> (flip andThen) (\i -> list i genName)
      |> map (\ns ->
        case ns of
          [n] ->
            "Author: " ++ n
          n::ns ->
            "Authors: " ++ String.join ", " ns ++ " and " ++ n
          [] ->
            "This can't happen"
        )

If you find yourself calling `constant` in every branch of the callback, you can
probably use `map` instead.
values.type: Random.PCG.Generator a -> (a -> Random.PCG.Generator b) -> Random.PCG.Generator b

values.name: bool
values.comment:
Create a generator that produces boolean values with equal probability. This
example simulates flipping three coins and checking if they're all heads.

    threeHeads : Generator Bool
    threeHeads =
      map3 (\a b c -> a && b && c) bool bool bool

values.name: choice
values.comment:
Choose between two values with equal probability.

    type Flip = Heads | Tails

    coinFlip : Generator Flip
    coinFlip =
      choice Heads Tails

values.name: constant
values.comment:
Create a generator that always produces the value provided. This is useful
when creating complicated chained generators and you need to handle a simple
case. It's also useful for the base case of recursive generators.

values.name: fastForward
values.comment:
Fast forward a seed the given number of steps, which may be negative (the
seed will be "rewound"). This allows a single seed to serve as a random-access
lookup table of random numbers. (To be sure no one else uses the seed, use
`generate independentSeed` to split off your own.)

    diceRollTable : Int -> Int
    diceRollTable i =
      fastForward i mySeed |> generate (int 1 6) |> fst

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Filter a generator so that all generated values satisfy the given predicate.

    evens : Generator Int
    evens =
      filter (\i -> i % 2 == 0) (int minInt maxInt)

If the predicate is unsatisfiable, the generator will not terminate, your
application will crash with a stack overflow, and you will be sad. You should
also avoid predicates that are merely very difficult to satisfy.

    badCrashingGenerator =
      filter (\_ -> False) anotherGenerator

    likelyCrashingGenerator =
      filter (\i -> i % 2000 == 0) (int minInt maxInt)

values.name: float
values.comment:
Generate floats in a given range. The following example is a generator
that produces numbers between 0 and 1.

    probability : Generator Float
    probability =
        float 0 1

values.name: fromJson
values.comment:
A JSON decoder that can recover seeds encoded using `toJson`.

    Json.Decode.decodeValue fromJson (toJson mySeed) == Ok mySeed

If the JSON is an array of one or two integers, or just an integer, these will
be used to initialize a new seed. This can be useful when you sometimes have an
old seed and sometimes need a new one. The integers should be 32 random bits.

values.name: generate
values.comment:
Generate a random value as specified by a given `Generator`, using a `Seed`
and returning a new one.

In the following example, we are trying to generate numbers between 0 and 100
with the `int 0 100` generator. Each time we call `generate` we need to provide
a seed. This will produce a random number and a *new* seed to use if we want to
run other generators later.

    (x, seed1) = generate (int 0 100) seed0
    (y, seed2) = generate (int 0 100) seed1
    (z, seed3) = generate (int 0 100) seed2
    [x, y, z] -- [85, 0, 38]

Notice that we use different seeds on each line. This is important! If you reuse
the same seed, you get the same results.

    (x, _) = generate (int 0 100) seed0
    (y, _) = generate (int 0 100) seed0
    (z, _) = generate (int 0 100) seed0
    [x,y,z] -- [85, 85, 85]

As you can see, threading seeds through many calls to `generate` is tedious and
error-prone. That's why this library includes many functions to build more
complicated generators, allowing you to call `generate` only a small number of
times.

Our example is best written as:

    (xs, newSeed) = generate (list 3 <| int 0 100) seed0
    xs -- [85, 0, 38]

values.name: independentSeed
values.comment:
A generator that produces a seed that is independent of any other seed in
the program. These seeds will generate their own unqiue sequences of random
values. They are useful when you need an unknown amount of randomness *later*
but can request only a fixed amount of randomness *now*.

Let's say you write a component that uses some randomness to initialize itself
and then never needs randomness again. You can easily write a `Generator
Component` by mapping over the generators it needs. But if component requires
randomness after initialization, it should keep its own independent seed, which
it can get by mapping over *this* generator.

    type alias Component = { seed : Seed }

    genComponent : Generator Component
    genComponent = map Component independentSeed

If you have a lot of components, you can initialize them like so:

    genComponents : List (Seed -> a) -> Generator (List a)
    genComponents constructors =
      list (List.length constructors) independentSeed
          |> map (List.map2 (<|) constructors)

The independent seeds are extremely likely to be distinct for all practical
purposes. However, it is not proven that there are no pathological cases.

values.name: initialSeed
values.comment:
Like `initialSeed2`, but takes only one integer. Mostly for compatibility
with core.

values.name: initialSeed2
values.comment:
Take two integers to fully initialize the 64-bit state of the random
number generator. Only the least significant 32 bits of each integer matter, and
those bits should be as random as possible.

You can generate and copy random integers to create a reproducible psuedo-random
generator.

    $ node
    > Math.floor(Math.random()*0xFFFFFFFF)
    227852860
    > Math.floor(Math.random()*0xFFFFFFFF)
    1498709020

    -- Elm
    seed0 : Seed
    seed0 = initialSeed2 227852860 1498709020

Alternatively, you can generate the random integers on page load and pass them
through a port. The program will be different every time.

    -- Elm
    port randomSeed : (Int, Int)

    seed0 : Seed
    seed0 = (uncurry initialSeed2) randomSeed

    -- JS
    Elm.fullscreen(Elm.ModuleName,
      {randomSeed: [Math.floor(Math.random()*0xFFFFFFFF),
                    Math.floor(Math.random()*0xFFFFFFFF)] })

Either way, you should initialize a random seed only once. After that, whenever
you use a seed, you'll get another one back.

values.name: int
values.comment:
Generate 32-bit integers in a given range, inclusive.

    int 0 10   -- an integer between zero and ten
    int -5 5   -- an integer between -5 and 5

    int minInt maxInt  -- an integer in the widest range feasible

This function *can* produce values outside of the range [[`minInt`](#minInt),
[`maxInt`](#maxInt)] but sufficient randomness is not guaranteed.

*Performance note:* This function will be ~1.5x faster if the range (i.e. `max - min + 1`) is a power of two. The
effect will only be noticable if you are generating tens of thousands of random integers.

values.name: list
values.comment:
Create a list of random values of a given length.

    floatList : Generator (List Float)
    floatList =
        list 10 (float 0 1)

    intList : Generator (List Int)
    intList =
        list 5 (int 0 100)

    intPairs : Generator (List (Int, Int))
    intPairs =
        list 10 <| pair (int 0 100) (int 0 100)

values.name: map
values.comment:
Transform the values produced by a generator using a stateless function as a
callback.

These examples show how to generate letters based on a basic integer generator.

    lowercaseLetter : Generator Char
    lowercaseLetter =
      map (\n -> Char.fromCode (n + 97)) (int 0 25)

    uppercaseLetter : Generator Char
    uppercaseLetter =
      map (\n -> Char.fromCode (n + 65)) (int 0 25)

values.name: map2
values.comment:
Combine two generators. This is useful when you have a function with two
arguments that both need to be given random inputs.

    pointInCircle : Float -> Generator (Float, Float)
    pointInCircle radius =
      let
        r = float 0 radius
        theta = map degrees (float 0 360)
      in
        map2 (curry fromPolar) r theta
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> Random.PCG.Generator a -> Random.PCG.Generator b -> Random.PCG.Generator c

values.name: map3
values.comment:
Combine three generators. This could be used to produce random colors.

    rgb : Generator Color.Color
    rgb =
      map3 Color.rgb (int 0 255) (int 0 255) (int 0 255)

    hsl : Generator Color.Color
    hsl =
      map3 Color.hsl (map degrees (float 0 360)) (float 0 1) (float 0 1)
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d) -> Random.PCG.Generator a -> Random.PCG.Generator b -> Random.PCG.Generator c -> Random.PCG.Generator d

values.name: map4
values.comment:
Combine four generators. This could be used to produce random transparent
colors.

    rgba : Generator Color.Color
    rgba =
      map4 Color.rgba (int 0 255) (int 0 255) (int 0 255) (float 0 1)
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e) -> Random.PCG.Generator a -> Random.PCG.Generator b -> Random.PCG.Generator c -> Random.PCG.Generator d -> Random.PCG.Generator e

values.name: map5
values.comment: Combine five generators.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f) -> Random.PCG.Generator a -> Random.PCG.Generator b -> Random.PCG.Generator c -> Random.PCG.Generator d -> Random.PCG.Generator e -> Random.PCG.Generator f

values.name: maxInt
values.comment: The maximum value for randomly generated 32-bit ints.

values.name: maybe
values.comment:
Produce `Just` a value on `True`, and `Nothing` on `False`.

You can use `bool` or `oneIn n` for the first argument.
values.type: Random.PCG.Generator Bool -> Random.PCG.Generator a -> Random.PCG.Generator (Maybe.Maybe a)

values.name: minInt
values.comment: The minimum value for randomly generated 32-bit ints.

values.name: oneIn
values.comment:
Produce `True` one-in-n times on average.

Do not pass a value less then one to this function.

    flippedHeads = oneIn 2
    rolled6 = oneIn 6

values.name: pair
values.comment:
Create a pair of random values. A common use of this might be to generate
a point in a certain 2D space. Imagine we have a collage that is 400 pixels
wide and 200 pixels tall.

    randomPoint : Generator (Int,Int)
    randomPoint =
        pair (int -200 200) (int -100 100)
values.type: Random.PCG.Generator a -> Random.PCG.Generator b -> Random.PCG.Generator ( a, b )

values.name: split
values.comment:
Split a seed into two new seeds. Each seed will generate different random
numbers.

**This function is deprecated** in favor of `independentSeed`. If you absolutely
need two seeds, use `generate independentSeed` instead.

Splitting is a reproducible operation; just like generating numbers, it
will be the same every time. Similarly, once you split a seed, you must not
reuse it.

values.name: toJson
values.comment:
Serialize a seed as a [JSON value](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/latest/Json-Encode#Value)
to be sent out a port, stored in local storage, and so on. The seed can be
recovered using `fromJson`.

Do not inspect or change the resulting JSON value.

docs.name: Random.Array
docs.comment:
# Random Sampling of Arrays

These implementations are thought to be correct as validated by non-rigorous
tests, and should be fine for games and simulations. Please do not trust them
when statisical or especially cryptographic randomness is required.

For best results, invoke `Random.initialSeed` only once in your program, and
thread the returned new seeds through. For a good random seed, evaluate
`Math.floor(Math.random()*0xFFFFFFFF)` either once and hard-code the result, or
as the value of `port initialSeed : Int`.


@docs sample, choose, shuffle

values.name: choose
values.comment:
Sample without replacement: produce a randomly selected element of the
array, the new seed, and the array with that element omitted (shifting all later
elements down).
values.type: Random.Seed -> Array.Array a -> ( Maybe.Maybe a, Random.Seed, Array.Array a )

values.name: sample
values.comment:
Sample with replacement: produce a randomly selected element of the
array and the new seed. Takes O(1) time.
values.type: Random.Seed -> Array.Array a -> ( Maybe.Maybe a, Random.Seed )

values.name: shuffle
values.comment:
Shuffle the array using the Fisher-Yates algorithm. Takes O(_n_ log _n_)
time and O(_n_) additional space.
values.type: Random.Seed -> Array.Array a -> ( Array.Array a, Random.Seed )

docs.name: SocketIO
docs.comment:
A module for working with [Socket.io](http://socket.io/) servers. This
module uses Socket.io 1.4.4.

Compared to native JavaScript socket.io, this library is limited in its ability
to dynamically change hosts, handle errors, and data must be encoded as a
string.

See the README for information on examples, including one for The Elm Architecture.

# Creating a Socket
Avoid creating signals of sockets.
@docs io, Options, defaultOptions

# Sending and Receiving
These functions should be used with `Task.andThen` to provide them with a socket
obtained with `io`.
@docs emit, on, connected

# The Socket Type
@docs Socket

aliases.name: Options
aliases.comment:
A type for options on a socket. See the [Socket.io docs](http://socket.io/docs/client-api/)
for further explanation.
aliases.type: { multiplex : Bool , reconnection : Bool , reconnectionDelay : Time.Time , reconnectionDelayMax : Time.Time , timeout : Time.Time }

types.name: Socket
types.comment:
An opaque type representing a socket. You cannot access anything directly,
only through the API provided above.

values.name: connected
values.comment:
Set up a signal of bools indicating whether or not the socket is connected.
You should initialize the mailbox to `False`; if the server is available a
`True` event will be sent almost immediately. If the server is not available,
`io` will not complete and therefore this task will not run. If the socket
disconnects (and then reconnects later), the address's mailbox's signal will
have events indicating that.

values.name: defaultOptions
values.comment:
Default options for a new socket and manager. These are the same as
Socket.io itself.

values.name: emit
values.comment:
Send a string on the socket using the given event name. To serialize your
Elm values, use `toString` or `Json.Encode`.

    port outgoing = socket `Task.andThen` emit "myEvent" "Testing 1 2 3"

values.name: io
values.comment:
Create a socket, given a hostname and options.

    socket = io "http://localhost:8001" defaultOptions

It's possible to run the Elm Reactor and your Socket.io node server
simultaneously on different ports.

The task never fails; if the server is unreachable it will never succeed.

values.name: on
values.comment:
Receive data of the given event name at a mailbox as a string. If data
received is not already a string, it will be JSON-encoded. Unserializable JS
values become `"null"`; this is a good initial value when you set up the
mailbox.

    mailbox = Signal.mailbox "null"
    port incoming = socket `Task.andThen` on "myEvent" mailbox.address
values.type: String -> Signal.Address String -> SocketIO.Socket -> Task.Task x ()

docs.name: Turtle.Advanced

aliases.name: AnimateOptions
aliases.comment:
Customize the `animateWith` function by supplying the initial random seed, the dimensions of the drawing, and the
clock on which the animation progresses.
aliases.type: { seed : Random.Seed , dims : Signal.Signal ( Int, Int ) , clock : Signal.Signal () }

aliases.name: DrawOptions
aliases.comment: Customize the `drawWith` function by supplying the initial random seed and the dimensions of the drawing.

values.name: animateWith
values.comment: Animate the steps running sequentially, using the options given. Useful if `animate` isn't quite meeting your needs.

values.name: atomically
values.comment:
The same as `make`, except when using `animate` the steps are all run together (atomically). Also considered to be a
single step by `depth` and `length`. Used by the geometry helpers in this library to draw shapes immediately rather than
watch the turtle trace them out.

values.name: back
values.comment:
Move the turtle back a distance, without affecting the rotation. The turtle will still draw the path if the pen is
down.

values.name: circle
values.comment: Create a circle of the given radius, centered at the current location.

values.name: defaultAnimateOptions
values.comment:
The options used for `animate`. Uses the same seed as the draw options, `Window.dimensions`, and a 5fps timer. You
can use a faster timer, or `Mouse.clicks`, among other things.

values.name: defaultDrawOptions
values.comment: The options used for `draw`. Uses an arbitrary seed and the arbitrary dimensions of 1000x1000.

values.name: depth
values.comment: Determine the recursive depth of a list of Steps.

values.name: drawWith
values.comment:
Draw the steps immediately, using the options given. You will usually use this with `Signal.map` to rapidly iterate
a design, change a drawing based on user input, or create a custom animation.

values.name: invisibly
values.comment: Run a step with the pen up, and then put it down to start drawing. Useful for moving the a new location.

values.name: length
values.comment: Determine the number of steps in a list of Steps, accounting for recursion.

values.name: ngon
values.comment:
Create a regular n-gon with sides of length 50. Use `scale` or `scaled` to increase the size. The turtle begins the
first edge immediately; you may want to position and rotate the turtle first.

values.name: randomly
values.comment:
Provide access to a random seed, and therefore, the Random library. This is much more powerful than `withRandom`
taking a random float, but carries with it the responsibility to pass back an unused seed. To use with a Generator, call
`Random.generate theGenerator`.

values.name: rotateTo
values.comment: Rotate to a given angle in degrees, regardless of the old rotation.

values.name: rotated
values.comment: Rotate a step left (counterclockwise) by a given angle in degrees, and then rotate back (assuming the step itself does not change the angle.)

values.name: scaled
values.comment: Scale a step by a given factor without affecting later actions (assuming the step itself does not change the scale).

values.name: star
values.comment:
Create a star polygon. The first argument specifies the number of points. The second argument specifies the ratio of
the exterior angle to the interior angle. A pentagram is `star 5 3` and a Star of David is `star 6 2`. This can take
some experimentation to get the effect you need; sometimes a star comes out as a convex polygon.

Each side has length 50. Use `scale` or `scaled` to increase the size. The turtle begins the
first edge immediately; you may want to position and rotate the turtle first.

values.name: stay
values.comment: Tell the turtle to do nothing.

values.name: teleport
values.comment: Move to a given location, regardless of the old location.

docs.name: Turtle

aliases.name: Step
aliases.comment: A Step is an action that a turtle can do.

values.name: animate
values.comment: Animate the turtle drawing, showing the each step as it moves.

values.name: draw
values.comment:
Run the turtle and immediately show the result. It is useful when you are
changing your code quickly and don't want to wait for the turtle to move.

values.name: forward
values.comment: Move the turtle forward by a certain amount. How can you make the turtle move backwards?

values.name: left
values.comment: Turn the turtle left by a certain number of degrees.

values.name: make
values.comment:
Do every step in the list. Really useful for giving names to small jobs. Think about `make star`, or making a
five-pointed star with `make (star 5)`.

values.name: penColor
values.comment: Change the color of the drawing.

values.name: penDown
values.comment: Put the pen back down so that the turtle starts drawing again.

values.name: penUp
values.comment: Lift the pen from the paper so that nothing is drawn.

values.name: right
values.comment: Turn the turtle right by a certain number of degrees.

values.name: scale
values.comment:
Make moving forward bigger or smaller. The numbers multiply, so doing `scale 3` and then `scale 5` is the same as
doing `scale 15`.

values.name: withRandom
values.comment: Give a step-making function a random number between 0 and 1.

docs.name: Random.Distributions

values.name: erf
values.comment:
The error function
Approximation with a maximal error of 1.2*10^-7.

Directly from wikipedia:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Error_function#Numerical_approximation

    \begin{align}
    \tau = {} & t\cdot\exp\left(-x^2-1.26551223+1.00002368 t+0.37409196 t^2+0.09678418 t^3\right.\\
    & \left.{}-0.18628806 t^4+0.27886807 t^5-1.13520398 t^6+1.48851587\cdot t^7\right. \\
    & \left.{}-0.82215223 t^8+0.17087277 t^9\right)
    \end{align}

values.name: erfc
values.comment:
The complimentary error function.
Approximation with a maximal error of 1.2*10^-7.

values.name: erfinv
values.comment:
The inverse of the error function.

Implementation [from wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Error_function#Approximation_with_elementary_functions)

values.name: normal
values.comment: Generate samples from a standard normal distribution.

values.name: normalCumulative
values.comment:
The cumulative distribution function of a normal distribution.

Implemented using [the error function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_distribution#Cumulative_distribution_function).

    y = normalCumulative mu sigma x

values.name: normalDensity
values.comment:
The probability density function for a normal distribution.

    y = normalDensity mu sigma x

values.name: normalDensityInverse
values.comment:
The inverse of the density function for a normal distribution.

    x = normalDensityInverse mu sigma y

values.name: normalQuantile
values.comment:
The quantile function for a normal distribution with the given mean and standard deviation

i.e. the inverse of the cumulative distribution function of the normal
distribution.

    q = normalQuantile mu sigma p

Implementation using the probit function [from Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_distribution#Quantile_function).

values.name: probit
values.comment:
The probit function.

The quantile function for the standard normal distribution (i.e. the inverse of
the cumulative distribution function of the standard normal distribution).

Implemented using the inverse error function [as described on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probit#Computation)

values.name: quantile
values.comment:
Produces sample quantiles of the xs corresponding to the given probabilities.

    quantile samples probs

Based on the [corresponding R function](https://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-devel/library/stats/html/quantile.html).

`probs` is assumed to be a sorted list of probabilities.
values.type: List Float -> List Float -> List Float

values.name: ziggurat
values.comment:
Implement the [Ziggurat algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ziggurat_algorithm) for one-sided distributions.

    oneSidedNormalGenerator =
      let
        n = numLayers
        pdfFunc = normalDensity 0 1
        invPdfFunc = normalDensityInverse 0 1
        cdfFunc = standardNormalCumulative
        x1 = zigguratX1 n pdfFunc invPdfFunc cdfFunc
        y1 = pdfFunc x1
        listTables = zigguratTables n y1 layerArea pdfFunc invPdfFunc
        tables = Array.fromList listTables
        tailGen = zigguratNormalTail x1
      in
        ziggurat tables pdfFunc tailGen
values.type: Array.Array ( Float, Float ) -> (Float -> Float) -> Random.Generator Float -> Random.Generator Float

values.name: zigguratTables
values.comment:
Generate the ziggurat tables.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ziggurat_algorithm#Generating_the_tables

    tables = zigguratTables numLayers y1 layerArea pFunc invPFunc
    (xs, ys) = List.unzip tables
values.type: Int -> Float -> Float -> (Float -> Float) -> (Float -> Float) -> List ( Float, Float )

values.name: zigguratX1
values.comment:
Find x1 and A for a given table size, density function, and inverse density
function.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ziggurat_algorithm#Finding_x1_and_A

    x1 = zigguratX1 n pdfFunc invPdfFunc cdfFunc

docs.name: MicroKanren.Operators
docs.comment:
Infix operators for Kanren

@docs (++), (>>=), (===), ()

values.comment: Infix alias of `mplus`.
values.type: MicroKanren.Stream a -> MicroKanren.Stream a -> MicroKanren.Stream a

values.comment: Infix alias of `identical`.
values.type: MicroKanren.Term a -> MicroKanren.Term a -> MicroKanren.Goal a

values.comment: Infix alias of `bind`.
values.type: MicroKanren.Stream a -> MicroKanren.Goal a -> MicroKanren.Stream a

values.comment: Unicode alias of `identical`.
values.type: MicroKanren.Term a -> MicroKanren.Term a -> MicroKanren.Goal a

docs.name: MicroKanren

aliases.name: Goal
aliases.comment:
A goal to be pursued within the received state.
A successful goal returns a non-empty stream, containing the states which satisfied it.

aliases.name: State
aliases.comment:
A state encapsulates the substitution `s`, which encompasses current variable-term bindings,
and the counter `c`, which represents the index of the next unbound (fresh) logic variable.

aliases.name: Substitution
aliases.comment: A dictionary of variable-term bindings.

aliases.name: Var
aliases.comment:
The `Var` type is an index (or counter),
used to track the results of logic operations.

types.name: Stream
Term
types.comment:
The terms on which a Kanren program operates.

Three variants are established:
  - `LVar`, the identifier of a logic variable; effectively a term-level `Var`
    acting as a reference.
  - `LVal`, which wraps some value of type `a` for use by logic operations.
  - `Pair`, two terms of the same type `a`.

values.name: bind
values.comment:
Invoke a goal on each element of the given stream,
and interleave the resulting streams.
values.type: MicroKanren.Stream a -> MicroKanren.Goal a -> MicroKanren.Stream a

values.name: callFresh
values.comment: Create a goal which introduces a new logic variable for use by another goal.

values.name: conjoin
values.comment:
Create a goal which succeeds if the second goal is achievable within the stream
generated by the first goal.

Effectively a binary conjunction of goals.
values.type: MicroKanren.Goal a -> MicroKanren.Goal a -> MicroKanren.Goal a

values.name: disjoin
values.comment:
Create a goal which succeeds if either of the received goals are achieved.

Effectively a binary disjunction of goals.
values.type: MicroKanren.Goal a -> MicroKanren.Goal a -> MicroKanren.Goal a

values.name: extend
values.comment: Extend the substitution with a new variable-term binding.
values.type: MicroKanren.Var -> MicroKanren.Term a -> MicroKanren.Substitution a -> MicroKanren.Substitution a

values.name: identical
values.comment: Create a goal which succeeds if the two terms unify in the received state.
values.type: MicroKanren.Term a -> MicroKanren.Term a -> MicroKanren.Goal a

values.name: mplus
values.comment:
Merge two streams by interleaving their states, so that infinite streams
will not prevent finite streams from yielding their state.
values.type: MicroKanren.Stream a -> MicroKanren.Stream a -> MicroKanren.Stream a

values.name: mzero
values.comment: An alias for the empty stream.

values.name: unify
values.comment:
Unify two terms in the received substitution `s`,
potentially extending it.

- `LVar` variables unify when they refer to the same index,
  i.e. they are the same variable. `s` is returned unchanged..
- `LVal` values unify when they are equivalent under Elm's native `(==)`.
  `s` is returned unchanged.
- Pairs unify when their terms unify pairwise.
- Finally, an `LVar` variable and an `LVal` value unify under an extended substitution `s'`,
  where they form a new binding.

If unification fails, `Nothing` is returned.
values.type: MicroKanren.Term a -> MicroKanren.Term a -> MicroKanren.Substitution a -> Maybe.Maybe (MicroKanren.Substitution a)

values.name: unit
values.comment:
The trivial goal, which lifts the state into a mature stream
whose only element is that state.

values.name: walk
values.comment:
Given a `LVar`, traverse the substitution and return its value.
If the given term cannot be found, or is not a variable, the term itself is returned.
values.type: MicroKanren.Term a -> MicroKanren.Substitution a -> MicroKanren.Term a

docs.name: CoMidi
