docs.name: GenericSet

types.name: GenericSet
types.comment:
Represents a set of unique values. So `(GenericSet Int)` is a set of integers and
`(GenericSet String)` is a set of strings.

values.name: diff
values.comment:
Get the difference between the first set and the second. Keeps values
that do not appear in the second set. Keeps the comparer from the first set.
values.type: GenericSet.GenericSet a -> GenericSet.GenericSet a -> GenericSet.GenericSet a

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty set using the given comparer.

values.name: filter
values.comment: Create a new set consisting only of elements which satisfy a predicate.

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Fold over the values in a set, in order from lowest to highest (by the
comparer).
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> GenericSet.GenericSet a -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment:
Fold over the values in a set, in order from highest to lowest (by the
comparer).
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> GenericSet.GenericSet a -> b

values.name: fromList
values.comment:
Convert a list into a set, removing any duplicates, using the given
comparer.
values.type: (a -> a -> Basics.Order) -> List a -> GenericSet.GenericSet a

values.name: insert
values.comment: Insert a value into a set.

values.name: intersect
values.comment:
Get the intersection of two sets. Keeps values that appear in both sets.
Keeps the comparer from the first set.
values.type: GenericSet.GenericSet a -> GenericSet.GenericSet a -> GenericSet.GenericSet a

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment: Determine if a set is empty.

values.name: map
values.comment:
Map a function onto a set, creating a new set with no duplicates and a new
comparer.
values.type: (b -> b -> Basics.Order) -> (a -> b) -> GenericSet.GenericSet a -> GenericSet.GenericSet b

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if a value is in a set.

values.name: partition
values.comment:
Create two new sets; the first consisting of elements which satisfy a
predicate, the second consisting of elements which do not.
values.type: (a -> Bool) -> GenericSet.GenericSet a -> ( GenericSet.GenericSet a, GenericSet.GenericSet a )

values.name: remove
values.comment: Remove a value from a set. If the value is not found, no changes are made.

values.name: singleton
values.comment: Create a set with one value using the given comparer.

values.name: size
values.comment: Determine the number of elements in a set.

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert a set into a list, sorted by the comparer.

values.name: union
values.comment:
Get the union of two sets. Keep all values. Keep the comparer from the
first set.
values.type: GenericSet.GenericSet a -> GenericSet.GenericSet a -> GenericSet.GenericSet a

docs.name: GenericDict

types.name: GenericDict
types.comment:
A dictionary of keys and values. So a `(GenericDict String User)` is a dictionary
that lets you look up a `String` (such as user names) and find the associated
`User`.

values.name: diff
values.comment:
Keep a key-value pair when its key does not appear in the second
dictionary. Keep the comparer from the first dictionary.
values.type: GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty dictionary using the given comparer.

values.name: filter
values.comment: Keep a key-value pair when it satisfies a predicate.
values.type: (k -> v -> Bool) -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Fold over the key-value pairs in a dictionary, in order from lowest
key to highest key (by the comparer).
values.type: (k -> v -> b -> b) -> b -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment:
Fold over the key-value pairs in a dictionary, in order from highest
key to lowest key (by the comparer).
values.type: (k -> v -> b -> b) -> b -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> b

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert an association list into a dictionary using the given comparer.
values.type: (k -> k -> Basics.Order) -> List ( k, v ) -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v

values.name: get
values.comment:
Get the value associated with a key. If the key is not found, return
`Nothing`. This is useful when you are not sure if a key will be in the
dictionary.

    animals = fromList compare [ ("Tom", Cat), ("Jerry", Mouse) ]

    get "Tom"   animals == Just Cat
    get "Jerry" animals == Just Mouse
    get "Spike" animals == Nothing
values.type: k -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> Maybe.Maybe v

values.name: insert
values.comment:
Insert a key-value pair into a dictionary. Replaces value when there is
a collision.
values.type: k -> v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v

values.name: intersect
values.comment:
Keep a key-value pair when its key appears in the second dictionary.
Preference is given to values in the first dictionary. Keep the comparer from
the first dictionary.
values.type: GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment:
Determine if a dictionary is empty.

    isEmpty (empty compare) == True

values.name: keys
values.comment:
Get all of the keys in a dictionary, sorted from lowest to highest.

    keys (fromList [(0,"Alice"),(1,"Bob")]) == [0,1]

values.name: map
values.comment: Apply a function to all values in a dictionary.
values.type: (k -> a -> b) -> GenericDict.GenericDict k a -> GenericDict.GenericDict k b

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if a key is in a dictionary.

values.name: partition
values.comment:
Partition a dictionary according to a predicate. The first dictionary
contains all key-value pairs which satisfy the predicate, and the second
contains the rest.
values.type: (k -> v -> Bool) -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> ( GenericDict.GenericDict k v, GenericDict.GenericDict k v )

values.name: remove
values.comment:
Remove a key-value pair from a dictionary. If the key is not found,
no changes are made.
values.type: k -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v

values.name: singleton
values.comment: Create a dictionary with one key-value pair, using the given comparer.
values.type: (k -> k -> Basics.Order) -> k -> v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v

values.name: size
values.comment: Determine the number of key-value pairs in the dictionary.

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert a dictionary into an association list of key-value pairs, sorted by keys.
values.type: GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> List ( k, v )

values.name: union
values.comment:
Combine two dictionaries. If there is a collision, preference is given
to the first dictionary. Keep the comparer from the first dictionary.
values.type: GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v

values.name: update
values.comment: Update the value of a dictionary for a specific key with a given function.
values.type: k -> (Maybe.Maybe v -> Maybe.Maybe v) -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v -> GenericDict.GenericDict k v

values.name: values
values.comment:
Get all of the values in a dictionary, in the order of their keys.

    values (fromList [(0,"Alice"),(1,"Bob")]) == ["Alice", "Bob"]

    verticalAlign bottom

message if it could not be compiled.

values.name: mixin
values.comment:
A Mixin allowing you to modularly reuse common styles in other styles.
The return value of `mixin` can be used like any other property, since all
properties in elm-css are implemented as mixins.

    underlineOnHover =
        mixin "underlineOnHover"
            [ textDecoration none

            , hover
                [ textDecoration underline ]
            ]

    stylesheet
      [ (.) FancyLink
          [ color (rgb 128 64 32)
          , underlineOnHover
          ]
      ]

...has the same result as:

    stylesheet
      [ (.) FancyLink
          [ color (rgb 128 64 32)
          , textDecoration none
          , hover
            [ textDecoration underline ]
          ]
      ]

values.name: thick
values.comment:
The
[border width values](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/border-width)
of `thin`, `medium`, and `thick` have unspecified behavior according to the
CSS specification, and as such are intentionally unsupported.

Using them is a bad idea, but if the fate of the world depends on it, you can
fall back on something like this:

    stylesheet
        [ button
            [ property "border-left" "thick" ]
        ]

values.name: thin
values.comment:
The
[border width values](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/border-width)
of `thin`, `medium`, and `thick` have unspecified behavior according to the
CSS specification, and as such are intentionally unsupported.

Using them is a bad idea, but if the fate of the world depends on it, you can
fall back on something like this:

    stylesheet
        [ button
            [ property "border-left" "thin" ]
        ]

    top (px 5)

This can also be used as a `top` [vertical-align](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/vertical-align) value:

    verticalAlign top

values.name: transform
values.comment:
Sets [`transform`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform)
with a single explicit transform value. If you need to set the transform
property to `none`, use the `transforms` function with an empty list. See
`transforms` for more details.

    transform (scaleX 1.4)

values.name: transformBox
values.comment: The [`transform-box`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform-box) property.

values.name: transformStyle
values.comment: The [`transform-style`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform-style) property.

values.name: transforms
values.comment:
Sets [`transform`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform)
with a series of transform-functions. If an empty list is provided, the CSS
output will be `none`, as if to state directly that the set of transforms
applied to the current selector is empty:

    transforms [] -- transform: none;

In the case that only one transform is needed, the `transform` function may be
used instead for convenience. `transform` expects exactly one transform-function
and cannot be passed `none`:

    transform (matrix 1 2 3 4 5 6) -- transform: matrix(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6);

If a collection of transforms is needed, use the `transforms` function with a
populated list:

    transforms [ perspective 1, scale2 1 1.4 ]

values.name: style
values.comment: Create an inline style from CSS

values.name: stylesheetLink
values.comment: Link in a stylesheet from a url

values.name: withNamespace
values.comment:
Takes a namespace and returns helper functions for `id`, `class`, and `classList` which work just like their equivalents in `elm-html` except that they accept union types and automatically incorporate the given namespace. Also note that `class` accepts a `List` instead of a single element; this is so you can specify multiple classes without having to call `classList` passing tuples that all end in `True`. -- Put this before your view code to specify a namespace. { id, class, classList } = withNamespace "homepage" view = h1 [ id Hero, class [ Fancy ] ] [ text "Hello, World!" ] type HomepageIds = Hero | SomethingElse | AnotherId type HomepageClasses = Fancy | AnotherClass | SomeOtherClass The above would generate this DOM element:

Hello, World!

docs.name: Css.Helpers
docs.comment:
Utility functions for elm-css.

@docs toCssIdentifier, identifierToString

values.name: identifierToString
values.comment:
Converts an arbitrary identifier to a valid CSS identifier, then prepends
the given namespace.

values.name: toCssIdentifier
values.comment:
Converts an arbitrary value to a valid CSS identifier by calling
`toString` on it, trimming it, replacing chunks of whitespace with `-`,
and stripping out invalid characters.

docs.name: Validate

aliases.name: Validator
aliases.comment:
A `Validator` is a function which takes a subject and returns a list of errors
describing anything invalid about that subject.

An empty error list means the subject was valid.

values.name: all
values.comment:
Run each of the given validators, in order, and return their concatenated
error lists.
values.type: List (Validate.Validator error subject) -> Validate.Validator error subject

values.name: any
values.comment:
Return `True` if none of the given validators returns any errors for the given
subject, and `False` if any validator returns one or more errors.

values.name: eager
values.comment:
Run each of the given validators, in order, stopping after the first error
and returning it. If no errors are encountered, return `Nothing`.
values.type: List (Validate.Validator error subject) -> subject -> Maybe.Maybe error

values.name: ifBlank
values.comment:
Return an error if the given `String` is empty, or if it contains only
whitespace characters.

values.name: ifEmptyDict
values.comment: Return an error if the given `Dict` is empty.

values.name: ifEmptySet
values.comment: Return an error if the given `Set` is empty.

values.name: ifInvalid
values.comment:
Return an error if the given predicate returns `True` for the given
subject.

values.name: ifInvalidEmail
values.comment: Return an error if the given email string is malformed.

values.name: ifNotInt
values.comment: Return an error if the given `String` cannot be parsed as an `Int`.

values.name: ifNothing
values.comment: Return an error if given a `Maybe` that is `Nothing`.

docs.name: Graph

aliases.name: Adjacency
aliases.comment:
Adjacency is represented as an ordered dictionary
rather than as an ordered list. This enables more dynamic
graphs with efficient edge removal and insertion on the run.

aliases.name: BfsNodeVisitor
aliases.comment:
A specialized node visitor for breadth-first traversal. Compared to a
`SimpleNodeVisitor`, the path of contexts from the root to the current
node is passed instead of just the current node's context. Additionally, the
distance from the root is passed as an `Int` (the root has distance 0 and it
holds always that `length path == distance - 1`).

If you don't need the additional information, you can turn a `SimpleNodeVisitor`
into a `BfsNodeVisitor` by calling `ignorePath`.
aliases.type: List (Graph.NodeContext n e) -> Int -> acc -> acc

aliases.name: DfsNodeVisitor
aliases.comment:
A node visitor specialized for depth-first traversal. Along with the node
context of the currently visited node, the current accumulated value is passed.
The visitor then has the chance to both modify the value at discovery of the
node through the first return value and also provide a finishing
transformation which is called with the value after all children were processed
and the node is about to be finished.

In the cases where you don't need access to the value both at dicovery and at
finish, look into `onDiscovery` and `onFinish`.
aliases.type: Graph.NodeContext n e -> acc -> ( acc, acc -> acc )

aliases.name: Edge
aliases.comment:
Represents a directd edge in the graph. In addition
to start and end node identifiers, a label value can
be attached to an edge.
aliases.type: { from : Graph.NodeId, to : Graph.NodeId, label : e }

aliases.name: NeighborSelector
aliases.comment: Selects the next neighbors for the currently visited node in the traversal.

aliases.name: Node
aliases.comment:
The type representing a node: An identifier with
a label.

aliases.name: NodeContext
aliases.comment:
Represents a node with its incoming and outgoing edges
(predecessors and successors).
aliases.type: { node : Graph.Node n , incoming : Graph.Adjacency e , outgoing : Graph.Adjacency e }

aliases.name: NodeId
aliases.comment: The type used for identifying nodes, an integer.

aliases.name: SimpleNodeVisitor
aliases.comment:
A generic node visitor just like that in the ordinary `fold` function.
There are combinators that make these usable for both depth-first traversal
(`onDiscovery`, `onFinish`) and breadth-first traversal (`ignorePath`).

types.name: Graph
types.comment:
The central graph type. It is parameterized both over the node label type `n`
and the edge label type `e`.

One can build such a graph with the primitives under *Build*. Most of the time
`fromNodesAndEdges` works fairly well.

For simplicity, this library just uses a patricia trie based graph representation, which means
it is just an efficient version of `Dict NodeId (NodeContext n e)`. This allows efficient insertion and
removal of nodes of the graph after building.

values.name: alongIncomingEdges
values.comment:
A less common way for selecting neighbors is to follow incoming edges:

    alongIncomingEdges ctx =
      IntDict.keys (ctx.incoming)

values.name: alongOutgoingEdges
values.comment:
A good default for selecting neighbors is to just go along outgoing edges:

    alongOutgoingEdges ctx =
      IntDict.keys (ctx.outgoing)

`dfs`/`bfs` use this as their selecting strategy.

values.name: anyNode
values.comment:
Focuses on an arbitrary `NodeContext` of a `Graph`.
This exists for the same purposes as `nodeById`, but this focuses on an
arbitrary node rather than on a node with a specific id.

values.name: bfs
values.comment:
An off-the-shelf breadth-first traversal. It will visit all components of the
graph in no guaranteed order, discovering nodes `alongOutgoingEdges`.
See the docs of `BfsNodeVisitor` on how to supply such a beast. There are also
examples on how to use `bfs`.
values.type: Graph.BfsNodeVisitor n e acc -> acc -> Graph.Graph n e -> acc

values.name: dfs
values.comment:
An off-the-shelf depth-first traversal. It will visit all components of the
graph in no guaranteed order, discovering nodes `alongOutgoingEdges`.
See the docs of `DfsNodeVisitor` on how to supply such a beast. There are also
examples on how to use `dfs`.
values.type: Graph.DfsNodeVisitor n e acc -> acc -> Graph.Graph n e -> acc

values.name: dfsForest
values.comment:
`dfsForest seeds graph` computes a depth-first spanning `Forest` of the
components in `graph` spanned by `seeds` `alongOutgoingEdges`.

A traversal over this forest would be equivalent to a depth-first traversal
over the original graph.
values.type: List Graph.NodeId -> Graph.Graph n e -> Graph.Tree.Forest (Graph.NodeContext n e)

values.name: dfsTree
values.comment:
`dfsTree seed graph` computes a depth-first [spanning tree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanning_tree) of the component
in `graph` starting from `seed` `alongOutgoingEdges`. This function is exemplary for needing to
utilize the whole power of `DfsNodeVisitor`.
values.type: Graph.NodeId -> Graph.Graph n e -> Graph.Tree.Tree (Graph.NodeContext n e)

values.name: edges
values.comment:
`edges graph` returns a list of all `Edge`s (e.g. a record of `from` and `to` ids
and a `label`) in `graph`.

    edges empty == []
    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] [Edge 1 2 "->"]
    edges graph == [Edge 1 2 "->"]

values.name: empty
values.comment:
An empty graph.

    size empty == 0

values.name: fold
values.comment:
A fold over all node contexts. The accumulated value is computed lazily,
so that the fold can exit early when the suspended accumulator is not forced.

    hasLoop ctx = IntDict.member ctx.node.id ctx.incoming
    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] [Edge 1 2 "->"]
    -- The graph should not have any loop.
    fold (\ctx acc -> acc ||hasLoop ctx) False graph == False
values.type: (Graph.NodeContext n e -> acc -> acc) -> acc -> Graph.Graph n e -> acc

values.name: from
values.comment: Focus for the `from` field of `Edge`.

values.name: fromNodeLabelsAndEdgePairs
values.comment:
A more convenient version of `fromNodesAndEdges`, when edges are unlabeled
and there are no special requirements on node ids.

`fromNodeLabelsAndEdgePairs labels edges` implicitly assigns node ids according
to the label's index in `labels` and the list of edge pairs is converted to
unlabeled `Edge`s.

    graph = fromNodeLabelsAndEdgePairs ['a', 'b'] [(0, 1)]
values.type: List n -> List ( Graph.NodeId, Graph.NodeId ) -> Graph.Graph n ()

values.name: fromNodesAndEdges
values.comment:
`fromNodesAndEdges nodes edges` constructs a graph from the supplied `nodes`
and `edges`. This is the most comfortable way to construct a graph as a whole.
Oftentimes it is even more convenient to use `fromNodeLabelsAndEdgePairs` when
edges are unlabeled anyway and auto incremented node ids are OK.

The following constructs a graph with 2 nodes with a string label, connected
by an edge labeled "->".

    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] [Edge 1 2 "->"]
values.type: List (Graph.Node n) -> List (Graph.Edge e) -> Graph.Graph n e

values.name: get
values.comment:
Analogous to `Dict.get`, `get nodeId graph` returns the `Just` the node
context with id `nodeId` in `graph` if there is one and `Nothing` otherwise.

    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] []
    get 42 graph == Nothing
    get 1 graph == Just <node context of node 1>
values.type: Graph.NodeId -> Graph.Graph n e -> Maybe.Maybe (Graph.NodeContext n e)

values.name: guidedBfs
values.comment:
The `bfs` function is not powerful enough? Go for this beast.

`guidedBfs selectNeighbors visitNode seeds acc graph` will perform a breadth-first
traversal on `graph` starting with a queue of `seeds`. The children of each node
will be selected with `selectNeighbors` (see `NeighborSelector`), the visiting
of nodes is handled by `visitNode` (c.f. `BfsNodeVisitor`), folding `acc` over
the graph.

When there are not any more nodes to be visited, the function will return the
accumulated value together with the unvisited rest of `graph`.

    bfsLevelOrder graph =
      -- NodeId 1 is just a wild guess here
      guidedBfs alongOutgoingEdges (ignorePath (::)) [1] [] graph
values.type: Graph.NeighborSelector n e -> Graph.BfsNodeVisitor n e acc -> List Graph.NodeId -> acc -> Graph.Graph n e -> ( acc, Graph.Graph n e )

values.name: guidedDfs
values.comment:
The `dfs*` functions are not powerful enough? Go for this beast.

`guidedDfs selectNeighbors visitNode seeds acc graph` will perform a depth-first
traversal on `graph` starting with a stack of `seeds`. The children of each node
will be selected with `selectNeighbors` (see `NeighborSelector`), the visiting
of nodes is handled by `visitNode` (c.f. `DfsNodeVisitor`), folding `acc` over
the graph.

When there are not any more nodes to be visited, the function will return the
accumulated value together with the unvisited rest of `graph`.

    dfsPreOrder graph =
      -- NodeId 1 is just a wild guess here
      guidedDfs alongOutgoingEdges (onDiscovery (::)) [1] [] graph
values.type: Graph.NeighborSelector n e -> Graph.DfsNodeVisitor n e acc -> List Graph.NodeId -> acc -> Graph.Graph n e -> ( acc, Graph.Graph n e )

values.name: heightLevels
values.comment:
Computes the height function of a given graph. This is a more general
[topological sort](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_sorting),
where independent nodes are in the same height level (e.g. the same list
index). A valid topological sort is trivially obtained by flattening the
result of this function.

The height function is useful for solving the maximal clique problem for
certain [perfect graphs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perfect_graph)
([comparability graphs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparability_graph)).
There is the excellent reference
[Algorithmic Graph Theory and Perfect Graphs](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=984029).
values.type: Graph.Graph n e -> List (List (Graph.NodeContext n e))

values.name: id
values.comment: Focus for the `id` field of `Node`.

values.name: ignorePath
values.comment:
Turns a `SimpleNodeVisitor` into a `BfsNodeVisitor` by ignoring the path
and distance parameters.
This is useful for when the visitor should be agnostic of the
traversal (breadth-first or depth-first or even just `fold`).

    bfsLevelOrder : List (NodeContext n e)
    bfsLevelOrder graph =
      graph
        |> bfs (ignorePath (::)) []
        |> List.reverse
values.type: Graph.SimpleNodeVisitor n e acc -> Graph.BfsNodeVisitor n e acc

values.name: incoming
values.comment: Focus for the `incoming` field of `NodeContext`.

values.name: inducedSubgraph
values.comment:
The [induced subgraph](http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Edge-InducedSubgraph.html)
of a number of node ids.
values.type: List Graph.NodeId -> Graph.Graph n e -> Graph.Graph n e

values.name: insert
values.comment:
Analogous to `Dict.insert`, `insert nodeContext graph` inserts a fresh node
with its context (label, id and edges) into `graph`. If there was already a node
with the same id, it will be replaced by the new node context.

    graph1 = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1"] []
    newNode =
      { node = Node 2 "2"
      , incoming = IntDict.singleton 1 () -- so there will be an edge from 1 to 2
      , outgoing = IntDict.empty
      }
    graph2 = insert newNode graph1
    size graph2 == 2

It's possible to build up whole graphs this way, but a lot less tedious way would
be simply to use `fromNodesAndEdges`.
values.type: Graph.NodeContext n e -> Graph.Graph n e -> Graph.Graph n e

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment:
`isEmpty graph` is true if and only if there are no nodes in the graph.
Some properties to reason about in code, which hold for any `graph`:

    isEmpty graph =
      graph == empty
    isEmpty graph =
      size graph == 0

values.name: label
values.comment: Focus for the `label` field of `Node` and `Edge`.

values.name: mapContexts
values.comment:
Maps each node context to another one. This may change edge and node labels
(including their types), possibly the node ids and also add or remove edges
entirely through modifying the adjacency lists.

The following is a specification for reverseEdges:

    flipEdges ctx = { ctx | incoming = ctx.outgoing, outgoing = ctx.incoming }
    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] [Edge 1 2 "->"]
    reverseEdges graph == mapContexts flipEdges graph
values.type: (Graph.NodeContext n1 e1 -> Graph.NodeContext n2 e2) -> Graph.Graph n1 e1 -> Graph.Graph n2 e2

values.name: mapEdges
values.comment:
Maps over edge labels, possibly chaing their types. Leaves the graph
topology intact.
values.type: (e1 -> e2) -> Graph.Graph n e1 -> Graph.Graph n e2

values.name: mapNodes
values.comment:
Maps over node labels, possibly changing their types. Leaves the graph
topology intact.
values.type: (n1 -> n2) -> Graph.Graph n1 e -> Graph.Graph n2 e

values.name: member
values.comment:
Analogous to `Dict.member`, `member nodeId graph` is true, if and only if
there is a node with id `nodeId` in `graph`.

    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] []
    member 42 graph == False
    member 1 graph == True

values.name: node
values.comment: Focus for the `node` field of `NodeContext`.

values.name: nodeById
values.comment:
`nodeById nodeId` focuses on the node with id `nodeId` with a `Graph`.
Since the node might or might not exist, the small part on which we focus wraps
the `NodeContext` in a `Maybe`.

This is a combination of the `get` and `update` functions which is handy for
composition of foci deep into a graph. Unfortunately, we need a combinator which
would get rid of the `Maybe` wrapping (that would be the task of a prism I think),
but suppose we have something like `Focus.withDefault : a -> Focus (Maybe a) a`,
then we could define

    ctx = NodeContext (Node 2 "2") IntDict.empty IntDict.empty
    focus = nodeById 2 => Focus.withDefault ctx => node => label
    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] [Edge 1 2 "->"]
    graph1 = Focus.set focus graph "="
    Focus.get focus graph1 == "="

Well, I hope I could bring over the point.
values.type: Graph.NodeId -> Focus.Focus (Graph.Graph n e) (Maybe.Maybe (Graph.NodeContext n e))

values.name: nodeIdRange
values.comment:
`nodeIdRange graph` returns `Just (minNodeId, maxNodeId)` if `graph` is not empty and `Nothing`
otherwise.

This is useful for finding unoccupied node ids without trial and error.

    nodeIdRange empty == Nothing
    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] []
    nodeIdRange graph == Just (1, 2)
values.type: Graph.Graph n e -> Maybe.Maybe ( Graph.NodeId, Graph.NodeId )

values.name: nodeIds
values.comment:
`nodeIds graph` returns a list of all nodes' ids in `graph`.

    nodeIds empty == []
    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] []
    nodeIds graph == [1, 2]

values.name: nodes
values.comment:
`nodes graph` returns a list of all `Node`s (e.g. `id` and `label`) in
`graph`.

    nodes empty == []
    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] []
    nodes graph == [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"]

values.name: onDiscovery
values.comment:
Transform a `SimpleNodeVisitor` into an equivalent `DfsNodeVisitor`, which
will be called upon node discovery. This eases providing `DfsNodeVisitor`s in
the default case:

    dfsPostOrder : Graph n e  -> List (NodeContext n e)
    dfsPostOrder graph =
      dfs (onDiscovery (::)) [] graph
values.type: Graph.SimpleNodeVisitor n e acc -> Graph.DfsNodeVisitor n e acc

values.name: onFinish
values.comment:
Transform a `SimpleNodeVisitor` into an equivalent `DfsNodeVisitor`, which
will be called upon node finish. This eases providing `DfsNodeVisitor`s in
the default case:

    dfsPreOrder : Graph n e  -> List (NodeContext n e)
    dfsPreOrder graph =
      dfs (onFinish (::)) [] graph
values.type: Graph.SimpleNodeVisitor n e acc -> Graph.DfsNodeVisitor n e acc

values.name: outgoing
values.comment: Focus for the `outgoing` field of `NodeContext`.

values.name: remove
values.comment:
Analogous to `Dict.remove`, `remove nodeId graph` returns a version of `graph`
without a node with id `nodeId`. If there was no node with that id, then remove
is a no-op:

    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] [Edge 1 2 ()]
    graph == remove 42 graph
    graph |> remove 2 |> size == 1
values.type: Graph.NodeId -> Graph.Graph n e -> Graph.Graph n e

values.name: reverseEdges
values.comment: Reverses the direction of every edge in the graph.
values.type: Graph.Graph n e -> Graph.Graph n e

values.name: size
values.comment:
`size graph` returns the number of nodes in `graph`.

    size empty == 0
    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] []
    size graph == 2

values.name: stronglyConnectedComponents
values.comment:
Decomposes a graph into its strongly connected components. The resulting
list is a topological ordering of the component graph.
values.type: Graph.Graph n e -> List (Graph.Graph n e)

values.name: symmetricClosure
values.comment:
`symmetricClosure edgeMerger graph` is the
[symmetric closure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_closure) of `graph`,
e.g. the undirected equivalent, where for every edge in `graph` there is also
a corresponding reverse edge. This implies that `ctx.incoming` == `ctx.outgoing`
for each node context `ctx`.

`edgeMerger` resolves conflicts for when there are already edges in both
directions, e.g. the graph isn't truly directed. It is guaranteed that
`edgeMerger` will only be called with the smaller node id passed in first
to enforce consitency of merging decisions.

    graph = fromNodesAndEdges [Node 1 "1", Node 2 "2"] [Edge 1 2 "->"]
    onlyUndirectedEdges ctx =
      ctx.incoming == ctx.outgoing
    merger from to outgoingLabel incomingLabel =
      outgoingLabel -- quite arbitrary, will not be called for the above graph
    fold
      (\ctx acc -> acc && onlyUndirectedEdges ctx)
      True
      (symmetricClosure merger graph)
      == True
values.type: (Graph.NodeId -> Graph.NodeId -> e -> e -> e) -> Graph.Graph n e -> Graph.Graph n e

values.name: to
values.comment: Focus for the `to` field of `Edge`.

values.name: toString'
values.comment:
Returns a string representation of the graph in the format of
`Graph.fromNodesAndEdges [<nodes>] [<edges>]`.

values.name: topologicalSort
values.comment:
Computes a
[topological ordering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_sorting) of the
given graph.
values.type: Graph.Graph n e -> List (Graph.NodeContext n e)

values.name: update
values.comment:
Analogous to `Dict.update`, `update nodeId updater graph` will find
the node context of the node with id `nodeId` in `graph`. It will then call `updater`
with `Just` that node context if that node was found and `Nothing`
otherwise. `updater` can then return `Just` an updated node context
(modifying edges is also permitted!) or delete the node by returning
`Nothing`. The updated `graph` is returned.

This is the most powerful building function since all possible per-node
operations are possible (node removal, insertion and updating of context
properties).

The other operations can be implemented in terms of `update` like this:

    remove nodeId graph =
      update nodeId (always Nothing) graph
    insert nodeContext graph =
      update nodeContext.node.id (always (Just nodeContext)) graph
values.type: Graph.NodeId -> (Maybe.Maybe (Graph.NodeContext n e) -> Maybe.Maybe (Graph.NodeContext n e)) -> Graph.Graph n e -> Graph.Graph n e

docs.name: Graph.Tree

aliases.name: Forest
aliases.comment:
This is just an alias for a list of trees, called a forest in the
literature.

types.name: Tree
types.comment:
Data type representing an n-ary tree with node labels of type `a`
Building such a tree is done with the `empty`, `leaf` and `inner` smart
constructors. An example for a tree with three leafs and a root node:

    tree = inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3, leaf 4]

values.name: empty
values.comment: Construct an empty tree with no nodes.

values.name: height
values.comment:
Computes the height of the tree in O(n) time.

    tree = inner 0 [inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3], inner 4 [leaf 5, leaf 6]]
    height tree == 3

values.name: inner
values.comment:
Construct a new tree by `inner label children`, combining a number of
subtrees `children` with a `label` for the new inner node which will be
the root of the tree. Empty subtrees are filtered out. An example:

    tree1 = inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3, leaf 4]
    tree2 = inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3, leaf 4, empty]
    tree1 == tree2

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment:
`isEmpty tree` returns true if and only if `tree` is `empty`.

    isEmpty empty == True
    isEmpty (leaf 42) == False

values.name: leaf
values.comment:
Construct a tree with a single node from a value for the node's label.

    tree : Tree Int
    tree = leaf 42

values.name: levelOrder
values.comment:
`levelOrder visit acc tree` is a breadth-first fold over `tree`,
visiting each node and accumulating results with `visit`. Nodes are visited
in level-order, e.g. for a tree like

    tree = inner 0 [inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3], inner 4 [leaf 5, leaf 6]]

nodes would be visited in order `[0, 1, 4, 2, 3, 5, 6]`. This is in fact the
list produced by `levelOrderList`, but through `levelOrder` you also get access
to the children of the current node via the second parameter of visit.
values.type: (label -> Graph.Tree.Forest label -> acc -> acc) -> acc -> Graph.Tree.Tree label -> acc

values.name: levelOrderList
values.comment:
See the documentation on `levelOrder`. `levelOrderList tree` produces
a list of the nodes of the tree visited in level-order, e.g. breadth-first.
So:

    tree = inner 0 [inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3], inner 4 [leaf 5, leaf 6]]
    levelOrderList tree == [0, 1, 4, 2, 3, 5, 6]

If you also need information on child trees instead of just the node labels,
use `levelOrder`.

values.name: postOrder
values.comment:
`postOrder visit acc tree` is a (depth-first) post-order traversal (fold)
over `tree` where `visit` is called with the label and the child sub-forest of
the current node in addition to a supplied accumulator value.

When `visit` is called for some node, `acc` already contains the value of all
sub-trees, so post-order traversal is a kind of bottom-up traversal, where
all children are visited prior to their parent.
See `postOrderList` for an example on the order in which nodes are visited.
values.type: (label -> Graph.Tree.Forest label -> acc -> acc) -> acc -> Graph.Tree.Tree label -> acc

values.name: postOrderList
values.comment:
See `postOrder` for an explanation of how post-order traversals work.
Here is an example on visit order:

    tree = inner 0 [inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3], inner 4 [leaf 5, leaf 6]]
    postOrderList tree == [2, 3, 1, 5, 6, 4, 0]

If you also need information on child trees instead of just the node labels,
use `postOrder`.

values.name: preOrder
values.comment:
`preOrder visit acc tree` is a (depth-first) pre-order traversal (fold)
over `tree` where `visit` is called with the label and the child sub-forest of
the current node in addition to a supplied accumulator value.

Post-order traversals work top-down: When `visit` is called for some node,
`acc` already contains the value of all ancestral nodes.
See `preOrderList` for an example on the order in which nodes are visited.
values.type: (label -> Graph.Tree.Forest label -> acc -> acc) -> acc -> Graph.Tree.Tree label -> acc

values.name: preOrderList
values.comment:
See `preOrder` for an explanation of how post-order traversals work.
Here is an example on visit order:

    tree = inner 0 [inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3], inner 4 [leaf 5, leaf 6]]
    preOrderList tree == [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

If you also need information on child trees instead of just the node labels,
use `preOrder`.

values.name: root
values.comment:
`root tree` returns `Nothing` if `tree` is `empty`, otherwise
it returns `Just (label, childForest)` of the root node.

    tree = inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3, leaf 4]
    root tree == Just (1, [leaf 2, leaf 3, leaf 4])
    root empty == Nothing
values.type: Graph.Tree.Tree label -> Maybe.Maybe ( label, Graph.Tree.Forest label )

values.name: size
values.comment:
The size of the tree, e.g. the number of nodes.

    tree = inner 0 [inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3], inner 4 [leaf 5, leaf 6]]
    size tree == 7

values.name: unfoldForest
values.comment:
Construct a new forest with `unfoldForest next seeds` by `unfoldTree next seed`
for each `seed` in `seeds`. A simple specification would be

    unfoldForest next seeds = List.map (unfoldTree next) seeds
values.type: (seed -> ( label, List seed )) -> List seed -> Graph.Tree.Forest label

values.name: unfoldTree
values.comment:
Construct a new tree with `unfoldTree next seed`, top to bottom. `next` will be
called repeatedly with seeds, from which it should construct a label for
the current tree node but also a list of seeds from which to unfold
child nodes. This sort of works top to bottom compared to creating a
tree bottom up by using the other primitives.

    tree1 = inner 1 [leaf 2, leaf 3, leaf 4]
    next seed = (seed, if seed == 1 then [2, 3, 4] else [])
    tree2 = unfoldTree next 1
    tree1 == tree2
values.type: (seed -> ( label, List seed )) -> seed -> Graph.Tree.Tree label

docs.name: IntDict.Safe

aliases.name: SafeKeyResult
aliases.comment:
A value of this type is returned by all functions in this module. 
See the core libraries' `Result` documentation for how to cope with it.

types.name: InvalidKey
types.comment: An error type signaling an invalid key.

values.name: safeGet
values.comment: Version of `IntDict.get` that validates the key.

values.name: safeInsert
values.comment: Version of `IntDict.insert` that validates the key.
values.type: Int -> v -> IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.Safe.SafeKeyResult (IntDict.IntDict v)

values.name: safeMember
values.comment: Version of `IntDict.member` that validates the key.

values.name: safeRemove
values.comment: Version of `IntDict.remove` that validates the key.

values.name: safeUpdate
values.comment: Version of `IntDict.update` that validates the key.
values.type: Int -> (Maybe.Maybe v -> Maybe.Maybe v) -> IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.Safe.SafeKeyResult (IntDict.IntDict v)

docs.name: IntDict
docs.comment:
# IntDict

This module exposes the same API as `Dict`.

# Technicalities

Since JavaScript's number type is kind of messed up, Elm's `Int` is not particularly
well-behaved wrt. bitwise operations. Currently, JS supports 32 bit integers, so there is
probably enough room for key picks. **However, when sanitizing user input, it is mandatory
that a prior `isValidKey` or one of the safe versions in `IntDict.Safe` is used!** This is
to prevent the overflow behavior.

This library is inspired by Haskells [IntMap](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/containers-0.2.0.1/docs/Data-IntMap.html),
which in turn implements Okasaki and Gill's [Fast mergable integer maps](http://ittc.ku.edu/~andygill/papers/IntMap98.pdf).

As noted in the [references](http://ittc.ku.edu/~andygill/papers/IntMap98.pdf), here are some runtimes:

*O(min(n, W))*: `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `get`, `member`

*O(n + m)*: `uniteWith`, `union`, `intersection`, `diff`

where *n* and *m* are the sizes of the first and second dictionary respectively and *W*
is the number of bits in `Int` (so a constant with current value 32).

# Data
@docs IntDict, isValidKey
# Build
@docs empty, singleton, insert, update, remove
# Query
@docs isEmpty, size, member, get, findMin, findMax
# Combine
@docs uniteWith, union, intersect, diff
# Lists
@docs keys, values, toList, fromList
# Transform
@docs map, foldl, foldr, filter, partition
# String representation
@docs toString'

types.name: IntDict
types.comment:
A dictionary mapping `Int`s to values of a type `v`. Analogous to
`Dict Int v`.

values.name: diff
values.comment:
Keep a key-value pair when its key does not appear in the second dictionary.
Preference is given to the first dictionary.
values.type: IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty dictionary.

values.name: filter
values.comment: Keep a key-value pair when it satisfies a predicate.
values.type: (Int -> v -> Bool) -> IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v

values.name: findMax
values.comment: Find the maximum key and value in the dictionary.

values.name: findMin
values.comment: Find the minimum key and value in the dictionary.

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Fold over the key-value pairs in a dictionary, in order from lowest
key to highest key.
values.type: (Int -> v -> a -> a) -> a -> IntDict.IntDict v -> a

values.name: foldr
values.comment:
Fold over the key-value pairs in a dictionary, in order from highest
key to lowest key.
values.type: (Int -> v -> a -> a) -> a -> IntDict.IntDict v -> a

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert an association list into a dictionary.

values.name: get
values.comment:
Get the value associated with a key. If the key is not found, return
`Nothing`. This is useful when you are not sure if a key will be in the
dictionary.

values.name: insert
values.comment:
Insert a key-value pair into a dictionary. Replaces value when there is
a collision.
values.type: Int -> v -> IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v

values.name: intersect
values.comment:
Keep a key-value pair when its key appears in the second dictionary.
Preference is given to values in the first dictionary.
values.type: IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment: Check if the dictionary contains no items.

values.name: isValidKey
values.comment:
Validates that a given integer is usable as a key.
This is necessary due to JavaScript's weird number type.
Basically this assures that we can use the functions
from `Bitwise` without risking integer overflow.

**This function is a necessity for sanitizing user input!** Alternatively,
use the safe functions from `IntDict.Safe` which perform the check for you.

As with the current version of JavaScript (2015), only 32 bit signed integers are supported.
If this ever changes, contact me! Certain parts of the implementation depend on this!

values.name: keys
values.comment: Get all of the keys in a dictionary.

values.name: map
values.comment: Apply a function to all values in a dictionary.
values.type: (Int -> a -> b) -> IntDict.IntDict a -> IntDict.IntDict b

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if a key is in a dictionary.

values.name: partition
values.comment:
Partition a dictionary according to a predicate. The first dictionary
contains all key-value pairs which satisfy the predicate, and the second
contains the rest.
values.type: (Int -> v -> Bool) -> IntDict.IntDict v -> ( IntDict.IntDict v, IntDict.IntDict v )

values.name: remove
values.comment:
Remove a key-value pair from a dictionary. If the key is not found,
no changes are made.

values.name: singleton
values.comment: Create a dictionary with one key-value pair.

values.name: size
values.comment: The number of items in the dictionary. `O(1)`.

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert a dictionary into an association list of key-value pairs.

values.name: toString'
values.comment:
Generates a string representation similar to what `toString`
generates for `Dict`.

values.name: union
values.comment:
Combine two dictionaries. If there is a collision, preference is given
to the first dictionary.
values.type: IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v

values.name: uniteWith
values.comment:
`uniteWith merger d1 d2` combines two dictionaries. If there is a collision, `merger`
is called with the conflicting key, the value from `d1` and that from `d2`.
values.type: (Int -> v -> v -> v) -> IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v

values.name: update
values.comment: Update the value of a dictionary for a specific key with a given function.
values.type: Int -> (Maybe.Maybe v -> Maybe.Maybe v) -> IntDict.IntDict v -> IntDict.IntDict v

values.name: values
values.comment: Get all of the values in a dictionary.

docs.name: Timer

aliases.name: Model
aliases.comment:
Type alias that represents the internal value of a timer.
It's basically just a simple counter.

types.name: Action
types.comment:
A type that you can use to update the timer.
A `Tick` moves forward, a `Tock` goes backwards.

values.name: addLeadingZero
values.comment:
Adds a leading zero to a number *only if* it's a single digit.

    addLeadingZero 0 == "0"
    addLeadingZero 1 == "01"
    addLeadingZero 12 == "12"

values.name: clock
values.comment: A counter that increments every second.

values.name: countdown
values.comment:
A `Signal` that tells a `Timer` to step backwards.
Use this if you want a timer that goes to the past.
This will have no effect if the time is already expired (00:00).

values.name: init
values.comment: Initialize a timer.

values.name: init'
values.comment:
Initialize a timer with a starting value, in seconds.

    Timer.init' (round Time.hour)

    -- or, if you like magic numbers
    Timer.init' 3600

values.name: tick
values.comment:
A `Signal` that tells a `Timer` to step forward.
Use this if you want a timer that goes to the future.

values.name: update
view
values.comment:
Provides a way to display the timer, in a format that
looks like 01:30 (always with leading zeros).

    Timer.view (Timer.init 30) -- will return "00:30"

docs.name: Chart

values.name: addValueToLabel
values.comment:
addValueToLabel adds the data value of each item to the data label. This is applied by default in hBar.

    vBar vs ls "Title"
        |> addValueToLabel
        |> toHtml

values.name: colors
values.comment: colors supports alternative spelling of colours

values.name: colours
values.comment:
colours replaces the default colours. Bar charts use just one colour, which will be the head of the list provided.

    vChart vs ls
        |> colours ["steelblue"]
        |> toHtml

    pie vs ls
        |> colours ["steelblue", "#96A65B", "#D9A679", "#593F27", "#A63D33"]
        |> toHtml

values.name: hBar
values.comment:
The horizontal bar chart results in a set of bars, one above the other, of lengths in proportion to the value. A label with the data value is printed in each bar.

    hBar vals labels
        |> title "My Chart"
        |> toHtml

values.name: pie
values.comment:
The pie chart results in a circle cut into coloured segments of size proportional to the data value.

    pie vals labels
        |> toHtml

values.name: title
values.comment:
title adds a title to the model.

    -- e.g. build a chart from scratch
    chartInit vs ls BarHorizontal
        |> title "This will be the title"
        |> toHtml

values.name: toHtml
values.comment:
toHtml is called last, and causes the chart data to be rendered to html.

    hBar vs ls
        |> toHtml

values.name: updateStyles
values.comment:
updateStyles replaces styles for a specified part of the chart. Charts have the following div structure

    .container
        .title
        .chart-container
            .chart      (container for the bars or pie segments)
                .chart-elements
            .legend     (also for the label container in a vertical bar chart)
                .legend-labels

    vChart vs ls
        |> updateStyles "chart" [ ( "color", "black" ) ]
        |> toHtml

values.name: vBar
values.comment:
The vertical bar chart results in a set of bars of lengths in proportion to the value. A label is printed below each bar.

    vBar vals labels
        |> title "My Chart"
        |> toHtml

docs.name: Jwt

types.name: JwtError
types.comment:
The three errors that can emerge are:
 - network errors,
 - issues with processing (e.g. base 64 decoding) the token, and
 - problems decoding the json data within the content of the token

values.name: authenticate
values.comment:
`authenticate` is a custom Http POST method that sends a stringified
Json object containing the login credentials. It then extracts the token from the
json response from the server and returns it.

    authenticate
        ("token" := Json.string)
        "http://localhost:5000/auth"
        ("{\"username\":\"" ++ model.uname ++ "\",\"password\":\""++ model.pword ++ "\"}")
            |> Task.map Token
            |> Effects.task
values.type: Json.Decode.Decoder String -> String -> String -> Task.Task never (Result.Result Jwt.JwtError String)

values.name: decodeToken
values.comment:
decodeToken converts the token content to an Elm record structure.

    decoderToken dec token

In the event of success, `decodeToken` returns an Elm record structure using the JSON Decoder.
values.type: Json.Decode.Decoder a -> String -> Result.Result Jwt.JwtError a

values.name: getWithJwt
values.comment:
getWithJwt is a replacement for `Http.get` that attaches a provided Jwt token
to the headers of the GET request.

    getWithJwt model.token "http://localhost:5000/api/restos/test"
        |> Task.toResult
        |> Task.map AuthData
        |> Effects.tasks
values.type: String -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> String -> Task.Task Http.Error a

docs.name: Array.Experimental
docs.comment:
Array.Experimental is a testing playground for various Array related functions. It contains functions that are experimental, unidiomatic, controversial or downright silly. This is specifically to not clutter Array and Array.Extra, and also have an isolated place to test crazy ideas.

*Do not* use this module in production code. Try your best to come up with equivalent functionality or solve your problem in a different way, and if you fail, consider contributing to Array and Array.Extra packages.

*Do not* import functions from this module unqualified if you do use it.

This package has the lowest possible bar for inclusion of Array related functions. If you have some code that you want to publish somewhere, but not necessarily contribute to core libraries, feel absolutely free to contribute here. Treat this package as a safe sandbox. The GitHub page for ideas, suggestions, discussions, and pull requests is:

https://github.com/sindikat/elm-maybe-experimental

# Array functions
@docs get, set, update, take, drop

values.name: drop
values.comment:
Drop *n* first elements from an array. In other words, slice an array from an index until the very end.

    drop 5 (fromList [0..9]) == fromList [5,6,7,8,9]

values.name: get
values.comment:
Return `Just` the element at the index. Given negative argument, counts the element from end. Returns `Nothing` if the index  abs (length array).

    get  0 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Just 0
    get  2 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Just 2
    get  5 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Nothing
    get -1 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Just 2

`Array.get` from core libraries do not support negative arguments, but it might in the future.

values.name: set
values.comment:
Sets the element at the index. Given negative argument, counts the element from end. Returns the array unchanged if the index  abs (length array).

    set  1 7 (fromList [1,2,3]) == fromList [1,7,3]
    set -1 7 (fromList [1,2,3]) == fromList [1,2,7]

`Array.set` from core libraries do not support negative arguments, but it might in the future.
values.type: Int -> a -> Array.Array a -> Array.Array a

values.name: take
values.comment:
Take *n* first elements from an array. In other words, slice an array from the very beginning until index not including.

    take 5 (fromList [0..9]) == fromList [0,1,2,3,4]

values.name: update
values.comment:
Update the element at the index using a function. Given negative argument, counts the element from end. Returns the array unchanged if the index  abs (length array).

    update  1 ((+)10) (fromList [1,2,3]) == fromList [1,12,3]
    update -1 ((+)10) (fromList [1,2,3]) == fromList [1,2,13]

There is no `Array.update` in the core libraries.
values.type: Int -> (a -> a) -> Array.Array a -> Array.Array a

docs.name: EasyEvents
docs.comment:
# Event helpers
@docs onInput, onInputInt, onInputFloat, onSpecificKeyPress, onEnterPress, onChange

values.name: onChange
values.comment:
Takes an address of a type, and a function that produces a value of that
type from a string. That value will be send to the address in a message
when a "change" event is fired.

You'll probably use this to send an action to your update function when
an HTML `select` is changed.

values.name: onEnterPress
values.comment:
Takes an address, and an action, and sends the action to the address only
when the enter key is pressed on the parent element.

values.name: onInput
values.comment:
Accepts an action, and a function that turns a string into an action.

Example:

```
type Action = UpdateName String

foo address model =
    input
        [ type' "text"
        , onInput address UpdateName
        , value model
        ]
```

The code above would send an UpdateName action to `adress` whenever an input
event is fired on the input element.

values.name: onInputFloat
values.comment: Like `onInput`, but for Floats instead of Strings

values.name: onInputInt
values.comment: Like `onInput`, but for Ints instead of Strings

values.name: onSpecificKeyPress
values.comment:
Takes an address, a key code, and an action. Sends the action to the address
whenever that specific key code is pressed with the parent element focused.

This is useful for reacting only to specific key-presses (like submitting a
form when the enter key is pressed, for example).

docs.name: Table

aliases.name: Props
aliases.comment:
- Use the caption to describe the purpose of the table (it helps out visually impaired people)
- Pass in HTML for the headers (accepting HTML lets you do fancy things like use buttons)
- In the same way, pass in lists of HTML for rows
aliases.type: { caption : String , headers : List Html.Html , rows : List (List Html.Html) }

values.name: table
values.comment: Simple enough, just pass in props and you'll get back a semantic, accessible table!

aliases.comment: Record that holds url attributes
aliases.type: { protocol : String , username : String , password : String , host : List String , port' : Int , path : List String , hasTrailingSlash : Bool , hash : String , query : Erl.Query }

values.name: addQuery
values.comment:
Set key/value in query string

    Erl.addQuery key value url

values.name: appendPathSegments
values.comment:
Append some path segments to a url

    Erl.appendPathSegments ["hello", "world"] url

values.name: clearQuery
values.comment:
Clears the current query string

    Erl.clearQuery url

values.name: extractHash
values.comment: Extract the hash (hash) from the url

values.name: extractHost
values.comment: Extract the host from the url

values.name: extractPath
values.comment: Extract the path from the url

values.name: extractPort
values.comment: Extract the port from the url

values.name: extractProtocol
values.comment: Extract the protocol from the url

values.name: extractQuery
values.comment: Extract the query string from the url

values.name: new
values.comment:
Generate an empty Erl.Url record

    Erl.new ==

    { protocol = ""
    , username = ""
    , password = ""
    , host = []
    , path = []
    , hasTrailingSlash = False
    , port' = 0
    , hash = ""
    , query = Dict.empty
    }

values.name: parse
values.comment:
Parse a url string, returns an Erl.Url record

    Erl.parse "http://api.example.com/users/1#x/1?a=1" == Erl.Url{...}

values.name: queryToString
values.comment:
Convert to a string only the query component of an url, this includes '?'

    Erl.queryToString url == "?a=1&b=2"

values.name: removeQuery
values.comment:
Removes key from query string

    Erl.removeQuery key url

values.name: setQuery
values.comment:
Set key/value in query string, removes any existing ones

    Erl.setQuery key value url

values.name: toString
values.comment:
Generate url string from an Erl.Url record

    url = { protocol = "http",
          , username = "",
          , password = "",
          , host = ["www", "foo", "com"],
          , path = ["users", "1"],
          , hasTrailingSlash = False
          , port' = 2000,
          , hash = "a/b",
          , query = Dict.empty |> Dict.insert "q" "1" |> Dict.insert "k" "2"
          }

    Erl.toString url == "http://www.foo.com:2000/users/1?k=2&q=1#a/b"

docs.name: Hop

values.name: new
values.comment:
Create a Router

    config =
      { basePath = "/app"
      , hash = False
      , matchers = matchers
      , notFound = NotFound
      }

    router =
      Hop.new config

docs.name: Hop.Navigate
docs.comment:
Functions for changing the browser location

@docs navigateTo, addQuery, removeQuery, setQuery, clearQuery

values.name: addQuery
values.comment:
Add query string values (patches any existing values)

    addQuery config query location

- config is the router Config record
- query is a dictionary with keys to add
- location is a record representing the current location

Example use in update:

    update action model =
      case action of
        ...
        AddQuery query ->
          (model, Effects.map HopAction (addQuery config query model.location))

To remove a value set the value to ""

values.name: clearQuery
values.comment:
Clear all query string values

    clearQuery config location

Example use in update:

    update action model =
      case action of
        ...
        ClearQuery ->
          (model, Effects.map HopAction (clearQuery config model.location))

values.name: navigateTo
values.comment:
Changes the location (hash and query)

  navigateTo will append "#/" if necessary

    navigateTo config "/users"

  Example use in update:

    update action model =
      case action of
        ...
        NavigateTo path ->
          (model, Effects.map HopAction (navigateTo config path))

values.name: removeQuery
values.comment:
Remove one query string value

    removeQuery config query location

Example use in update:

    update action model =
      case action of
        ...
        RemoveQuery query ->
          (model, Effects.map HopAction (removeQuery config key model.location))

values.name: setQuery
values.comment:
Set query string values (removes existing values)

    setQuery config query location

Example use in update:

    update action model =
      case action of
        ...
        SetQuery query ->
          (model, Effects.map HopAction (setQuery config query model.location))

docs.name: Hop.Matchers

values.name: int
values.comment:
Parameter matcher that matches an integer

    match2 User "/users/" int

values.name: match1
values.comment:
Create a matcher with one static segment.

    type Route = Books

    match1 Books "/books"

This will match exactly

    "/books"

values.name: match2
values.comment:
Create a matcher with one static segment and one dynamic parameter.

    type Route = Book Str

    match2 Book "/books/" str

This will match a path like

    "/books/abc"
values.type: (param1 -> route) -> String -> Combine.Parser param1 -> Hop.Types.PathMatcher route

values.name: match3
values.comment:
Create a matcher with three segments.

    type Route = BookReviews Int

    match3 BookReviews "/books/" int "/reviews"

This will match a path like

    "/books/1/reviews"
values.type: (param1 -> route) -> String -> Combine.Parser param1 -> String -> Hop.Types.PathMatcher route

values.name: match4
values.comment:
Create a matcher with four segments.

    type Route = BookChapter Int String

    match4 BookChapter "/books/" int "/chapters/" str

This will match a path like

    "/books/1/chapters/abc"
values.type: (param1 -> param2 -> route) -> String -> Combine.Parser param1 -> String -> Combine.Parser param2 -> Hop.Types.PathMatcher route

values.name: matchLocation
values.comment:
Matches a location record.
Returns the matched route.

    matchLocation config { path = ["users", "1"], query = [] }

    ==

    (User 1)

values.name: matchPath
values.comment:
Matches a path.
BasePath should already be removed.
e.g. "/users/1/comments/2".

Returns the matched route.

    matchPath config "/users/1/comments/2"

    ==

    User 1 (Comment 2)

values.name: matcherToPath
values.comment:
Generates a path from a matcher. Use this for reverse routing.

The last parameters is a list of strings. You need to pass one string for each dynamic parameter that this route takes.

    matcherToPath bookReviewMatcher ["1", "2"]

    ==

    "/books/1/reviews/2"

values.name: nested1
values.comment:
Create a matcher with two segments and nested routes

    type CategoriesRoute = Games | Business | Product Int
    type Route = ShopCategories CategoriesRoute

    nested1 ShopCategories "/shop" categoriesRoutes

This could match paths like (depending on the nested routes)

    "/shop/games"
    "/shop/business"
    "/shop/product/1"
values.type: (subRoute -> route) -> String -> List (Hop.Types.PathMatcher subRoute) -> Hop.Types.PathMatcher route

values.name: nested2
values.comment:
Create a matcher with two segments and nested routes

    type ReviewsRoutes = Reviews | Review Int
    type Route = BookReviews ReviewsRoutes

    nested2 BookReviews "/books/" int reviewsRoutes

This could match paths like (depending on the nested routes)

    "/books/1/reviews"
    "/books/1/reviews/3"
values.type: (param1 -> subRoute -> route) -> String -> Combine.Parser param1 -> List (Hop.Types.PathMatcher subRoute) -> Hop.Types.PathMatcher route

values.name: str
values.comment:
Parameter matcher that matches a string, except /

    match2 Token "/token/" str

aliases.name: Config
aliases.comment:
Configuration input for Hop.new

- basePath: Only for pushState routing (not hash). e.g. "/app". All routing and matching is done after this basepath.
- hash: True for hash routing, False for pushState routing.
- matchers: A List of route matchers.
- notFound: Route that will match when a location is not found.
aliases.type: { basePath : String , hash : Bool , matchers : List (Hop.Types.PathMatcher route) , notFound : route }

PathMatcher
aliases.comment: A path matcher
aliases.type: { parser : Combine.Parser action, segments : List String }

A Dict that holds query parameters

    Dict.Dict String String

aliases.name: Router
aliases.comment: Router record created by Hop.new

docs.name: Complex

values.name: abs
values.comment:
Takes the absolute value of a complex number.

    abs 2+2i == sqrt 8
    abs -2-2i == sqrt 8
    abs 0+0i == 0

values.name: acos
values.comment: Complex inverse cosine.

values.name: add
values.comment: Adds two complex numbers by adding the real and imaginary parts.

values.name: arg
values.comment:
The argument of a complex number. It is in radians. This is also known as the phase or angle.

    arg 0+0i == 0
    arg 0+i == pi/2

values.name: asin
values.comment: Complex inverse sine.

values.name: atan
values.comment: Complex inverse tan.

values.name: complex
values.comment:
Generates a complex number. 

    complex 1 2 == 1+2i

values.name: conjugate
values.comment:
Returns the conjugate of a complex number 

    conjugate 2+3i == 2 - 3i
    conjugate 2-3i == 2+3i

values.name: cos
values.comment: Complex cosine.

values.name: div
values.comment:
Divides two complex numbers.

    div 2+2i 1+1i == 2+0
    div 2+2i 0+0i == NaN + NaNi

values.name: euler
values.comment:
Euler's formula. 
           
           euler 2 == e^{i*2} == cos 2 + i*sin 2

values.name: exp
values.comment: The exponent of a complex number.

values.name: fromReal
values.comment:
Creates a complex number from one real numer. 

    fromReal 5 == 5 + 0i

values.name: i
values.comment:
The number i 
    
    i == complex 0 1

values.name: imaginary
values.comment:
Provides the imaginary part of a complex number.

    imaginary 2+3i == 3

values.name: ln
values.comment: The natrual log of a complex number.

values.name: mult
values.comment:
Multiplies two complex numbers so that

    mult (a+bi) (c+di) == (ac-bd) + (ad+bc)

values.name: negation
values.comment:
Negates a complex number.

    negation 1+2i == -1-2i
    negation -1-2i == 1 + 2i
    negation -1+2i == 1 - 2i

values.name: one
values.comment:
The number 1.

    complex 1 0 == one

values.name: pow
values.comment:
Take a complex number to a complex power.
    
    pow 1+0i 2+2i == (1)^{2+2i} == 1

values.name: real
values.comment:
Provides the real part of a complex number. 

    real 2+3i == 2

values.name: sgn
values.comment:
Returns the sign of a complex number. 

    sgn 0 + 0i == 0
    sgn 0 + 2i == 0
    sgn 1 + (-10)i == 1
    sgn (-1) + (10)i == (-1)
    sgn (-1) + (-10)i == (-1)

values.name: sin
values.comment: Complex sine.

values.name: sqrt
values.comment:
Square root of a complex number. Returns only one of two possibilites.

    sqrt (2+2i) == (1.55...) + i0.6435..

values.name: sub
values.comment: Subtacts two complex numbers by negating and adding.

values.name: tan
values.comment: Complex tangent.

values.name: zero
values.comment:
The number 0.

    complex 0 0 == zero

docs.name: Autocomplete.Simple
docs.comment:
A customizable Autocomplete component.

This Autocomplete has a static list of items. See the Autocomplete module for maintaining a dynamic list of items.

The Autocomplete consists of a menu, a list, the list's many items, and an input.
All of these views are styleable via css classes.
See the Styling module.

The currently selected item is preserved and styled with the aforementioned module.

This selection is modified by keyboard arrow input, mouse clicks, and API consumer defined keyCodes.

Check out how easy it is to plug into `StartApp`:
```
main : Signal Html.Html
main =
  StartApp.Simple.start
    { model = Autocomplete.init [ "elm", "makes", "coding", "life", "easy" ]
    , update = Autocomplete.update
    , view = Autocomplete.view
    }
```

docs.name: Autocomplete
docs.comment:
A customizable Autocomplete component.

This Autocomplete has a dynamic list of items.
See the `Autocomplete.Simple` module for using a simple, static list of items.

The Autocomplete consists of a menu, a list, the list's many items, and an input.
All of these views are styleable via css classes.
See the `Autocomplete.Styling` module.

The currently selected item is preserved and styled with the aforementioned module.

This selection is modified by keyboard arrow input, mouse clicks, and API consumer defined keyCodes.

This Autocomplete calls a API consumer-defined function that returns a refreshed list
of items upon every input or selection change.

An example of plugging this into `StartApp`:
```
fetchMoreItems : String -> Task Effects.Never (List String)
fetchMoreItems url =
  Http.url url []
    |> Http.getString
    |> Task.toMaybe
    |> Task.map responseToItems


responseToItems : Maybe String -> List String
responseToItems maybeString =
  case maybeString of
    Just string ->
      String.lines string

    Nothing ->
      []


getItemsTask : String -> Int -> Task Effects.Never (List String)
getItemsTask value index =
  fetchMoreItems "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/first20hours/google-10000-english/master/20k.txt"


app =
  let
    config =
      Autocomplete.Config.defaultConfig
        |> Autocomplete.Config.setLoadingDisplay (img [ src "assets/loading.svg" ] [])
  in
    StartApp.start
      { init = Autocomplete.initWithConfig [] getItemsTask config
      , update = Autocomplete.update
      , view = Autocomplete.view
      , inputs = []
      }


main =
  app.html


port tasks : Signal (Task.Task Never ())
port tasks =
  app.tasks
```

The above example can be found in `example/src/RemoteExample.elm`.

docs.name: Autocomplete.Styling
docs.comment:
Styling module for the Autocomplete component.

The autocomplete consists of a menu, a list, list items, and an input.
This module includes functions to provide css class names for styling those
child views.

Styling is easy as:
```
testData : List String
testData =
  [ "elm"
  , "makes"
  , "coding"
  , "life"
  , "easy"
  ]

styleView : Styling.View -> Html.Attribute
styleView view =
  case view of
    Styling.Menu ->
      class "autocomplete-menu-default"

    Styling.List ->
      class "autocomplete-list-default"

    Styling.Item ->
      class "autocomplete-item-default"

    Styling.SelectedItem ->
      class "autocomplete-selected-item-default"

    Styling.Input ->
      class "autocomplete-input-default"

main =
  let
    config =
      Autocomplete.Config.defaultConfig
        |> Autocomplete.Config.setStyleViewFn styleView
  in
    StartApp.Simple.start
      { model = initWithConfig testData config
      , update = update
      , view = view
      }
```

docs.name: MultiwayTreeZipper
docs.comment:
A library for navigating and updating immutable trees. The elements in
the tree must have the same type. The trees are implemented in a Huet
Zipper fashion.

# Types
@docs Context, Breadcrumbs, Zipper

# Navigation API
@docs goToChild, goUp, goToRoot

# Update API
@docs updateDatum, replaceDatum

# Access API
@docs datum, maybeDatum


# References
[The Zipper, Gerard Huet](https://www.st.cs.uni-saarland.de/edu/seminare/2005/advanced-fp/docs/huet-zipper.pdf)
[Learn You A Haskell, Zippers, Miran Lipovaca](http://learnyouahaskell.com/zippers)

# Future work
Might be able to integrate existing [Rose Tree](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/TheSeamau5/elm-rosetree) to work with the Zipper.
Wanted the first version to be self contained.

aliases.name: Breadcrumbs
aliases.comment:
A list of Contexts that is contructed as a MultiwayTree is navigated.
Breadcrumbs are used to retain information about parts of the tree that move out
of focus. As the tree is navigated, the needed Context is pushed onto the list
Breadcrumbs, and they are maintained in the reverse order in which they are
visited

aliases.name: Zipper
aliases.comment:
A structure to keep track of the current Tree, as well as the Breadcrumbs to
allow us to continue navigation through the rest of the tree.

types.name: Context
types.comment:
The necessary information needed to reconstruct a MultiwayTree as it is
navigated with a Zipper. This context includes the datum that was at the
previous node, a list of children that came before the node, and a list of
children that came after the node.

values.name: datum
values.comment: Access the datum at the current Zipper focus.

values.name: goToChild
values.comment:
Move down relative to the current Zipper focus. This allows navigation from
a parent to it's children.

    (&>) = Maybe.andThen

    simpleTree =
        Tree "a"
            [ Tree "b" []
            , Tree "c" []
            , Tree "d" []
            ]

    Just (simpleTree, [])
        &> goToChild 1

values.name: goToRoot
values.comment:
Move to the root of the current Zipper focus. This allows navigation from
any part of the tree back to the root.

    (&>) = Maybe.andThen

    simpleTree =
        Tree "a"
            [ Tree "b"
                [ Tree "e" [] ]
            , Tree "c" []
            , Tree "d" []
            ]

    Just (simpleTree, [])
        &> goToChild 0
        &> goToChild 1
        &> goToRoot

values.name: goUp
values.comment:
Move up relative to the current Zipper focus. This allows navigation from a
child to it's parent.

    (&>) = Maybe.andThen

    simpleTree =
        Tree "a"
            [ Tree "b" []
            , Tree "c" []
            , Tree "d" []
            ]

    Just (simpleTree, [])
        &> goToChild 0
        &> goUp

values.name: maybeDatum
values.comment: Access the datum at the current Zipper focus as a Maybe.

values.name: replaceDatum
values.comment:
Replace the datum at the current Zipper focus. This allows complete
replacement of a node's datum information, ignoring the previous state of the
node.

    (&>) = Maybe.andThen

    simpleTree =
        Tree "a"
            [ Tree "b"
                [ Tree "e" [] ]
            , Tree "c" []
            , Tree "d" []
            ]

    Just (simpleTree, [])
        &> goToChild 0
        &> replaceDatum "X" -- Replaces "b" with "X"
        &> goToRoot

values.name: updateDatum
values.comment:
Update the datum at the current Zipper focus. This allows changes to be made
to a part of a node's datum information, given the previous state of the node.

    (&>) = Maybe.andThen

    simpleTree =
        Tree "a"
            [ Tree "b"
                [ Tree "e" [] ]
            , Tree "c" []
            , Tree "d" []
            ]

    Just (simpleTree, [])
        &> goToChild 0
        &> updateDatum (\old -> old ++ "X") -- Appends an X to "b"
        &> goToRoot

docs.name: Fuzzy

aliases.name: Key
aliases.comment: Represents a matching character in a Match.

aliases.name: Match
aliases.comment:
Represents a matching word in hay.
score is the score that this Match contributes to the total score in a Result.
offset is the index where this match starts in the hay.
length is the length of the match.
keys is a list of matching indexes within the word. The keys are relative to the offset.
aliases.type: { score : Int, offset : Int, length : Int, keys : List Fuzzy.Key }

aliases.name: Result
aliases.comment:
Represents the result of a match.
score is the total score of the result.
matches is a list of matching words within the hay.

values.name: addPenalty
values.comment: Create a penalty configuration that is applied to each additional character in hay.

values.name: match
values.comment:
Perform fuzzy matching between a query String (needle) and a target String (hay).
The order of the arguments are significant. Lower score is better. Specifying some
separators will allow for partial matching within a sentence. The default configuration is
movePenalty = 100, addPenalty = 1, removePenalty = 1000.

    let
        simpleMatch config separators needle hay =
          match config separators needle hay |> .score
    in
        simpleMatch [] [] "test" "test" == 0
        simpleMatch [] [] "tst" "test" == 1
        simpleMatch [addPenalty 10000] [] "tst" "test" == 10000
        simpleMatch [] [] "test" "tste" == 100
        simpleMatch [] [] "test" "tst" == 1000
        simpleMatch [] ["/"] "/u/b/s" "/usr/local/bin/sh" == 5
        simpleMatch [] [] "/u/b/s" "/usr/local/bin/sh" == 211
        List.sortBy (simpleMatch [] [] "hrdevi") ["screen", "disk", "harddrive", "keyboard", "mouse", "computer"] == ["harddrive","keyboard","disk","screen","computer","mouse"]
values.type: List Fuzzy.Config -> List String -> String -> String -> Fuzzy.Result

values.name: movePenalty
values.comment: Create a penalty configuration that is applied to each out of order character in hay.

values.name: removePenalty
values.comment: Create a penalty configuration that is applied to each additional character in needle.

docs.name: Base64
docs.comment:
Library for base64 encoding and decoding of Ascii strings.
For the moment only works with the characters :

" !\"#$%&\'()*+,-./0123456789:;<=>?@ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ[\\]^_`abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz{|}~"

# Method
@docs encode, decode

values.name: decode
values.comment:
base64 decodes an ascii string. If the input is not a valid base64 string returns a Result.Err,
otherwise a Result.Ok String
    decode("RWxtIGlzIENvb2w=") == Result.Ok "Elm is Cool"

values.name: encode
values.comment:
base64 encodes an ascii string. If the input is not valid returns a Result.Err,
otherwise a Result.Ok String
    encode("Elm is Cool") == Result.Ok "RWxtIGlzIENvb2w="

values.name: interactFold
values.comment:
One top-level interface to this module. Given
- how to update the state (type `m`) given an action (type `a`),
- how to render a diagram given the state,
- and how to compute the location of the collage on screen from the window dimensions,
Return a signal of diagrams.

Since it returns a signal, you should only use it if this is the top-level interaction of your app; i.e.
you aren't making a component that's nestable inside others as in the Elm Architecture. To make a component,
use `update` to build an update function.
values.type: Diagrams.Interact.UpdateFunc m a -> Diagrams.Interact.RenderFunc m t a -> Diagrams.Wiring.CollageLocFunc -> m -> Signal.Signal (Diagrams.Type.Diagram t a)

values.name: processMouseEvent
values.comment:
Given diagram with mouse state (`MouseDiagram`), mouse event, and dimensions of collage, return
new `MouseDiagram` with list of actions triggered by this mouse event.
values.type: Diagrams.Type.Diagram t a -> Diagrams.Interact.MouseState t a -> Diagrams.Wiring.PrimMouseEvent -> ( Diagrams.Interact.MouseState t a, List a )

values.name: update
values.comment:
Function to update the interaction state, given an event (probably from `Diagrams.Wiring`'s `makeUpdateStream`)
-- the other top-level interface.
values.type: ( Diagrams.Wiring.CollageLocation, Diagrams.Wiring.PrimMouseEvent ) -> Diagrams.Interact.InteractionState m t a -> Diagrams.Interact.InteractionState m t a

values.name: updateModel
values.type: (m -> m) -> Diagrams.Interact.InteractionState m t a -> Diagrams.Interact.InteractionState m t a

Align a list of diagrams along a vertical line according to the

values.name: zcat
values.comment:
Place a list of diagrams on top of each other, with their origin points

docs.name: Diagrams.Query

types.name: PickTree
types.comment:
Result of `pick`: tree representing the subtree of the Diagram the
given point is over.

- Leaf nodes mean the mouse is over a primitive shape (rect, text, etc)
- Tag nodes mean the child of this pickTree is under that tag.
- Layers mean that the mouse is over two overlapping diagrams. The
  pick trees for these diagrams are given in a list starting with the
  one on top.
cases: { tag : t , offset : Diagrams.Geom.Point , actionSet : Diagrams.Actions.ActionSet t a , child : Diagrams.Query.PickTree t a }

values.name: getCoords
values.comment:
Try to find a subDiagram t at the given tag path. If it is found,
return `Just` the coordinates of its origin relative to the origin of this diagram.
If it isn't found, return `Nothing`.
values.type: Diagrams.Type.Diagram t a -> Diagrams.Query.TagPath t -> Maybe.Maybe Diagrams.Geom.Point

values.name: pick
values.comment:
Given a diagram and a point (e.g. of the mouse), return a `PickTree`, which represents
what subtree of the diagram that point is currently over.
values.type: Diagrams.Type.Diagram t a -> Diagrams.Geom.Point -> Maybe.Maybe (Diagrams.Query.PickTree t a)
