docs.name: Diagrams.Core
docs.comment:
Diagrams is a library built on top of `Graphics.Collage` which allows you to
construct graphics by laying out elements relative to each other.

A Diagram is represented as a tree of elements, where the leaves are primitive
shapes like rectangles, circles, paths and text and the nodes are transformations
like translation, rotation, and scaling.

There are also `Group` nodes. These have multiple children which are transformed
simultaneously by the transformations above them.

[Sierpinski triangle example](https://gist.github.com/vilterp/9966fd18de8d9b282ade)

Lastly, there are `Tag` nodes which just hold a child Diagram t and a value of type a;
these exist solely to identify a subdiagram, for the purposes of (a) specifying a tag
path and getting the coordinates it was positioned at (the `getCoords` function) or
(b) given a point, find what subtree it is over (the `pick` function).

Using signals to compose `pick` with mouse clicks, you can create a signal of
clicked-on elements. Folding this with the application state and re-rendering, you
can make an interface which is responsive to the mouse without channels.

The library is based on the excellent [Diagrams][hd] library for Haskell, which
has a nice [visual tutorial][hd-tut]. Things are named slightly differently, and this
version is missing a lot of features and generality.

With v5.0 the functionality has been split into many modules to make it more manageable;
this [graph of their dependencies][mod-graph] may be helpful. Not sure if a `Prelude` module
which exports everything is a good idea.

 [hd]: http://projects.haskell.org/diagrams/
 [hd-tut]: http://projects.haskell.org/diagrams/doc/quickstart.html
 [mod-graph]: https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1_321XRPhfP8t0u747QhNwR_PiibVHroxcioLq-vHdq8/edit

values.name: valueAsFloat
values.comment:
Uses `valueAsNumber` to update an input with a floating-point value.
This should only be used on <input> of type `number`, `range`, or `date`.
It differs from `value` in that a floating point value will not necessarily overwrite the contents on an input element.

    valueAsFloat 2.5 -- e.g. will not change the displayed value for input showing "2.5000"
    valueAsFloat 0.4 -- e.g. will not change the displayed value for input showing ".4"

values.name: valueAsInt
values.comment:
Uses `valueAsNumber` to update an input with an integer value.
This should only be used on <input> of type `number`, `range`, or `date`.
It differs from `value` in that an integer value will not necessarily overwrite the contents on an input element.

    valueAsInt 18 -- e.g. will not change the displayed value for input showing "00018"

docs.name: Ansi.Log

aliases.name: Chunk
aliases.comment: A blob of text paired with the style that was configured at the time.

aliases.name: CursorPosition
aliases.comment: The coordinate in the window where text will be printed.

aliases.name: Line
aliases.comment: A list of arbitrarily-sized chunks of output.

aliases.name: Model
aliases.comment:
Model is populated by parsing ANSI character sequences and escape codes
via `update`.

* `lines` contains all of the output that's been parsed
* `position` is the current position of the cursor
* `style` is the style to be applied to any text that's printed
* `remainder` is a partial ANSI escape sequence left around from an incomplete
  segment from the stream
aliases.type: { lineDiscipline : Ansi.Log.LineDiscipline , lines : Array.Array Ansi.Log.Line , position : Ansi.Log.CursorPosition , savedPosition : Maybe.Maybe Ansi.Log.CursorPosition , style : Ansi.Log.Style , remainder : String }

aliases.name: Style
aliases.comment: The current presentation state for any text that's printed.
aliases.type: { foreground : Maybe.Maybe Ansi.Color , background : Maybe.Maybe Ansi.Color , bold : Bool , faint : Bool , italic : Bool , underline : Bool , blink : Bool , inverted : Bool }

types.name: LineDiscipline
types.comment:
How to interpret linebreaks.

* `Raw`: interpret `\n` as just `\n`, i.e. move down a line, retaining the
  cursor column
* `Cooked`: interpret `\n` as `\r\n`, i.e. move down a line and go to the first
  column

values.name: init
values.comment: Construct an empty model.

values.name: update
values.comment:
Parse and interpret a chunk of ANSI output.

Trailing partial ANSI escape codes will be prepended to the chunk in the next
call to `update`.

values.name: view
values.comment:
Render the model's logs as HTML.

Wraps everything in <pre>, with a <div> for each Line, and <span> with styling
and classes for each Chunk.

The `span` elements will have the following attributes:

* `style="font-weight: bold|normal"`
* `class="ansi-COLOR-fg ansi-COLOR-bg ansi-bold"`

...where each class is optional, and `COLOR` is one of:

* `black`
* `red`
* `green`
* `yellow`
* `blue`
* `magenta`
* `cyan`
* `white`
* `bright-black`
* `bright-red`
* `bright-green`
* `bright-yellow`
* `bright-blue`
* `bright-magenta`
* `bright-cyan`
* `bright-white`

If the chunk is inverted, the `-fg` and `-bg` classes will have their colors
swapped. If the chunk is bold, the `ansi-bold` class will be present.

docs.name: Ansi

types.name: Action
types.comment:
The events relevant to interpreting the stream.

* `Print` is a chunk of text which should be interpreted with the style implied
  by the preceding actions (i.e. `[SetBold True, Print "foo"]`) should yield a
  bold `foo`
* `Remainder` is a partial ANSI escape sequence, returned at the end of the
  actions if it was cut off. The next string passed to `parse` should have this
  prepended to it.
* The rest are derived from their respective ANSI escape sequences.

types.name: Color
types.comment: The colors applied to the foreground/background.

types.name: EraseMode
types.comment: Method to erase the display or line.

values.name: parse
values.comment:
Convert an arbitrary String of text into a sequence of actions.

If the input string ends with a partial ANSI escape sequence, it will be
yielded as a `Remainder` action, which should then be prepended to the next
call to `parse`.

values.name: parseInto
values.comment: Update a structure with actions parsed out of the given string.

Create a new lexeme class from a Javascript style regex and an function to interpret a lexeme
from the matched token.

values.name: combinatorClass
values.comment:
In the case that you wish to use a more advanced combinator in place of a pattern, you may do that
with this class. You can use this to create more powerful abstractions in your lexeme output.

_DEPRECIATED_
values.type: Combine.Parser String -> (String -> Result.Result (List String) lex) -> Lexer.Class lex

values.comment: Interpret a token.

values.name: lexer

values.name: parserClass
values.comment:
Use a combinator parser directly. The form of the lexeme itself may be turing recognizable in
this case. In this sense you are no longer strictly "lexing", but the output still provides the
typical useful token metadata for Lexeme record list produced the top level alternation.

values.name: pattern
values.comment:
Get the pattern of a class. Note that this will return the empty string in the case that a
combinator is used instead.

docs.name: Gigan.Knowledge

aliases.name: BaseKnowledge
aliases.comment:
Knowledge of a KnowledgeBase. This adds basic support for nesting KnowledgeBase and KnowledgeBase
operations using `within`, which approximates the active record pattern as well as I can in Elm so
far.

aliases.name: KnowledgeBase
aliases.comment:
A knowledge base has a dictionary of Knowledge. Use this to represent arbitrary collections of
remote data with a uniform schema. You can support schemaless data with JSON, but that should really
only be done if you absolutely must, since it adds quite a bit of encoder/decoder overhead.
aliases.type: { base : Gigan.Knowledge.BaseImpl euser comparable v , deltas : Gigan.Knowledge.BaseImpl euser comparable v , deltaSink : Signal.Address (Gigan.Knowledge.BaseDeltaImpl euser comparable v) , config : Gigan.Knowledge.RemoteMapConfig euser comparable v }

aliases.name: KnowledgeBaseDelta
aliases.comment: This represents a change in Knowledge, a KnowledgeBase, or a KnowledgeRecord.

aliases.name: KnowledgeRecord
aliases.comment:
This is a wrapper for knowledge bases that are finite in size, and have a collection of
differently typed fields. It is best for records which may only be partially known. A concrete
example of this would be a user's personal information, where everything they have hidden should
come back as `forbiddenKnowledge`.
aliases.type: { kbase : Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v , writes : Dict.Dict comparable (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> userrecord -> userrecord) , reads : Dict.Dict comparable (userrecord -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) , record : userrecord }

aliases.name: KnowledgeRecordStub
aliases.comment:
A knowledge record stub represents how to manage a knowledge record, with the record itself
omitted. This type is outputted by the `record` function. Setting this for the first time using
`recordSet` will result in a proper KnowledgeRecord.
aliases.type: { kbase : Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v , writes : Dict.Dict comparable (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> userrecord -> userrecord) , reads : Dict.Dict comparable (userrecord -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) }

aliases.name: QueryTask
aliases.comment:
QueryTask is an opaque task that executes a Remote or a RemoteMap and sends the resulting deltas
to the configured address for the Knowledge, KnowledgeBase, or KnowledgeRecord.

aliases.name: RecordKnowledge
aliases.comment:
Knowledge of a KnowledgeRecord. This adds support for nesting KnowledgeRecord and KnowledgeRecord
operations using `within`, which approximates the active record pattern as well as I can in Elm so
far.

aliases.name: Remote
aliases.comment:
This is a Task which represents some kind of synchronization with remote data. It can also easily
be used for long running arbitrary computations, too. It produces a Gigan Error or a Knowledge.

aliases.name: RemoteConfig
aliases.comment:
Configures address to send remote results to, and an error handler for promoting Errors in to
Knowledge. The default error handler simply promotes errors to Undecided.
aliases.type: { address : Signal.Address (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) , errorHandler : Gigan.Error.Error euser -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v }

aliases.name: RemoteMap
aliases.comment:
This is a dictionary which represents a collection of Remote tasks which will be executed against
a KnowledgeBase or a KnowledgeRecord.

aliases.name: RemoteMapConfig
aliases.comment:
Configures an address per key to send remote results to, and an error handler per key for
promoting Errors in to Knowledge. The default error handler simply promotes errors to Undecided.
The default configuration proxies a single address which accepts a KnowledgeBaseDelta.
aliases.type: { addressOf : comparable -> Signal.Address (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) , errorHandlerOf : comparable -> Gigan.Error.Error euser -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v }

types.name: Knowledge
types.comment: A knowledge item.

values.name: assumeIf
values.comment:
If some predicate `satisfies` is satisfied by the knowledge `kb`, then we make the following
assumption. If this knowledge is an operation, then the assumption will be applied to
the result of that operation.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Bool) -> v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: assumeIfNot
values.comment: Negation of assumeIf.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Bool) -> v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: assumeIfNow
values.comment: If the predicate is satisfied, replace the knowledge with some known value.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v' -> Bool) -> v' -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v' -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v'

values.name: assumeInCase
values.comment:
If `possibleAssumption` yields some value `value'` when a Knowledge is applied, then
that value is used to overwrite the knowledge with an assumption `Known value'`, otherwise the
Knowledge is unaffected. If this knowledge is an operation, then the assumption will be applied
conditionally to the result of that operation.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Maybe.Maybe v) -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: assumeInCaseNow
values.comment:
This is the counterpart to assumeInCase which does _not_ abstract away whether or not this is
some pending remote operation. Concretely, we want this in the case that we are doing model to view
reductions because a pending operation should still have some concrete visible representation, such
as an ajax loader symbol. Of course, one should still correctly call *Integrate so that an operation
is always a `pendingKnowledge` by the time it gets past the `stage` step.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v' -> Maybe.Maybe v') -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v' -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v'

values.name: base
values.comment:
Create a new knowledge base. This takes an address which accepts knowledge base deltas in sequence.
Currently, you are responsible for dropping irrelevant deltas.
values.type: Signal.Address (Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBaseDelta euser comparable v) -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v

values.name: baseAt
values.comment: Get the knowledge at a given key from the knowledge base.
values.type: comparable -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: baseDeltaMap
values.comment:
Transform a knowledge base delta using any knowledge primitive that does not change the knowledge
type. This is the meat and potatoes of KnowledgeBase. This can be used for operations and any of the
reductions.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBaseDelta euser comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBaseDelta euser comparable v

values.name: baseDeltaTherefore
values.comment:
Transform a knowledge base delta using `therefore`. This is very useful for mapping a signal of
deltas on to multiple knowledge types, then maintaining several synchronized knowledge bases very
efficiently.
values.type: (v -> v') -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBaseDelta euser comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBaseDelta euser comparable v'

values.name: baseDo
values.comment: Use one of the many knowledge manipulation primitives on the knowledge at a particular location in a knowledge base.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> comparable -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v

values.name: baseErrorHandler
values.comment:
Add an error handler to a knowledge base to replace the default error handler. The default error
handler simply promotes errors to undecidedKnowledge. You may way to give a definition in your own
error handler that distinguishes between undecidedKnowledge and forbiddenKnowledge. No promotion to
forbiddenKnowledge is given by default because there is not sane default behavior that covers
the general case.
values.type: (Gigan.Error.Error euser -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v

values.name: baseIntegrate
values.comment:
Transform all new operations in to `pendingKnowledge` across the knowledge base. Note that this
will only traverse the knowledge which has changed since the last call to `baseIntegrate`, so this
scales quite well to large knowledge bases.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v

values.name: baseMember
values.comment: Determine if there is some knowledge at a given key that is not unknown.
values.type: comparable -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v -> Bool

values.name: baseQuery
values.comment:
For every new operation in the knowledge base, get and aggregate the remote tasks, producing
Just an opaque query task or Nothing in the case that no operations need to be done. Note that this
will only traverse the knowledge which has changed since the last call to `baseIntegrate`, so this
scales quite well to large knowledge bases.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Knowledge.QueryTask never)

values.name: baseUpdate
values.comment:
Apply a knowledge base delta to the knowledge base. You are responsible for determining the order
of the updates.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBaseDelta euser comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v

values.name: decideBy
values.comment:
Offer a decision on some `undecidedKnowledge kb`. Undecided knowledge is the result of some
problem which may or may not be in control of the client. Such knowledge may be the result of
anything that can result in an error in your application. If this knowledge is an operation, then
the assumption will be applied to the result of that operation.
values.type: (Gigan.Error.Error euser -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: dispatchIf
values.comment:
If some predicate `satisfies` is satisfied by the knowledge `kb`, then we make the following
remote operation.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Bool) -> Gigan.Knowledge.Remote euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: dispatchIfNot
values.comment: Negation of dispatchIf
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Bool) -> Gigan.Knowledge.Remote euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: dispatchInCase
values.comment:
If `possibleOperation` yields some Remote task `remote` when a Knowledge is applied, then
the knowledge is replaced by the knowledge `doOperation remote`, otherwise the knowledge is
unaffected. If this knowledge is an operation, then the result of that operation will be used as
the input to the provided function. In this way, operations can be chained arbitrarily deep,
but in a manner that helpfully abstracts away whether we are still waiting or already have the
result in the composition.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Knowledge.Remote euser v)) -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: dispatchInCaseNow
values.comment:
This is the counterpart to dispatchInCase which does _not_ abstract away whether or not this is
some pending remote operation. This is useful in the case that we don't care what's going on right
now. We'd rather issue some operation, regardless.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Knowledge.Remote euser v)) -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: doOperation
values.comment:
Define knowledge contingent on the future completion of some arbitrary operation. This is how
we hook up knowledge bases to sources of content.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.Remote euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: forbiddenKnowledge
values.comment:
The knowledge could not be obtained because the user of your program should not be allowed to
access it. This carries an error. To resolve `undecidedKnowledge`, one should use assumptions and or
operations to map it back in to sensible knowledge.

values.name: isForbidden
values.comment: True if the knowledge is forbiddenKnowledge.

values.name: isKnown
values.comment: True if the knowledge is known.

values.name: isNil
values.comment: True if the knowledge is unknownKnowledge or voidKnowledge.

values.name: isNotForbidden
values.comment: False if the knowledge is forbiddenKnowledge.

values.name: isNotKnown
values.comment: False if the knowledge is known.

values.name: isNotNil
values.comment: False if the knowledge is unknownKnowledge or voidKnowledge.

values.name: isNotOperation
values.comment: False if the knowledge is a pending operation.

values.name: isNotPending
values.comment: False if the knowledge is pendingKnowledge.

values.name: isNotUndecided
values.comment: False if the knowledge is undecidedKnowledge.

values.name: isNotUnknown
values.comment: False if the knowledge is unknownKnowledge.

values.name: isNotVoid
values.comment: False if the knowledge is voidKnowledge.

values.name: isOperation
values.comment: True if the knowledge is a pending operation.

values.name: isPending
values.comment: True if the knowledge is pendingKnowledge.

values.name: isUndecided
values.comment: True if the knowledge is undecidedKnowledge.

values.name: isUnknown
values.comment: True if the knowledge is unknownKnowledge.

values.name: isVoid
values.comment: True if the knowledge is voidKnowledge.

values.name: knowledgeDo
values.comment:
Do something to a knowledge. There is an ignored comparable argument here. This merely exists so
that the form of `knowledgeDo` is isomorphic to the form of `baseDo` and `recordDo`.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> comparable -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: knowledgeIntegrate
values.comment:
Given some configuration and a knowledge, produce a pendingKnowledge in the case that the
knowledge is an operation, otherwise give the same knowledge.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.RemoteConfig euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: knowledgeOf
values.comment:
A known thing. Carries a value of type `v` for `Knowledge euser v`. `knowledgeOf` anything can be
interpreted using `therefore` contingent upon it being a concrete `knowledgeOf` something. As described
elsewhere, `therefore` has no effect on knowledge that satisfies `isNotKnown`.

values.name: knowledgeQuery
values.comment:
Given some configuration and a knowledge, produce Just an opaque query task or Nothing
when the knowledge is an operation or the knowledge is not an operation respectively.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.RemoteConfig euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Knowledge.QueryTask never)

values.name: knowledgeUpdate
values.comment:
Update knowledge with an incoming delta. Again, we ignore the comparable component of the
knowledge base delta, but accept it to simplify the types.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBaseDelta euser comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: maybeKnownNow
values.comment: If a knowledge is known, then give Just it's value, otherwise Nothing.

values.name: maybeOr
values.comment:
Map Maybe in to Knowledge. Since Maybe doesn't carry errors, semantically Nothing means
"definitely nothing". For this reason, you may want to use it something like this:

    maybeOr voidKnowledge myPossibleThing

If you implement an operation that uses some existing code that returns a Maybe, that would be a
good place to use this. Just be mindful that this _does not give you the power to handle errors_.
Result should always be preferred in the case that there is any chance of things going wrong, and
`resultOr` should definitely see a lot more mileage in a production app that deals with lots of
unpredictable data.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Maybe.Maybe v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: otherwise
values.comment: Preferred shorthand for `reduceNotKnownNowTo`.

values.name: pendingKnowledge
values.comment:
Something on which knowledge is still pending. The most conforming way to use this is to not
use it directly. Calling *Integrate should be done after every update sequence during staging, which
results in all operations in a knowledge base being replaced with pendingKnowledge. If you stick to
this, the presence of pendingKnowledge is a guarantee you'll be getting a delta back about it
assuming your wiring's not broken.

values.name: record
values.comment:
Create a knowledge record stub. The content of the knowledge base will be bound to the content
of the record according to the `recordField` definitions you give. A knowledge record stub is not
yet completed with a concrete userrecord. Use this in your definitions. Create instances of your
knowledge record type by using `recordSet` on the result of `record`.
values.type: Signal.Address (Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBaseDelta euser comparable v) -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecordStub euser userrecord comparable v

values.name: recordAt
values.comment:
Retrieve a knowledge from the knowledge record using some getter. Avoiding stringly-typed nonsense that you can't protect from
runtime errors is generally a good idea. Since records have an enumerable set of contant field names, it makes more sense to use
this method to get from records. This won't compile if it's wrong. For example:

    recordAt .myFieldThatWillNotCompileIfItDoesntExist myRecord
values.type: (userrecord -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: recordAtKey
values.comment:
Retrieve a knowledge at the given key. If you do this, you may as well be using knowledge base.
However, you will get the benefit of console debug messages in the case that you try to access a
field that doesn't exist.
values.type: comparable -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: recordBinding
values.comment: Get the underlying knowledge base of a knowledge record.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v

values.name: recordContent
values.comment: Get the current userrecord content of a knowledge record.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v -> userrecord

values.name: recordDo
values.comment:
This is the knowledge record equivalent to baseDo for knowledge bases, using the same
semantics.
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> comparable -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v

values.name: recordErrorHandler
values.comment:
Add an error handler to a `KnowledgeRecord` or a `KnowledgeRecordStub`. Refer to
`baseErrorHandler` for a more detailed description of how adding error handlers works.
values.type: (Gigan.Error.Error euser -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> { k | kbase : Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v } -> { k | kbase : Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v }

values.name: recordField
values.comment:
Map a record field to a key in the knowledge base. The types in the record can be any odd combination
given that the userrecord type can be anything. However, all fields in the record must have a mapping to
and from some knowledge type which can represent any of the fields. This is not as tricky as one might
initially surmise. Your userrecord type should have a corresponding tag union type with a tag for each
record field. To make this clean, you should have a bijection between the record fields and the tags. Here's
an example:

    type Fields = FooField Int | BarField String

    type alias MyRecord =
      { foo : Int
      , bar : String
      }

    myRecordFields =
      recordField (\k r -> { r | foo = k }) (.foo >> FooField) "foo"
      >> recordField (\k r -> { r | bar = k }) (.bar >> BarField) "bar"

    .....

    myKnowledgeRecord =
      record address { foo = 42, bar = "answer" } |> myRecordFields
values.type: (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> userrecord -> userrecord) -> (userrecord -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> comparable -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v

values.name: recordIntegrate
values.comment:
This is the knowledge record equivalent to baseIntegrate for knowledge bases, using the same
semantics.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v

values.name: recordQuery
values.comment:
This is the knowledge record equivalent to baseQuery for knowledge bases, using the same
semantics.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Knowledge.QueryTask never)

values.name: recordSet
values.comment:
Completely replace the userrecord instance contained in a knowledge record or fill out a
knowledge record stub for the first time. The second usage is likely to be more common.
values.type: userrecord -> { k | kbase : Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBase euser comparable v, writes : Dict.Dict comparable (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> userrecord -> userrecord), reads : Dict.Dict comparable (userrecord -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) } -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v

values.name: recordUpdate
values.comment:
This is the knowledge record equivalent to baseUpdate for knowledge bases, using the same
semantics.
values.type: Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeBaseDelta euser comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v -> Gigan.Knowledge.KnowledgeRecord euser userrecord comparable v

values.name: reduceNotKnownNowTo
values.comment:
This is the special reduction we use to collapse away the Knowledge type, determining a final
value to work with. While more pedantically named, I find it leaves something to be desired
aesthetically, so I use `otherwise` for the same task.

values.name: remoteConfig
values.comment:
Specifies a RemoteConfig with which to close off a remote operation by sending it's results or an
error describing it's failure to the given address.
values.type: Signal.Address (Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> Gigan.Knowledge.RemoteConfig euser v

values.name: remoteErrorConfig
values.comment:
Adds an optional special error handler for resolving totally unexpected errors. A final error
handler should be provided such that any errors not trapped by a decideBy application still
gracefully recover. By default, a valid knowledge is produced from any error by promoting that
Error to Undecided.
values.type: (Gigan.Error.Error euser -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> Gigan.Knowledge.RemoteConfig euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.RemoteConfig euser v

values.name: resultOr
values.comment:
Map Result in to Knowledge. You'll need this if you want to roll your own knowledge base remotes,
which is quite easy to do due to the pluggability of the knowledge module. The function specifies how
to interpret errors. This is important in the case that you have to deal with permissions systems.
Some of your errors might be due to access denial, others might be due to unintentional errors. Use
forbiddenKnowledge and undecidedKnowledge respectively for these cases.
values.type: (Gigan.Error.Error euser -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v) -> Result.Result (Gigan.Error.Error euser) v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v

values.name: therefore
values.comment:
transform the value itself, if known, producing a knowledge of some new value type value'.
therefores are composed on to the results of remote operations if they represent known knowledge or
further operations to attempt. This allows us to compose async processing stages before knowledge
is finally reduced to a displayed or usable result as deeply and interchangably as we want to,
provided that we always use "therefore" _first_ to lift the knowledge type out before listing
a sequence of simple or contingent reductions.
values.type: (v -> v') -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser v'

values.name: undecidedKnowledge
values.comment:
The knowledge could not be obtained because something went wrong. This carries an error. To
resolve `undecidedKnowledge`, one should use assumptions and or operations to map it back in to
sensible knowledge.

values.name: unknownKnowledge
values.comment:
Somthing that's totally unknown. This is the default result of retrieving an element that has
no representation in a knowledge base, but also has obvious other uses as a placeholder that is
typely more powerful than Result or Maybe for production data management.

values.name: voidKnowledge
values.comment:
Something that is _known not to exist_. This is not the same as unknownKnowledge or
undecidedKnowledge. Void knowledge should arise from a remote operation which verified that there
is definitely nothing there, so it is not an assumption.

values.name: within
values.comment:
This is for nesting operations on knowledge bases. For example:

    -- this'll write something at the patch foo.bar if "bar" is void.
    baseDo (within <| baseDo (inquireIf isVoid myBarWriter) "bar") "foo" myBase

This code will work on a knowledge base of base knowledges, so that's a nested record. The active
record pattern can be approximated like this, and I've found it extremely handy.
values.type: (sub -> sub) -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser sub -> Gigan.Knowledge.Knowledge euser sub

docs.name: Gigan.Stem

aliases.name: Stem
aliases.comment:
A Stem is an instantaneous description of some model associated with an OrbiterInput (see Core)
that specifies how it should be updated, staged and presented.
aliases.type: { input : Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad , state : Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad }

values.name: maybeStemDispatch
values.type: Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Maybe.Maybe ( Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad, Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a )

values.name: maybeStemDispatchAs
values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Maybe.Maybe ( Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad, Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a' )

values.name: maybeStemDispatchment
values.type: Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a

values.name: maybeStemDispatchmentAs
values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a'

values.name: maybeStemIntegrate
values.type: Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad)

values.name: maybeStemModel
values.type: Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Maybe.Maybe b

values.name: maybeStemPresent
values.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Core.ViewOutput a c bad)

values.name: maybeStemPresentAs
values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Signal.Address (List a') -> Time.Time -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Core.ViewOutput a' c bad)

values.name: maybeStemReplaceModel
values.type: b -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad)

values.name: maybeStemStage
values.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad)

values.name: maybeStemStageAs
values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Signal.Address (List a') -> Time.Time -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad)

values.name: maybeStemUpdate
values.type: List a -> Time.Time -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad) -> Maybe.Maybe (Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad)

values.name: stem
values.comment: Create a stem from an OrbiterInput
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad

values.name: stemDispatch
values.comment:
Dispatch the tasks of a Stem. This function is in the depreciated family of `stemDispatch*`
functions. Use `stemDispatchment*` and `stemIntegrate` instead.
values.type: Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> ( Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad, Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a )

values.name: stemDispatchAs
values.comment:
Dispatch the tasks of a Stem using some transducer to translate the action list. This function
is in the depreciated family of `stemDispatch*` functions. Use `stemDispatchment*` and
`stemIntegrate` instead.
values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> ( Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad, Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a' )

values.name: stemDispatchment
values.comment: Get the currently waiting dispatchment.
values.type: Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a

values.name: stemDispatchmentAs
values.comment: Get the currently waiting task dispatchment, but apply some action type transformation.
values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a'

values.name: stemIntegrate
values.comment:
Remove the currently waiting task dispatchment. This should be done only after retrieving any
possibly waiting dispatchment.
values.type: Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad

values.name: stemModel
values.comment: Get the model of a stem.
values.type: Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> b

values.name: stemPresent
values.comment:
Run the present function from the configured OrbiterInput of the Stem on the Stem's current model to produce a ViewOutput, which includes the an element of the Stem's view type, and a TaskDispatchment for any desired asynchronous tasks.
This takes an address for actions to be sent to, the current time, and the Stem.
values.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.ViewOutput a c bad

values.name: stemPresentAs
values.comment: Same as stemPresent, but with a transformation to apply to action lists before they are sent to the address.
values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Signal.Address (List a') -> Time.Time -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.ViewOutput a' c bad

values.name: stemReplaceModel
values.comment: Create a stem with a different model from a replacement model and an original stem.
values.type: b -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad

values.name: stemStage
values.comment:
Run the update function from the configured OrbiterInput of the Stem on the Stem's current model to produce a new model and dispatch any asynchronous tasks desired.
This takes an address for actions to be sent to, the current time, and the Stem.
values.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad

values.name: stemStageAs
values.comment: Same as stemStage, but with a transformation to apply to action lists before they are sent to the address.
values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Signal.Address (List a') -> Time.Time -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad

values.name: stemUpdate
values.comment:
Run the update function from the configured OrbiterInput of the Stem on the Stem's current model to produce a new model and dispatch any asynchronous tasks desired.
This takes a list of actions, the current time, and the Stem.
values.type: List a -> Time.Time -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad -> Gigan.Stem.Stem a b c bad

docs.name: Gigan.Error

aliases.name: DecodingFailure
aliases.comment: Represents a decoding task which failed.

aliases.name: Error
aliases.comment: Error record.

types.name: ErrorType
types.comment: Type of error that occurred in Gigan.

values.name: decoderError
values.comment: Report a problem decoding something.

values.name: decoderErrorAndLog
values.comment: decoderError and log to console.

values.name: decodingFailure
values.comment:
Given the source string on which decoding was attempted and the reason for the failure,
give a DecodingFailure

values.name: reportError
values.comment:
Report an error. Given an ErrorType and a String describing what went wrong humanly, create
an error record.

values.name: reportErrorAndLog
values.comment: reportError and log to console.

values.name: unknownError
values.comment: Report an error, the nature of which is not known.

values.name: unknownErrorAndLog
values.comment: unknownError and log to console.

values.name: userError
values.comment: Report a user defined error.

values.name: userErrorAndLog
values.comment: userError and log to console.

docs.name: Gigan.Core
docs.comment:
The main application scaffolding. You can write a really pretty top level like this:

    myOrbiter : OrbiterOutput MyAction MyModel Layout.Item Error
    myOrbiter =
      myProgram
        `withSequenceInputs`
          [ someVeryImportantBrowserEnvironmentInput
          , someOtherOutsideSignal
          ]
        `orbitsWithWork`
          (computeTask doMyComplicatedStartupWork withThisData)
      +--> (it'sErrorTap myErrorHandler)
      +--> itself


    main : Signal Graphics.Element.Element
    main = Layout.fromItem <~ myOrbiter.view'


    port sink : Signal (Task z ())
    port sink = sieve myOrbiter


# Definitions
@docs AgentStatus, ComputedResult, ComputedSuccess, OrbiterInput, OrbiterOutput, OrbiterSnapshot, OrbiterTap, OrbiterTask, TaskDispatchment, UpdatedModel, ViewOutput

# Define Orbiter Programs
@docs defProgram, defProgram'

# Run Orbiter Programs
@docs orbits, orbitsWithWork, withInputs, withLazySequenceInputs, withSequenceInputs, sieve, (+-->)

# UpdatedModel and ViewOutput Manipulation
@docs updated, presented, withTasks, withDispatchment, withChildren, viewOutputTask

# Dispatch Actions and Errors
@docs actionTask, actionTaskAsync, errorTask, computeTask, computedSuccess, computedSuccessAsync, noActions, nilTask

# Intercept and Route Action and Error Outputs
@docs itself, itselfAsync, it'sErrorTap, thisAddress, thisAddressAsync, thisForwardAddress, thisForwardAddressAsync, thisErrorTap, thisForwardTap, thisTap

# Handling Tasks and TaskDispatchment
@docs combineDispatchments, collapseTasks, dispatchTasks, dispatchmentHasWork, dispatchmentTask, promoteDispatchment

# Manipulate Orbiter Snapshots
@docs orbiterSnapshot, orbiterSnapshotAddDispatchment, orbiterSnapshotDispatch, orbiterSnapshotPresent, orbiterSnapshotStage, orbiterSnapshotUpdate, performCycle

# Orbiter Task Agents
@docs orbiterAgentSuccess, orbiterAgentFailure, orbiterAgent, orbiterSuccessAgent, orbiterFailureAgent, orbiterBinaryAgent, orbiterBlindAgent, orbiterNilAgent, orbiterResultAgent, ignoreError

aliases.name: ComputedResult
aliases.comment:
A ComputedResult is a Result which may be a ComputedSuccess or some error type on failure. This
is used as the output type of the function passed to a `computeTask`.

aliases.name: ComputedSuccess
aliases.comment:
This is the success type of an OrbiterTask. It consists of a sequence of actions to execute, and
a tag saying whether we want the actions executed all at once, or spread out asynchronously. This
should be treated as opaque; use the constructors `computedSuccess` and `computedSuccessAsync`.

aliases.name: OrbiterInput
aliases.comment:
This is the input type for Orbiter. It can be seen as roughly analogous to StartApp's Config
type, but carries the full configuration and input in one. This should be considered opaque.
aliases.type: { inputs : Lazy.List.LazyList (Signal.Signal (Lazy.List.LazyList a)) , model0 : b , present : Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.ViewOutput a c bad , stage : Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.UpdatedModel a b bad , update : a -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.UpdatedModel a b bad }

aliases.name: OrbiterOutput
aliases.comment:
This is the output of an Orbiter program. This is not intended to be opaque. Any part of the
output structure is up for grabs. I do not reccomend usage of the lazyAddress externally.

    view'     Signal with the current view.
    model'    Signal with the current model.
    now       Signal with the most recent execution time.
    actions   Signal with the most recently atomically executed action list.
    tasks     Signal with the most recent OrbiterTask output.
    address   The address of the Orbiter program's Mailbox.
aliases.type: { view' : Signal.Signal c , model' : Signal.Signal b , now : Signal.Signal Time.Time , actions : Signal.Signal (List a) , tasks : Signal.Signal (Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a) , address : Signal.Address (List a) , lazyAddress : Signal.Address (Lazy.List.LazyList a) }

aliases.name: OrbiterSnapshot
aliases.comment:
This represents an instantaneous description of an Orbiter program. It consists of the current
model and a possible TaskDispatchment. This should be treated as opaque.
aliases.type: { model' : b, dispatchment : Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a }

aliases.name: OrbiterTap
aliases.comment:
OrbiterTap is an alias for functions that transform OrbiterTasks by routing their actions to
an address. You will probably not need to directly provide an OrbiterTap function, as the built in
family of taps should be sufficient for just about any application.
aliases.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

aliases.name: OrbiterTask
aliases.comment: A task with a ComputedSuccess result. These are used as the output task type of the Orbiter.

aliases.name: TaskDispatchment
aliases.comment:
This is an opaque type representing an ordered list of tasks to execute. This is quite similar
to Effects batching.

aliases.name: UpdatedModel
aliases.comment:
Represents the output of the `update` and `stage` functions configured in the OrbiterInput.
This type exists so that TaskDispatchments and OrbiterTasks can be cleanly included in the output
of `stage` and `update` without the need to return an ugly pair or embed anything in the model.
aliases.type: { dispatchment : Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a, model' : b }

aliases.name: ViewOutput
aliases.comment:
Represents the output of the `present` function configured in the OrbiterInput.
This type exists so that TaskDispatchments and OrbiterTasks can be cleanly included in the output
of `present` without the need to return an ugly pair or embed anything in the model.
aliases.type: { dispatchment : Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a, view' : c }

types.name: AgentStatus
types.comment:
Represents the status of a given OrbiterAgent. Orbiter agents are a way of transforming the
results of arbitrary tasks in to actions and errors for the program to consume.

values.comment:
While it may be a case of "your stupid infix operator", I think it makes writing taps nicer
simply because I see `+---> itself` and I think "oh, it has an edge going to itself". This is one
of those instances where the abstraction can actually help with comprehension because it acually looks
like a directed graph edge. See the main example for usage. _NOTE: you can use (|>) to be more
standard._
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> (Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: actionTask
values.comment:
An OrbiterTask that carries a list of actions to execute atomically.

Note that a tap which is explicitly from the `*Async` family of taps will override this behavior,
instead producing the same behavior as actionTaskAsync. For that reason, asynchronous taps should
mainly be used for one-way data flows that are not dependent on ordering.

values.name: actionTaskAsync
values.comment:
An OrbiterTask that carries a list of actions to execute asynchronously, meaning they may be
interspersed with other feedback and inputs.

values.name: collapseTasks
values.comment:
Collapse two action tasks by executing them sequentially and appending their resulting action
outputs.
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: combineDispatchments
values.comment:
Combine two TaskDispatchment instances. This appends the task list of the second to the task
list of the first.
values.type: Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a

values.name: computeTask
values.comment:
An OrbiterTask that obtains some ComputedResult from user provided data and a user provided
function, which is invoked during execution of the task. This just gives us basic support for
deferred computations.
values.type: (data -> Gigan.Core.ComputedResult bad a) -> data -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: computedSuccess
values.comment:
Produce a normal ComputedSuccess from a list of actions. These actions will be sent all at once,
and thus will be executed atomically.

values.name: computedSuccessAsync
values.comment:
Produce an asynchronous ComputedSuccess from a list of actions. These actions will be sent
one by one from sequential tasks, and thus their execution will be spread out with no guarantee that
the sequence of actions will be executed atomically.

If you need to run a list of a few thousand actions,
and it is safe for those actions to be interspersed with other actions, you may be looking at a very
good use case for this function. Note also that this will never preempt an action list that is sent
at once using `computeSuccess`, which is a product of how the Elm runtime works.

values.name: defProgram
values.comment:
defProgram is the old declaration form for defining OrbiterInput. It is simpler, and does not
support the `stage` function. Internally this uses the new form, but it has been left in for
two reasons. One is of course backwards compatibility, but sometimes you just don't need that
extra firepower, in which case it is mere clutter.
values.type: (Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.ViewOutput a c bad) -> (a -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.UpdatedModel a b bad) -> b -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad

values.name: defProgram'
values.comment:
defProgram' is the complete way to define an OrbiterInput. OrbiterInput is configured with
three functions. `update` and `present` should be familiar to users of StartApp, except for the
fact that they always have the current time. `stage` is a special addition which allows one to
use the program Mailbox address from a context in which the model can be updated.

The use case for `stage` which inspired it's existence is as follows: suppose you have a really
big model with a really, really big view. There is enough data that keen algorithms and data
structures, as well as avoiding redundant computations during presentation becomes a neccessity.

You can then structure your application as follows. Represent all these components as instances of
Stem. From inside `stage`, you can present _only the ones that will or should actually be seen_,
and cache the results in the model. Since you can create an updated model from here, you can save
anything that may be later needed during presentation.

`stage` is called only once after an entire list of actions is executed. If you get a list of 1000
actions, you can still guarantee the work in stage will be done only once, before presentation.
_The primary reason stage has access to the address is because it enables you to call present on
any sub components ahead of time for caching purposes._
values.type: (Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.ViewOutput a c bad) -> (Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.UpdatedModel a b bad) -> (a -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.UpdatedModel a b bad) -> b -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad

values.name: dispatchTasks
values.comment: Turn a list of OrbiterTasks in to a TaskDispatchment.
values.type: List (Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a) -> Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a

values.name: dispatchmentHasWork
values.comment: True iff the TaskDispatchment has at least one OrbiterTask.

values.name: dispatchmentTask
values.comment:
Turn a TaskDispatchment in to an OrbiterTask. Doing this will make things a lot more opaque,
so ask yourself if it is absolutely neccessary first. Mainly this is included for completeness.
values.type: Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: errorTask
values.comment: An OrbiterTask that carries an error.

values.name: ignoreError
values.comment: This makes any error in to noActions.

values.name: it'sErrorTap
values.comment: Same semantics as `itself`, but for errors. Error taps do not have an asynchronous alternative.
values.type: (bad -> List a) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: itself
values.comment: This is the most essential tap for almost any application. It routes the actions resulting from your TaskDispatchment output back to the program's main address.
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: itselfAsync
values.comment: Same as itself, but execute action lists asynchronously, such that they may be interspersed with other action lists.
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: nilTask
values.comment: An OrbiterTask that does nothing and produces noActions.

values.name: noActions
values.comment: A list of no actions.

values.name: orbiterAgent
values.comment:
The basic orbiter agent. Takes two functions, one of which transforms a successful result in to
an AgentStatus, and one which does the same for task failure results. This transforms an arbitrary
task in to an OrbiterTask. Notice that we can easily succeed anyway even if the task failed, or vice
versa, because we get an AgentStatus which may be successful or failing either way. This means you
can skip error handling altogether if you already know what to do with the failure from the scope
you're in; you can simply map the failure on to some actions that perform an appropriate
contingency.
values.type: (x -> Gigan.Core.AgentStatus bad a) -> (y -> Gigan.Core.AgentStatus bad a) -> Task.Task y x -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: orbiterAgentFailure
values.comment: Failed OrbiterAgent output.

values.name: orbiterAgentSuccess
values.comment: Successful OrbiterAgent output.

values.name: orbiterBinaryAgent
values.comment:
A binary orbiter agent. This does not process any of the results, but simply always gives the
succesful AgentStatus (the first one) on task success, otherwise it gives the failed AgentStatus.
values.type: Gigan.Core.AgentStatus bad a -> Gigan.Core.AgentStatus bad a -> Task.Task y x -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: orbiterBlindAgent
values.comment:
If we don't care about the outcome of a task because it can't fail or produce a meaningful
result, we can just queue up something to do after it's done. This is perfect for using delay tasks.
values.type: Gigan.Core.AgentStatus bad a -> Task.Task y x -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: orbiterFailureAgent
values.comment:
This is a combination of orbiterAgent and orbiterBinary agent which gives the successful agent
status in the case of success, and processes failed results to get an AgentStatus otherwise .
values.type: Gigan.Core.AgentStatus bad a -> (y -> Gigan.Core.AgentStatus bad a) -> Task.Task y x -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: orbiterNilAgent
values.comment:
No matter what, do nothing. This will get your task to run, but no kind of action or error
feedback will be produced.
values.type: Task.Task y x -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: orbiterResultAgent
values.comment:
The other orbiter agents defined so far are less succinct because they take two arguments, one
which applies to the success case and one which applies to the failure case. This one takes a single
function which processes the task's outcome as a Result, and so is generally a bit shorter to write.
values.type: (Result.Result y x -> Gigan.Core.AgentStatus bad a) -> Task.Task y x -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: orbiterSnapshot
values.comment: Constructor for an OrbiterSnapshot. I reccomend using the Stem module instead of these functions.
values.type: b -> Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad

values.name: orbiterSnapshotAddDispatchment
values.comment: Add a dispatchment to an OrbiterSnapshot.
values.type: Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad

values.name: orbiterSnapshotDispatch
values.comment:
Get the pending TaskDispatchment out of an OrbiterSnapshot and clear it from the snapshot in
one go. This gives an _ugly pair_. See the newer interface for this in Stem, and also see the way
Knowledge works. It seems much better to separate this in to two stages. It leaves room for a mistake,
which I was trying to avoid, but it's so much cleaner than way that it's worth it and actually
leads to fewer mistakes as a result.
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad -> ( Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad , Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a )

values.name: orbiterSnapshotPresent
values.comment: Run the `present` phase on an OrbiterSnapshot, yielding a ViewOutput.
values.type: { k | present : Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.ViewOutput a c bad } -> Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad -> Gigan.Core.ViewOutput a c bad

values.name: orbiterSnapshotStage
values.comment: Run the `stage` phase on an OrbiterSnapshot.
values.type: { k | stage : Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.UpdatedModel a b bad } -> Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad

values.name: orbiterSnapshotUpdate
values.comment: Run the `update` phase on an OrbiterSnapshot.
values.type: { k | update : a -> Time.Time -> b -> Gigan.Core.UpdatedModel a b bad } -> List a -> Time.Time -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad

values.name: orbiterSuccessAgent
values.comment:
This is a combination of orbiterAgent and orbiterBinary agent which processes successful results
to get an AgentStatus, otherwise giving the failed agent status.
values.type: (x -> Gigan.Core.AgentStatus bad a) -> Gigan.Core.AgentStatus bad a -> Task.Task y x -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: orbits
values.comment:
Run an orbiter without any startup task.

    orbits (myProgram `withSequenceInputs` [myInput, myInput2])
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: orbitsWithWork
values.comment:
This is the workhorse of Gigan.Core. Given an OrbiterInput and some starting OrbiterTask,
run the Orbiter program described by the input to give an OrbiterOutput.
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: performCycle
values.comment:
Perform a full cycle on an OrbiterSnapshot. This looks like:

      state
      |> orbiterSnapshotUpdate input actions now
      |> orbiterSnapshotStage input address now
      |> orbiterSnapshotDispatch

internally. The point of performCycle is to be used in foldp, which it is inside orbitsWithWork
and orbits (which really just calls orbitsWithWork with nilTask).
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad -> Signal.Address (List a) -> ( Time.Time, List a ) -> ( Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad , Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a ) -> ( Gigan.Core.OrbiterSnapshot a b bad , Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a )

values.name: presented
values.comment: Give a ViewOutput from your view type, carrying an empty TaskDispatchment.

values.name: promoteDispatchment
values.comment: Using some transformation function, create a TaskDispatchment with a different action type.
values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a'

values.name: sieve
values.comment:
The sieve is the final stop for OrbiterOutput. This should be attached at a port to get your
tasks running.
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Signal.Signal (Task.Task z ())

values.name: thisAddress
values.comment: Route the resulting actions from your TaskDispatchments to some action list address.
values.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisAddressAsync
values.comment: Same as thisAddress, but asynchronously as described above.
values.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisErrorTap
values.comment: Transform any errors in to lists of actions, then route them to the address.
values.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> (bad -> List a) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisForwardAddress
values.comment: Same as thisAddress, but with forwarding.
values.type: Signal.Address target -> (List a -> target) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisForwardAddressAsync
values.comment: Same as thisForwardAddress, but asynchronously as described above.
values.type: Signal.Address target -> (List a -> target) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisForwardTap
values.comment:
Same as thisTap but uses Address forwarding to transform action lists in to some other target type
for your address.
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterTap bad a -> Signal.Address target -> (List a -> target) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisTap
values.comment:
A tap defined using an OrbiterTap and some address. The OrbiterTasks that pass through this tap will be
routed to the given address. This is a bit lower level than is needed in most cases.
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterTap bad a -> Signal.Address (List a) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterOutput a b c bad

values.name: updated
values.comment: Give an UpdatedModel from a model, carrying an empty TaskDispatchment.

values.name: viewOutputTask
values.comment:
Get an OrbiterTask from a ViewOutput. This is DEPRECIATED. Use TaskDispatchment wherever
possible.
values.type: Gigan.Core.ViewOutput a c bad -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a

values.name: withChildren
values.comment:
This takes a list of UpdatedModel or ViewOutput instances, and appends each one to the
TaskDispatchment of the current output. This is preferred when doing model composition with Stem.
For example:

    staged { collectionModel | memberViews = memberOutputs } `withChildren` memberOutputs

where memberOutputs is a list of stemPresent or stemPresentAs outputs in the example.
values.type: List { anything | dispatchment : Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a } -> { anything | dispatchment : Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a } -> { anything | dispatchment : Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a }

values.name: withDispatchment
values.comment: This is the same as `withTasks`, but it takes an already existing TaskDispatchment.
values.type: Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a -> { anything | dispatchment : Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a } -> { anything | dispatchment : Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a }

values.name: withInputs
values.comment:
withInputs is the oldest way in Gigan of using action inputs, from before we started using
lists of actions. Lists of actions are much more powerful because not only can they be used to
make sure sequences of actions run atomically, but it also gives us an obvious and tagless way to
represent noop. Here's how it looked:

    defProgram myPresent myUpdate myModel0 `withInputs` [actionSignal0, actionSignal1]

This is DEPRECIATED.
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad -> List (Signal.Signal a) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad

values.name: withLazySequenceInputs
values.comment:
Since action lists are internally combined using lazy lists, one may want to just hand over their
LazyList without converting it to a list. This may sometimes be appropriate, but beware of unbounded
laziness. Profiling is your friend here.
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad -> List (Signal.Signal (Lazy.List.LazyList a)) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad

values.name: withSequenceInputs
values.comment:
withSequenceInputs is the preferred way of piping outside sources of actions in to an orbiter
program. You'll notice from the way this is used that OrbiterInput definitions made by defProgram'
or defProgram refrain from including any inputs right away. The reason for this is that a program
and the _source_ of it's input are two distinctly separate concerns, though the _content_ of it's
input is not. In Stem, the inputs of an OrbiterInput are not used. This way, OrbiterInput is also
usable for defining Stem state machines as well as Orbiter programs.

    defProgram' myPresent myStage myUpdate myModel0 `withSequenceInputs` [actionListSignal0, actionListSignal1]
values.type: Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad -> List (Signal.Signal (List a)) -> Gigan.Core.OrbiterInput a b c bad

values.name: withTasks
values.comment:
Add some tasks to the output of any of the three Orbiter functions.

    updated model `withTasks` [actionTask [Jump, Run]]
    presented viewstuff `withTasks` [errorTask [reportError "You done goofed."]]

This is definitely the most elegant way to build a TaskDispatchment as well, especially in the
context of declaring causality.
values.type: List (Gigan.Core.OrbiterTask bad a) -> { anything | dispatchment : Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a } -> { anything | dispatchment : Gigan.Core.TaskDispatchment bad a }

docs.name: Gigan.Layout

aliases.name: Item
aliases.comment: An item, which represents an Elm Element with a position and a handle.
aliases.type: { elem : Graphics.Element.Element , x : Int , u : Int , y : Int , v : Int }

types.name: Axis
types.comment: An axis along which to evenly distribute by spacing or handle position.

types.name: Bounds
types.comment: A bounding box, given as a minimum and a maximum.

types.name: Group
types.comment: Group is an opaque type that represents a grouped set of items with a pending set of transformations.

types.name: Rule
types.comment: A guide ruler defined as either a vertical or a horizontal axis aligned line.

values.name: adjustedRule
values.comment: Adjust a horizontal or vertical ruler.

values.name: appendGroup
values.comment:
Append two groups, resulting a group containing the elements from `grp` first and the
elements of `grp'` second.

values.name: autoBounds
values.comment: Automatic bounds.

values.name: boundsHeight
values.comment: Get the width of a bounding box, defined as boundsSize >> snd

values.name: boundsLower
values.comment: Get the minimum bound if a minimum bound is defined.

values.name: boundsSize
values.comment: Get the size of a bounding box if both maximum and minimum bounds are defined, otherwise (0, 0).

values.name: boundsUpper
values.comment: Get the maximum bound if a maximum bound is defined.

values.name: boundsWidth
values.comment: Get the width of a bounding box, defined as boundsSize >> fst

values.name: butBefore
values.comment: Apply some transformation to every item in the group before the pending transformations.

values.name: butBeforeAt
values.comment: Apply some transformation to the item at a particular index in the group before the pending transformations.

values.name: butBeforeSlice
values.comment: Apply some transformation to the items in a particular slice of the group before the pending transformations.

values.name: clampedBounds
values.comment:
Clamp a bounding box to some inner bounding box and some outer bounding box. Either the inner
or the outer bounding box may be autoBounds, so this may also only clamp an inner or an outer limit,
or neither.

values.name: clampedInnerBounds
values.comment: clampedInnerBounds myBounds = clampedBounds myBounds autoBounds

values.name: clampedOuterBounds
values.comment: clampedOuterBounds myBounds = clampedBounds autoBounds myBounds

values.name: computed
values.comment:
Run any pending transformations on all group items. For the most part, this can be avoided, but it should be
done if you are planning to get a lot of items back from the group transformed, or else the work of applying the
pending group transforms will be done at least twice, once when you retrieve the item using groupAt and once when
you flatten the group to produce an item.

values.name: defBounds
values.comment: Define a definite bounding box.

values.name: emptyItem
values.comment: An empty layout item.

values.name: flatten
values.comment:
Flatten a group using automatic bounds for the inner and outer bounds. This will produce the
tightest bounding box possible around the target, and place the handle at (0, 0) relative to the resulting
bounding box. This can result in the handle being placed outside of the group, but this can be desirable for
positioning. For example, I may want to grab something at (-5, -5), so I can position it's top left
corner relative to some outer box with (5, 5) padding.

values.name: flattenOutTo
values.comment:
Flatten a group using only an inner bound, which is equivalent to

    flattenWithinOutTo outer autoBounds

values.name: flattenTo
values.comment:
Flatten a group using an exact bound. If this is specified to be autoBounds, then the following
equivalency holds:

    flattenTo autoBounds group == flatten group

Otherwise, the items in the group are positioned in the resulting item relative to the top left corner of the bounds and
the resulting item shall have the exact size of the given bounds.

values.name: flattenWithin
values.comment:
Flatten a group using only an outer bound, which is equivalent to

    flattenWithinOutTo autoBounds outer

values.name: flattenWithinOutTo
values.comment: Flatten a group using an inner and an outer bound to clamp the size of the resulting item.

values.name: fromItem
values.comment:
Get the Graphics Element from an Item. Note that this will get the original Element back,
unaffected by any positioning done using placement and group operations. To produce Graphics
Elements with finished layouts, refer to the flatten functions.

values.name: grabItem
values.comment:
Grab an item, producing a handle. This defines a point on the item called the "handle" that is
placed exactly at item's coordinates. If I say

  grabItem 0 0

then that would grab the top left corner. u and v and given as window coordinates relative to the
top left corner of the item.

values.name: grabItemRelative
values.comment:
Grab an item in normalized coordinates relative to it's size. This means that (1, 1) is the
bottom right corner, and (0, 0) is the top left corner.

values.name: grabItemRelativeX
values.comment: Grab an item by it's x coordinate relative to the item's size.

values.name: grabItemRelativeY
values.comment: Grab an item by it's y coordinate relative to the item's size.

values.name: grabItemX
values.comment: Grab an item by it's x coordinate.

values.name: grabItemY
values.comment: Grab an item by it's y coordinate.

values.name: group
values.comment: Create an item group from a list.

values.name: groupAt
values.comment:
Retrieve the item at a given index in the group, or Nothing if the index is out of bounds. If
there are waiting transformations, a copy of the item with those transformations applied will be
given.

values.name: groupAtBefore
values.comment:
Retrieve the item at a given index in the group, or Nothing if the index is out of bounds. The
item will be retrieved in it's original state without any pending group transformations applied.

values.name: groupElements
values.comment:
This is a shortcut for grouping graphics elements, which is very useful for compositing graphics
elements such as images directly for layering effects.

values.name: groupFromArray
values.comment: Create an item group from an array.

values.name: groupFromDict
values.comment: Create an item group from a dictionary.

values.name: groupSize
values.comment: Get the size of the group.

values.name: horizontalRule
values.comment: Create a new horizontal ruler at the given y coordinate.

values.name: horizontalRuleBetween
values.comment: Shorthand for ruleBetween horizontalRule

values.name: horizontalRuleCentered
values.comment: Shorthand for ruleCenter horizontalRule

values.name: horizontally
values.comment: Do a distribution horizontally.

values.name: itemBounds
values.comment: Get the resultant bounding box of an item, given it's placement and handle.

values.name: itemHeight
values.comment: Get the height of an item.

values.name: itemHorizontalRule
values.comment: Create a horizontal ruler aligned with an item.

values.name: itemRule
values.comment: Create a vertical or a horizontal ruler aligned with an item.

values.name: itemSize
values.comment: Get the size of an Item.

values.name: itemVerticalRule
values.comment: Create a vertical ruler aligned with an item.

values.name: itemWidth
values.comment: Get the width of an item.

values.name: lerpOf
values.comment:
Modify any of the item manipulation primitives by linearly interpolating the handle and coordinates
between the current and output values. This provides the basic building block for transitional animations.
Easing functions could quite easily be implemented on top of this.

values.name: move
values.comment: Move an item.

values.name: moveX
values.comment: Move an item horizontally.

values.name: moveY
values.comment: Move an item vertically.

values.name: place
values.comment: Place the handle of an item at these coordinates.

values.name: placeX
values.comment: Place the handle of an item at this x coordinate.

values.name: placeY
values.comment: Place the handle of an item at this y coordinate.

values.name: prependGroup
values.comment:
Prepend a group before another, resulting a group containing the elements from `grp` second and
the elements of `grp'` first.

values.name: regularly
values.comment:
Distribute the items in the group along some Axis given a starting coordinate and an ending
coordinate, such that the handles of the items are evenly distributed between the starting and the
ending coordinates. The height or width of this vertical or horizontal distribution is dependent on
the positioning of the handles on the items, and the coordinate not effected by the distribution is
left in place.

values.name: ruleBetween
values.comment:
Given a ruler direction (verticalRule or horizontalRule), a lower and an upper bound, and some
float t between 0 and 1, linearly interpolate between the lower and upper bound by t.

values.name: ruleCenter
values.comment:
Given a ruler direction (verticalRule or horizontalRule), a lower bound, and an upper bound,
center a ruler between the lower and the upper bound. The following equivalencies hold:

    ruleCenter verticalRule x0 x1 == ruleBetween verticalRule x0 x1 0.5
    ruleCenter horizontalRule y0 y1 == ruleBetween horizontalRule y0 y1 0.5

values.name: snapToRule
values.comment: Snap an item's handle to a vertical or horizontal ruler.

values.name: spacedBetween
values.comment:
Distribute the items in the group along some Axis given a starting coordinate and an ending
coordinate, such that the spaces between all of the items are even, resulting in a justified layout.
Vertical distribution is done top to bottom, horizontal distribution is done left to right.

The height or width of this vertical or horizontal distribution is

    to - from

and the coordinate not effected by the distribution is left in place.

values.name: spacedBy
values.comment:
Distribute the items in the group along some Axis given a starting coordinate and spacing given
in window coordinates, resulting in an evenly spaced horizontal or vertical distribution. Vertical
distribution is done top to bottom, horizontal distribution is done left to right.

The height or width of this vertical or horizontal distribution is

    from + siz * (n - 1) + (sum itemHeight items)

and the coordinate not effected by the distribution is left in place.

values.name: thenDo
values.comment: Apply some transformation to every item in the group after the pending transformations.

values.name: thenDoAt
values.comment: Apply some transformation to the item at a particular index in the group after the pending transformations.

values.name: thenDoSlice
values.comment: Apply some transformation to the items in a particular slice of the group after the pending transformations.

values.name: toItem
values.comment: Convert a Graphics Element to an Item

values.name: towardsRule
values.comment: Move an item's handle toward a vertical or horizontal ruler by some constant amount.

values.name: towardsRuleRelative
values.comment: Move an item's handle toward a vertical or horizontal ruler by some factor t

values.name: verticalRule
values.comment: Create a new vertical ruler at the given x coordinate.

values.name: verticalRuleBetween
values.comment: Shorthand for ruleBetween verticalRule

values.name: verticalRuleCentered
values.comment: Shorthand for ruleCenter verticalRule

values.name: vertically
values.comment: Do a distribution vertically.
