values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Signal.Address (List a') -> Time.Time -> Scaffold.Machine.Machine a b c bad -> Scaffold.Machine.Machine a b c bad

values.name: updating
values.comment:
Run the update function from the configured ProgramInput of the Machine on the Machine's current model to produce a new model and dispatch any asynchronous tasks desired.
This takes a list of actions, the current time, and the Machine.
values.type: List a -> Time.Time -> Scaffold.Machine.Machine a b c bad -> Scaffold.Machine.Machine a b c bad

docs.name: Scaffold.Resource

aliases.name: ResourcePath
aliases.comment: Used as the resource path type.

aliases.name: ResourceRef
aliases.comment: A reference to a resource, including it's path.
aliases.type: { path : Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath , resource : Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v }

aliases.name: ResourceTask
aliases.comment:
This is a Task which represents some kind of synchronization with optask data. It can also easily
be used for long running arbitrary computations, too. It produces a Gigan Error or a Resource.
aliases.type: Task.Task ( Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath, Scaffold.Error.Error euser ) (Scaffold.Resource.ResourceRef euser v)

aliases.name: UserTask
aliases.comment: This task simplifies routing out for the user.

types.name: Resource
types.comment: A resource item.

values.name: assumeIf
values.comment:
If some predicate `satisfies` is satisfied by the resource `res`, then we make the following
assumption. If this resource is an operation, then the assumption will be applied to
the result of that operation.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Bool) -> v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: assumeIfNot
values.comment: Negation of assumeIf.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Bool) -> v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: assumeIfNow
values.comment: If the predicate is satisfied, replace the resource with some known value.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v' -> Bool) -> v' -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v' -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v'

values.name: assumeInCase
values.comment:
If `possibleAssumption` yields some value `value'` when a Resource is applied, then that
value is used to overwrite the resource with an assumption `Known value'`, otherwise the Resource
is unaffected. If this resource is an operation, then the assumption will be applied conditionally
to the result of that operation.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Maybe.Maybe v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: assumeInCaseNow
values.comment:
This is the counterpart to assumeInCase which does _not_ abstract away whether or not this is
some pending optask operation. Concretely, we want this in the case that we are doing model to view
reductions because a pending operation should still have some concrete visible representation, such
as an ajax loader symbol. Of course, one should still correctly call *Integrate so that an operation
is always a `pendingResource` by the time it gets past the `stage` step.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v' -> Maybe.Maybe v') -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v' -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v'

values.name: atPath
values.comment: Manipulate an item at the given path, or else do nothing if the path does not exist.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: catchError
values.comment: Provide a decider that turns an error of type `Error.Error euser` in to a resource of `Resource euser v`.
values.type: (Scaffold.Error.Error euser -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v

values.name: chooseLeft
values.comment: Collision handler for nested Resources that always chooses the left hand side.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: chooseNeither
values.comment: Collision handler that removes collision keys entirely.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: chooseRight
values.comment: Collision handler for nested Resources that always chooses the right hand side.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: chooseVoid
values.comment: Collision handler for nested Resources that voids collision keys.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: collapse
values.comment: Collapses a resource tree made of group resources in to a single resource of the same type.
values.type: (List ( Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath , Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v ) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: comprehend
values.comment:
The equivalent of therefore for ResourceTasks. This allows you to map fetched data to multiple
models with ease, as long as operations which should effect all of the models are all sunk in to
ResourceTasks producing the base model's type.
values.type: (v -> v') -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v'

values.name: comprehend'
values.comment:
Like `comprehend`, but accounts for the path of the leaves effected by the transformation
by using `therefore'` on the result of the task. This prepends the reference path of the resource
task, such that global context for the resource's location is available if desired.

Note that you may specify a prefix path to the existing one to provide additional context in large
resource group structures.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> v -> v') -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v'

values.name: copyPath
values.comment: Copy the resource at a given path `path` in the resource group structure to a target path `path'`.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: decideBy
values.comment:
Offer a decision on some `undecidedResource res`. Undecided resource is the result of some
problem which may or may not be in control of the client. Such resource may be the result of
anything that can result in an error in your application. If this resource is an operation, then
the assumption will be applied to the result of that operation.
values.type: (Scaffold.Error.Error euser -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: deletePath
values.comment:
Delete the item at the given path. This equivalency holds:

    atPath (always unknownResource) path res == deletePath path res
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: deltaOf
values.comment: Like `deltaTo`, but without the transformation. The following equivalency holds
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: deltaTask
values.comment:
Transform a `ResourceTask` back in to a `UserTask`, which will produce a nested `Resource`
finger reflecting the final path output of the given `ResourceTask`. This output resource can be
treated just like a delta using the `Resource.merge` and `Resource.mergeMany` functions to inject it
in to the working set.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.UserTask euser v

values.name: deltaTo
values.comment:
`deltaTo` applies the given transformation function to the pending changes to the
`Resource` structure, producing a partial structure representing only what has changed since the
last call to `integrate`. The resulting partial structure is intended for use as a delta, to be
passed to `update` for some other Resource structure. This results in a simple one-way data binding.

To introduce k-way data binding, one need only use the `interpret` function to transform the
`ResourceTask` output of the subordinate views back in to deltas that transform the origin
`Resource` structure. NOTE that this implies when one wishes for the origin structure to reflect
changes to one of it's subordinates, one must dispatch UserTasks that succeed with the intended
changes. This can be very clean as long as there is a bijection between the origin structure
and each of it's subordinates. The complexity of the mapping is of course dependent on your record
design, so one must still take care.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v') -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v'

values.name: deriveIf
values.comment:
If the predicate is satisfied, apply the given transformation function. If this is a pending
operationResource, then apply deriveIf with the same arguments to the result.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v' -> Bool) -> (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v' -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v') -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v' -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v'

values.name: deriveIfNow
values.comment: If the predicate is satisfied, apply the given transformation function.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v' -> Bool) -> (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v' -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v') -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v' -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v'

values.name: dispatch
values.comment:
Given some configuration and a resource, produce Just an opaque query task or Nothing
when the resource is an operation or the resource is not an operation respectively.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> List (Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v)

values.name: dispatchIf
values.comment:
If some predicate `satisfies` is satisfied by the resource `res`, then we make the following
optask.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Bool) -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: dispatchIfNot
values.comment: Negation of dispatchIf
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Bool) -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: dispatchInCase
values.comment:
If `possibleOperation` yields some ResourceTask task `optask` when a Resource is applied, then
the resource is replaced by the resource `operationResource optask`, otherwise the resource is
unaffected. If this resource is an operation, then the result of that operation will be used as
the input to the provided function. In this way, operations can be chained arbitrarily deep,
but in a manner that helpfully abstracts away whether we are still waiting or already have the
result in the composition.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Maybe.Maybe (Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v)) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: dispatchInCaseNow
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Maybe.Maybe (Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v)) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: flatten
values.comment:
Flatten the given resource if it is a group to a resource of the same type. Note that unlike
`collapse`, this function does not recursively collapse the entire tree automatically. This grants
a greater degree of flexibility.
values.type: (List ( String, Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v ) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: flattenDict
values.comment: Variant of `flatten` whose argument function takes a dictionary instead of a list of pairs.
values.type: (Dict.Dict String (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: getPath
values.comment:
Get the item at the given path. Returns unknownResource if the item _might_ exist, but the hierarchy
does not show knowledge at the fringe (i.e., the fringe is unknown at the last known location in
the path), but may also return voidResource to a path which is known not to exist. For example,
if foo is a resource, then foo/bar cannot be a valid path because foo is not a collection. Pending
will be given in the case that an operation is pending.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: groupResource
values.type: List ( String, Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v ) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: integrate
values.comment:
Given some configuration and a resource, produce a pendingResource in the case that the
resource is an operation, otherwise give the same resource.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: interpret
values.comment:
Interpret the given `ResourceTask`'s resource output by a given transform function. NOTE that this
can be literally any function whose signature ends in `ResourceTask euser v -> ResourceTask euser v'`,
which is of course inclusive of `ResourceTask euser v -> ResourceTask euser v'` in the case that
`v` is the same type as `v'`.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v') -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v'

values.name: interpret'
values.comment:
Like `interpret`, but the prefix path of the resource is passed to the given function, and the
user can optionally specify their own prefix path. `interpret'` is to `interpret` what `comprehend'`
is to `comprehend`.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v') -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v'

values.name: isForbidden
values.comment: True if the resource is forbiddenResource.

values.name: isGroup
values.comment: True if the resource is unknownResource.

values.name: isKnown
values.comment: True if the resource is known.

values.name: isNil
values.comment: True if the resource is unknownResource or voidResource.

values.name: isNotForbidden
values.comment: False if the resource is forbiddenResource.

values.name: isNotGroup
values.comment: False if the resource is unknownResource.

values.name: isNotKnown
values.comment: False if the resource is known.

values.name: isNotNil
values.comment: False if the resource is unknownResource or voidResource.

values.name: isNotOperation
values.comment: False if the resource is a pending operation.

values.name: isNotPending
values.comment: False if the resource is pendingResource.

values.name: isNotUndecided
values.comment: False if the resource is undecidedResource.

values.name: isNotUnknown
values.comment: False if the resource is unknownResource.

values.name: isNotVoid
values.comment: False if the resource is voidResource.

values.name: isOperation
values.comment: True if the resource is a pending operation.

values.name: isPending
values.comment: True if the resource is pendingResource.

values.name: isUndecided
values.comment: True if the resource is undecidedResource.

values.name: isUnknown
values.comment: True if the resource is unknownResource.

values.name: isVoid
values.comment: True if the resource is voidResource.

values.name: maybeKnownNow
values.comment: If a resource is known, then give Just it's value, otherwise Nothing.

values.name: maybeOr
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Maybe.Maybe v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: merge
values.comment:
Merge can be used to assemble path fingers or existing group structures arbitrarily. A common
usage would be to put many different resources at their own prefix paths, then merge them all by
folding on this if your data structure is odd, otherwise use mergeMany if you are already working
with a list. This takes a choice function that determines the outcome of two different resources
existing at the same path, _at least one of which is concrete and not a group_. Groups merge
automatically with eachother.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: mergeMany
values.comment: Merge many folds from the left over the given list of resources with merge.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> List (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: movePath
values.comment: Move the resource at a given path `path` in the resource group structure to a target path `path'`.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: operationResource
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: otherwise
values.comment:
In the event that the given resource is not a simple `defResource`, we replace it with a different simple
resource.

values.name: prefixPath
values.comment:
Create a path before the given resource. This has the effect of prefixing whatever is there
whether concrete or a group with the given path. Thus, creating a resource path ["foo", "bar"] and
another at ["foo", "baz"] would result in two resources that can be merged without conflicts
guaranteed because their contents are in the `foo -> bar -> ...` and `foo -> baz -> ...` subtries
respectively.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: putPath
values.comment:
Put a resource in to a group resource at the given path. In the case that something is already
there, use the `choice` function to determine which should be used. See the `choose*` family for some
built-in functions.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: resultOr
values.type: (Scaffold.Error.Error euser -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Result.Result (Scaffold.Error.Error euser) v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: routeTo
values.comment: Route the results of a given `ResourceTask` to a given `ResourcePath`.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v

values.name: therefore
values.comment:
Given a resource of value type v, create a resource of value type v' by transforming the
known value or group using some function (v -> v'). NOTE that this will create an entirely new
resouce structure, and thus any pending changes will be integrated immediately. If you wish to
preserve deltas for the purpose of mirroring and efficient data flow, then one should be using
deltaTo in order to transform just the changes.
values.type: (v -> v') -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v'

values.name: therefore'
values.comment: `therefore`, but which includes the current path as the first argument.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> v -> v') -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v'

values.name: throughout
values.comment:
Use the given function to transform all leaf resources throughout a group structure. This
applies to the result of any pending resource operations.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: throughoutNow
values.comment:
Use the given function to transform all leaf resources throughout a group structure. This version
applies the transformation function now, even if the resource is a pending operation. This should be
used in contexts where we are rendering some resulting view of the resources most of the time.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: toProgram
values.comment:
Convert a resource to program input. I've found that this is a very un-Elm-like way
of doing things that makes the Elm Architecture harder to stick to. If anyone else finds a
counterexample, please let me know! If it does turn out to be useful, I will complete the set.

NOTE : DEPRECIATED, removed from v5.
values.type: (b -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser b -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser (Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad)

values.name: toProgramTask
values.comment: Convert a `UserTask euser v` in to an `App.ProgramTask bad a`
values.type: (Scaffold.Error.Error euser -> List a) -> (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> List a) -> Scaffold.Resource.UserTask euser v -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: update
values.comment:
Update the second `Resource` argument by merging the first argument's delta `Resource`. Chooses
the left `Resource` on a conflict, mechanically speaking.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: update'
values.comment:
Same as `update`, but pass the given conflict resolution choice function to `merge` instead of
`chooseLeft`, which is the default. This allows one to make a selection as to whether or not the
given delta is still relevant.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: updateList
values.comment:
Same as `update`, but apply a list of delta resources sequentially. This resolves all conflicts
by `chooseLeft`, which favors the deltas always.
values.type: List (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: updateList'
values.comment:
Same as `updateList`, but uses the provided conflict resolution choice function instead of
`chooseLeft` as in `updateList`. This allows one to make a selection as to whether or not the
given delta is still relevant.
values.type: (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> List (Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

values.name: userTask
values.comment: Create a task which will route the resulting resource to the given path.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.UserTask euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.ResourceTask euser v

values.name: within
values.comment:
DEPRECIATED version of therefore, not supporting type transformation.

NOTE : removed in version 5.
values.type: (sub -> sub) -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser sub -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser sub

values.name: writePath
values.comment:
Equivalent to `putPath chooseLeft`, this is a simple write which will always blindly overwrite the
current resource at the given path.
values.type: Scaffold.Resource.ResourcePath -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v -> Scaffold.Resource.Resource euser v

docs.name: Scaffold.Error

aliases.name: DecodingFailure
aliases.comment: Represents a decoding task which failed.

aliases.name: Error
aliases.comment: Error record.

types.name: ErrorType
types.comment: Type of error that occurred in Scaffold.

values.name: decoderError
values.comment: Report a problem decoding something.

values.name: decoderErrorAndLog
values.comment: decoderError and log to console.

values.name: decodingFailure
values.comment:
Given the source string on which decoding was attempted and the reason for the failure,
give a DecodingFailure

values.name: reportError
values.comment:
Report an error. Given an ErrorType and a String describing what went wrong humanly, create
an error record.

values.name: reportErrorAndLog
values.comment: reportError and log to console.

values.name: unknownError
values.comment: Report an error, the nature of which is not known.

values.name: unknownErrorAndLog
values.comment: unknownError and log to console.

values.name: userError
values.comment: Report a user defined error.

values.name: userErrorAndLog
values.comment: userError and log to console.

docs.name: Scaffold.Layout

aliases.name: Item
aliases.comment: An item, which represents an Elm Element with a position and a handle.
aliases.type: { elem : Scaffold.Layout.Element , x : Int , u : Int , y : Int , v : Int }

types.name: Axis
types.comment: An axis along which to evenly distribute by spacing or handle position.

types.name: Bounds
types.comment: A bounding box, given as a minimum and a maximum.

types.name: Group
types.comment: Group is an opaque type that represents a grouped set of items with a pending set of transformations.

types.name: Rule
types.comment: A guide ruler defined as either a vertical or a horizontal axis aligned line.

values.name: adjustedRule
values.comment: Adjust a horizontal or vertical ruler.

values.name: appendGroup
values.comment:
Append two groups, resulting a group containing the elements from `grp` first and the
elements of `grp'` second.

values.name: autoBounds
values.comment: Automatic bounds.

values.name: boundsHeight
values.comment: Get the width of a bounding box, defined as boundsSize >> snd

values.name: boundsLower
values.comment: Get the minimum bound if a minimum bound is defined.

values.name: boundsSize
values.comment: Get the size of a bounding box if both maximum and minimum bounds are defined, otherwise (0, 0).

values.name: boundsUpper
values.comment: Get the maximum bound if a maximum bound is defined.

values.name: boundsWidth
values.comment: Get the width of a bounding box, defined as boundsSize >> fst

values.name: butBefore
values.comment: Apply some transformation to every item in the group before the pending transformations.

values.name: butBeforeAt
values.comment: Apply some transformation to the item at a particular index in the group before the pending transformations.

values.name: butBeforeSlice
values.comment: Apply some transformation to the items in a particular slice of the group before the pending transformations.

values.name: clampedBounds
values.comment:
Clamp a bounding box to some inner bounding box and some outer bounding box. Either the inner
or the outer bounding box may be autoBounds, so this may also only clamp an inner or an outer limit,
or neither.

values.name: clampedInnerBounds
values.comment: clampedInnerBounds myBounds = clampedBounds myBounds autoBounds

values.name: clampedOuterBounds
values.comment: clampedOuterBounds myBounds = clampedBounds autoBounds myBounds

values.name: computed
values.comment:
Run any pending transformations on all group items. For the most part, this can be avoided, but it should be
done if you are planning to get a lot of items back from the group transformed, or else the work of applying the
pending group transforms will be done at least twice, once when you retrieve the item using groupAt and once when
you flatten the group to produce an item.

values.name: defBounds
values.comment: Define a definite bounding box.

values.name: defCenteredBounds
values.comment: Define a bounding box with a particular size whose center falls on (0, 0)

values.name: defSizeBounds
values.comment: Define a bounding box at (0, 0)

values.name: emptyItem
values.comment: An empty layout item.

values.name: flatten
values.comment:
Flatten a group using automatic bounds for the inner and outer bounds. This will produce the
tightest bounding box possible around the target, and place the handle at (0, 0) relative to the resulting
bounding box. This can result in the handle being placed outside of the group, but this can be desirable for
positioning. For example, I may want to grab something at (-5, -5), so I can position it's top left
corner relative to some outer box with (5, 5) padding.

values.name: flattenOutTo
values.comment:
Flatten a group using only an inner bound, which is equivalent to

    flattenWithinOutTo outer autoBounds

values.name: flattenOutToStyled
values.comment: Same as flattenOutTo, but applies the given additional styles to the container.
values.type: List ( String, String ) -> Scaffold.Layout.Bounds -> Scaffold.Layout.Group -> Scaffold.Layout.Item

values.name: flattenStyled
values.comment: Same as flatten, but applies the given additional styles to the container.

values.name: flattenTo
values.comment:
Flatten a group using an exact bound. If this is specified to be autoBounds, then the following
equivalency holds:

    flattenTo autoBounds group == flatten group

Otherwise, the items in the group are positioned in the resulting item relative to the top left corner of the bounds and
the resulting item shall have the exact size of the given bounds.

values.name: flattenToStyled
values.comment: Same as flattenTo, but applies the given additional styles to the container.
values.type: List ( String, String ) -> Scaffold.Layout.Bounds -> Scaffold.Layout.Group -> Scaffold.Layout.Item

values.name: flattenWithin
values.comment:
Flatten a group using only an outer bound, which is equivalent to

    flattenWithinOutTo autoBounds outer

values.name: flattenWithinOutTo
values.comment: Flatten a group using an inner and an outer bound to clamp the size of the resulting item.

values.name: flattenWithinOutToStyled
values.comment: Same as flattenWithinOutTo, but applies the given additional styles to the container.
values.type: List ( String, String ) -> Scaffold.Layout.Bounds -> Scaffold.Layout.Bounds -> Scaffold.Layout.Group -> Scaffold.Layout.Item

values.name: flattenWithinStyled
values.comment: Same as flattenWithin, but applies the given additional styles to the container.
values.type: List ( String, String ) -> Scaffold.Layout.Bounds -> Scaffold.Layout.Group -> Scaffold.Layout.Item

values.name: fromItem
values.comment: Convert an Item to Html by placing it inside of a sized container.

values.name: fromItemStyled
values.comment:
The same as fromItem, but styles the sized container with a given arbitrary list of CSS
properties.

values.name: grabItem
values.comment:
Grab an item, producing a handle. This defines a point on the item called the "handle" that is
placed exactly at item's coordinates. If I say

  grabItem 0 0

then that would grab the top left corner. u and v and given as window coordinates relative to the
top left corner of the item.

values.name: grabItemRelative
values.comment:
Grab an item in normalized coordinates relative to it's size. This means that (1, 1) is the
bottom right corner, and (0, 0) is the top left corner.

values.name: grabItemRelativeX
values.comment: Grab an item by it's x coordinate relative to the item's size.

values.name: grabItemRelativeY
values.comment: Grab an item by it's y coordinate relative to the item's size.

values.name: grabItemX
values.comment: Grab an item by it's x coordinate.

values.name: grabItemY
values.comment: Grab an item by it's y coordinate.

values.name: group
values.comment: Create an item group from a list.

values.name: groupAt
values.comment:
Retrieve the item at a given index in the group, or Nothing if the index is out of bounds. If
there are waiting transformations, a copy of the item with those transformations applied will be
given.

values.name: groupAtBefore
values.comment:
Retrieve the item at a given index in the group, or Nothing if the index is out of bounds. The
item will be retrieved in it's original state without any pending group transformations applied.

values.name: groupFromArray
values.comment: Create an item group from an array.

values.name: groupFromDict
values.comment: Create an item group from a dictionary.

values.name: groupSize
values.comment: Get the size of the group.

values.name: horizontalRule
values.comment: Create a new horizontal ruler at the given y coordinate.

values.name: horizontalRuleBetween
values.comment: Shorthand for ruleBetween horizontalRule

values.name: horizontalRuleCentered
values.comment: Shorthand for ruleCenter horizontalRule

values.name: horizontally
values.comment: Do a distribution horizontally.

values.name: iconItem
values.comment:
Create an item using an SVG icon function. This is intended primarily for use with the material
icon set, but if others follow suit with the same API for different icon sets, this will work just
as well. Note that the size and color arguments are intentionally flipped. This is for currying
purposes; it is much less likely for the size of an icon to change than the color.

values.name: itemBounds
values.comment: Get the resultant bounding box of an item, given it's placement and handle.

values.name: itemHeight
values.comment: Get the height of an item.

values.name: itemHorizontalRule
values.comment: Create a horizontal ruler aligned with an item.

values.name: itemRule
values.comment: Create a vertical or a horizontal ruler aligned with an item.

values.name: itemSize
values.comment: Get the size of an Item.

values.name: itemVerticalRule
values.comment: Create a vertical ruler aligned with an item.

values.name: itemWidth
values.comment: Get the width of an item.

values.name: lerpOf
values.comment:
Modify any of the item manipulation primitives by linearly interpolating the handle and coordinates
between the current and output values. This provides the basic building block for transitional animations.
Easing functions could quite easily be implemented on top of this.

values.name: makeIconItem
values.comment: iconItem, but you can set html attributes on the container div.
values.type: (Color.Color -> Int -> Svg.Svg) -> List Html.Attribute -> Int -> Color.Color -> Scaffold.Layout.Item

values.name: makeItem
values.comment:
Create an item using an Html constructor. Nice for when you largely rely on Layout over Html,
using Html just for the end controls.
values.type: Int -> Int -> (List Html.Attribute -> List Html.Html -> Html.Html) -> List Html.Attribute -> List Html.Html -> Scaffold.Layout.Item

values.name: makeItemStyled
values.comment:
Create an item using an Html constructor, but append a style attribute to the end of the
attributes list with the given styles. Useful in the case that you want to forward declare the
style of a whole bunch of items' Html contents with a partial function.
values.type: List ( String, String ) -> Int -> Int -> (List Html.Attribute -> List Html.Html -> Html.Html) -> List Html.Attribute -> List Html.Html -> Scaffold.Layout.Item

values.name: move
values.comment: Move an item.

values.name: moveX
values.comment: Move an item horizontally.

values.name: moveY
values.comment: Move an item vertically.

values.name: place
values.comment: Place the handle of an item at these coordinates.

values.name: placeX
values.comment: Place the handle of an item at this x coordinate.

values.name: placeY
values.comment: Place the handle of an item at this y coordinate.

values.name: prependGroup
values.comment:
Prepend a group before another, resulting a group containing the elements from `grp` second and
the elements of `grp'` first.

values.name: regularly
values.comment:
Distribute the items in the group along some Axis given a starting coordinate and an ending
coordinate, such that the handles of the items are evenly distributed between the starting and the
ending coordinates. The height or width of this vertical or horizontal distribution is dependent on
the positioning of the handles on the items, and the coordinate not effected by the distribution is
left in place.

values.name: ruleBetween
values.comment:
Given a ruler direction (verticalRule or horizontalRule), a lower and an upper bound, and some
float t between 0 and 1, linearly interpolate between the lower and upper bound by t.

values.name: ruleCenter
values.comment:
Given a ruler direction (verticalRule or horizontalRule), a lower bound, and an upper bound,
center a ruler between the lower and the upper bound. The following equivalencies hold:

    ruleCenter verticalRule x0 x1 == ruleBetween verticalRule x0 x1 0.5
    ruleCenter horizontalRule y0 y1 == ruleBetween horizontalRule y0 y1 0.5

values.name: snapToRule
values.comment: Snap an item's handle to a vertical or horizontal ruler.

values.name: spacedBetween
values.comment:
Distribute the items in the group along some Axis given a starting coordinate and an ending
coordinate, such that the spaces between all of the items are even, resulting in a justified layout.
Vertical distribution is done top to bottom, horizontal distribution is done left to right.

The height or width of this vertical or horizontal distribution is

    to - from

and the coordinate not effected by the distribution is left in place.

values.name: spacedBy
values.comment:
Distribute the items in the group along some Axis given a starting coordinate and spacing given
in window coordinates, resulting in an evenly spaced horizontal or vertical distribution. Vertical
distribution is done top to bottom, horizontal distribution is done left to right.

The height or width of this vertical or horizontal distribution is

    from + siz * (n - 1) + (sum itemHeight items)

and the coordinate not effected by the distribution is left in place.

values.name: thenDo
values.comment: Apply some transformation to every item in the group after the pending transformations.

values.name: thenDoAt
values.comment: Apply some transformation to the item at a particular index in the group after the pending transformations.

values.name: thenDoSlice
values.comment: Apply some transformation to the items in a particular slice of the group after the pending transformations.

values.name: toItem
values.comment: Create an item from Html

values.name: towardsRule
values.comment: Move an item's handle toward a vertical or horizontal ruler by some constant amount.

values.name: towardsRuleRelative
values.comment: Move an item's handle toward a vertical or horizontal ruler by some factor t

values.name: verticalRule
values.comment: Create a new vertical ruler at the given x coordinate.

values.name: verticalRuleBetween
values.comment: Shorthand for ruleBetween verticalRule

values.name: verticalRuleCentered
values.comment: Shorthand for ruleCenter verticalRule

values.name: vertically
values.comment: Do a distribution vertically.

docs.name: Scaffold.App
docs.comment:
The main application scaffolding. You can write a really pretty top level like this:

    myProgramOutput : ProgramOutput MyAction MyModel Layout.Item Error
    myProgramOutput =
      defStagedProgram myPresent myStage myUpdate myInitialModel
      |> defSequenceInputs
        [ someVeryImportantBrowserEnvironmentInput
        , someOtherOutsideSignal
        ]
      |> runAnd (computeTask doMyComplicatedStartupWork myData)
      |> it'sErrorConnector myErrorHandler
      |> thisAddressAsync myOutsideMailboxAddress
      |> itself


    main : Signal Graphics.Element.Element
    main =
      viewOutput myProgramOutput
      |> Signal.map Layout.fromItem


    port sink : Signal (Task z ())
    port sink = sink myProgramOutput


# Definitions
@docs AgentStatus, ComputedResult, ComputedSuccess, ProgramInput, ProgramOutput, ProgramSnapshot, ProgramConnector, ProgramTask, TaskDispatchment, UpdatedModel, ViewOutput

# Define Programs
@docs defProgram, defProgram', defStagedProgram, forwardSingleton

# Run Programs
@docs run, runAnd, defSingletonInputs, defSequenceInputs, defLazySequenceInputs, sink

# UpdatedModel and ViewOutput Manipulation
@docs updated, presented, withTask, withTasks, withDispatchment, withDispatchments, withChildren, viewOutputTask

# Dispatch Actions and Errors
@docs actionTask, actionTaskAsync, errorTask, computeTask, computedSuccess, computedSuccessAsync, noActions, nilTask

# Program Output Routing and Management
@docs itself, itselfAsync, it'sErrorConnector, thisAddress, thisAddressAsync, thisForwardAddress, thisForwardAddressAsync, thisErrorConnector, thisForwardConnector, thisConnector, outputView

# Handling Tasks and TaskDispatchment
@docs combineDispatchments, collapseTasks, dispatchTasks, dispatchmentHasWork, dispatchmentTask, promoteDispatchment, promoteDispatchmentErrors, handleDispatchmentErrors

# Manipulate Program Snapshots
@docs programSnapshot, programSnapshotAddDispatchment, programSnapshotDispatch, programSnapshotPresent, programSnapshotStage, programSnapshotUpdate, performCycle

# Program Task Agents
@docs agentSuccess, agentSingletonSuccess, agentFailure, agent, successAgent, failureAgent, binaryAgent, blindAgent, nilAgent, resultAgent, ignoreError

aliases.name: ComputedResult
aliases.comment:
A ComputedResult is a Result which may be a ComputedSuccess or some error type on failure. This
is used as the output type of the function passed to a `computeTask`.

aliases.name: ComputedSuccess
aliases.comment:
This is the success type of an ProgramTask. It consists of a sequence of actions to execute, and
a tag saying whether we want the actions executed all at once, or spread out asynchronously. This
should be treated as opaque; use the constructors `computedSuccess` and `computedSuccessAsync`.

aliases.name: ProgramConnector
aliases.comment:
ProgramConnector is an alias for functions that transform ProgramTasks by routing their actions to
an address. You will probably not need to directly provide an ProgramConnector function, as the built in
family of taps should be sufficient for just about any application.
aliases.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

aliases.name: ProgramInput
aliases.comment:
This is the input type for Program. It can be seen as roughly analogous to StartApp's Config
type, but carries the full configuration and input in one. This should be considered opaque.
aliases.type: { inputs : Lazy.List.LazyList (Signal.Signal (Lazy.List.LazyList a)) , model0 : b , present : Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.ViewOutput a c bad , stage : Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.UpdatedModel a b bad , update : a -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.UpdatedModel a b bad }

aliases.name: ProgramOutput
aliases.comment:
This is the output of an Program program. This is not intended to be opaque. Any part of the
output structure is up for grabs. I do not reccomend usage of the lazyAddress externally.

    view'     Signal with the current view.
    model'    Signal with the current model.
    now       Signal with the most recent execution time.
    actions   Signal with the most recently atomically executed action list.
    tasks     Signal with the most recent ProgramTask output.
    address   The address of the Program program's Mailbox.
aliases.type: { view' : Signal.Signal c , model' : Signal.Signal b , now : Signal.Signal Time.Time , actions : Signal.Signal (List a) , tasks : Signal.Signal (Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a) , address : Signal.Address (List a) , lazyAddress : Signal.Address (Lazy.List.LazyList a) }

aliases.name: ProgramSnapshot
aliases.comment:
This represents an instantaneous description of an Program program. It consists of the current
model and a possible TaskDispatchment. This should be treated as opaque.
aliases.type: { model' : b, dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a }

aliases.name: ProgramTask
aliases.comment: A task with a ComputedSuccess result. These are used as the output task type of the Program.

aliases.name: TaskDispatchment
aliases.comment:
This is an opaque type representing an ordered list of tasks to execute. This is quite similar
to Effects batching.

aliases.name: UpdatedModel
aliases.comment:
Represents the output of the `update` and `stage` functions configured in the ProgramInput.
This type exists so that TaskDispatchments and ProgramTasks can be cleanly included in the output
of `stage` and `update` without the need to return an ugly pair or embed anything in the model.
aliases.type: { dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a, model' : b }

aliases.name: ViewOutput
aliases.comment:
Represents the output of the `present` function configured in the ProgramInput.
This type exists so that TaskDispatchments and ProgramTasks can be cleanly included in the output
of `present` without the need to return an ugly pair or embed anything in the model.
aliases.type: { dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a, view' : c }

types.name: AgentStatus
types.comment:
Represents the status of a given program agent. Program agents are a way of transforming the
results of arbitrary tasks in to actions and errors for the program to consume.

values.name: actionTask
values.comment:
An ProgramTask that carries a list of actions to execute atomically.

Note that a tap which is explicitly from the `*Async` family of taps will override this behavior,
instead producing the same behavior as actionTaskAsync. For that reason, asynchronous taps should
mainly be used for one-way data flows that are not dependent on ordering.

values.name: actionTaskAsync
values.comment:
An ProgramTask that carries a list of actions to execute asynchronously, meaning they may be
interspersed with other feedback and inputs.

values.name: agent
values.comment:
The basic program agent. Takes two functions, one of which transforms a successful result in to
an AgentStatus, and one which does the same for task failure results. This transforms an arbitrary
task in to an ProgramTask. Notice that we can easily succeed anyway even if the task failed, or vice
versa, because we get an AgentStatus which may be successful or failing either way. This means you
can skip error handling altogether if you already know what to do with the failure from the scope
you're in; you can simply map the failure on to some actions that perform an appropriate
contingency.
values.type: (x -> Scaffold.App.AgentStatus bad a) -> (y -> Scaffold.App.AgentStatus bad a) -> Task.Task y x -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: agentFailure
values.comment: Failed program agent output.

values.name: agentSingletonSuccess
values.comment: Successful program agent output.

values.name: agentSuccess
values.comment: Successful program agent output.

values.name: binaryAgent
values.comment:
A binary program agent. This does not process any of the results, but simply always gives the
succesful AgentStatus (the first one) on task success, otherwise it gives the failed AgentStatus.
values.type: Scaffold.App.AgentStatus bad a -> Scaffold.App.AgentStatus bad a -> Task.Task y x -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: blindAgent
values.comment:
If we don't care about the outcome of a task because it can't fail or produce a meaningful
result, we can just queue up something to do after it's done. This is perfect for using delay tasks.
values.type: Scaffold.App.AgentStatus bad a -> Task.Task y x -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: collapseTasks
values.comment:
Collapse two action tasks by executing them sequentially and appending their resulting action
outputs.
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: combineDispatchments
values.comment:
Combine two TaskDispatchment instances. This appends the task list of the second to the task
list of the first.
values.type: Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a

values.name: computeTask
values.comment:
An ProgramTask that obtains some ComputedResult from user provided data and a user provided
function, which is invoked during execution of the task. This just gives us basic support for
deferred computations.
values.type: (data -> Scaffold.App.ComputedResult bad a) -> data -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: computedSuccess
values.comment:
Produce a normal ComputedSuccess from a list of actions. These actions will be sent all at once,
and thus will be executed atomically.

values.name: computedSuccessAsync
values.comment:
Produce an asynchronous ComputedSuccess from a list of actions. These actions will be sent
one by one from sequential tasks, and thus their execution will be spread out with no guarantee that
the sequence of actions will be executed atomically.

If you need to run a list of a few thousand actions,
and it is safe for those actions to be interspersed with other actions, you may be looking at a very
good use case for this function. Note also that this will never preempt an action list that is sent
at once using `computeSuccess`, which is a product of how the Elm runtime works.

values.name: defLazySequenceInputs
values.comment:
Define a list of action sequence signal inputs for a given ProgramInput, where the sequences are
given as lazy lists via Lazy.List.
values.type: List (Signal.Signal (Lazy.List.LazyList a)) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad

values.name: defProgram
values.comment:
defProgram is the old declaration form for defining ProgramInput. It is simpler, and does not
support the `stage` function. Internally this uses the new form, but it has been left in for
two reasons. One is of course backwards compatibility, but sometimes you just don't need that
extra firepower, in which case it is mere clutter.
values.type: (Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.ViewOutput a c bad) -> (a -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.UpdatedModel a b bad) -> b -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad

values.name: defProgram'
values.comment:
defProgram' is the complete way to define an ProgramInput. ProgramInput is configured with
three functions. `update` and `present` should be familiar to users of StartApp, except for the
fact that they always have the current time. `stage` is a special addition which allows one to
use the program Mailbox address from a context in which the model can be updated.

The use case for `stage` which inspired it's existence is as follows: suppose you have a really
big model with a really, really big view. There is enough data that keen algorithms and data
structures, as well as avoiding redundant computations during presentation becomes a neccessity.

You can then structure your application as follows. Represent all these components as instances of
Machine. From inside `stage`, you can present _only the ones that will or should actually be seen_,
and cache the results in the model. Since you can create an updated model from here, you can save
anything that may be later needed during presentation.

`stage` is called only once after an entire list of actions is executed. If you get a list of 1000
actions, you can still guarantee the work in stage will be done only once, before presentation.
_The primary reason stage has access to the address is because it enables you to call present on
any sub components ahead of time for caching purposes._
values.type: (Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.ViewOutput a c bad) -> (Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.UpdatedModel a b bad) -> (a -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.UpdatedModel a b bad) -> b -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad

values.name: defSequenceInputs
values.comment: Define a list of action sequence signal inputs for a given ProgramInput.
values.type: List (Signal.Signal (List a)) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad

values.name: defSingletonInputs
values.comment: Define a list of action singleton signal inputs for a given ProgramInput.
values.type: List (Signal.Signal a) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad

values.name: defStagedProgram
values.comment: Clearer synonym for defProgram'.
values.type: (Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.ViewOutput a c bad) -> (Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.UpdatedModel a b bad) -> (a -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.UpdatedModel a b bad) -> b -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad

values.name: dispatchTasks
values.comment: Turn a list of ProgramTasks in to a TaskDispatchment.
values.type: List (Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a) -> Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a

values.name: dispatchmentHasWork
values.comment: True iff the TaskDispatchment has at least one ProgramTask.

values.name: dispatchmentTask
values.comment:
Turn a TaskDispatchment in to an ProgramTask. Doing this will make things a lot more opaque,
so ask yourself if it is absolutely neccessary first. Mainly this is included for completeness.
values.type: Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: errorTask
values.comment: An ProgramTask that carries an error.

values.name: failureAgent
values.comment:
This is a combination of agent and programBinary agent which gives the successful agent
status in the case of success, and processes failed results to get an AgentStatus otherwise .
values.type: Scaffold.App.AgentStatus bad a -> (y -> Scaffold.App.AgentStatus bad a) -> Task.Task y x -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: forwardSingleton
values.comment:
Sometimes you don't need the fanciness of an action list address. In that case, it's cool to
not have to write your own forwarding address.

values.name: handleDispatchmentErrors
values.comment: Transform errors from a dispatchment back in to actions at any point.
values.type: (bad -> List a) -> Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a

values.name: ignoreError
values.comment: This makes any error in to noActions.

values.name: it'sErrorConnector
values.comment: Same semantics as `itself`, but for errors. Error taps do not have an asynchronous alternative.
values.type: (bad -> List a) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: itself
values.comment: This is the most essential tap for almost any application. It routes the actions resulting from your TaskDispatchment output back to the program's main address.
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: itselfAsync
values.comment: Same as itself, but execute action lists asynchronously, such that they may be interspersed with other action lists.
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: nilAgent
values.comment:
No matter what, do nothing. This will get your task to run, but no kind of action or error
feedback will be produced.
values.type: Task.Task y x -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: nilTask
values.comment: An ProgramTask that does nothing and produces noActions.

values.name: noActions
values.comment: A list of no actions.

values.name: outputView
values.comment: Get the program view output.
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Signal.Signal c

values.name: performCycle
values.comment:
Perform a full cycle on an ProgramSnapshot. This looks like:

      state
      |> programSnapshotUpdate input actions now
      |> programSnapshotStage input address now
      |> programSnapshotDispatch

internally. The point of performCycle is to be used in foldp, which it is inside runWithWork
and run (which really just calls runWithWork with nilTask).
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad -> Signal.Address (List a) -> ( Time.Time, List a ) -> ( Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad , Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a ) -> ( Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad , Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a )

values.name: presented
values.comment: Give a ViewOutput from your view type, carrying an empty TaskDispatchment.

values.name: programSnapshot
values.comment: Constructor for an ProgramSnapshot. I reccomend using the Machine module instead of these functions.
values.type: b -> Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad

values.name: programSnapshotAddDispatchment
values.comment: Add a dispatchment to an ProgramSnapshot.
values.type: Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad

values.name: programSnapshotDispatch
values.comment:
Get the pending TaskDispatchment out of an ProgramSnapshot and clear it from the snapshot in
one go. This gives an _ugly pair_. See the newer interface for this in Machine, and also see the way
Resource works. It seems much better to separate this in to two stages. It leaves room for a mistake,
which I was trying to avoid, but it's so much cleaner than way that it's worth it and actually
leads to fewer mistakes as a result.
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad -> ( Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad , Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a )

values.name: programSnapshotPresent
values.comment: Run the `present` phase on an ProgramSnapshot, yielding a ViewOutput.
values.type: { k | present : Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.ViewOutput a c bad } -> Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad -> Scaffold.App.ViewOutput a c bad

values.name: programSnapshotStage
values.comment: Run the `stage` phase on an ProgramSnapshot.
values.type: { k | stage : Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.UpdatedModel a b bad } -> Signal.Address (List a) -> Time.Time -> Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad

values.name: programSnapshotUpdate
values.comment: Run the `update` phase on an ProgramSnapshot.
values.type: { k | update : a -> Time.Time -> b -> Scaffold.App.UpdatedModel a b bad } -> List a -> Time.Time -> Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramSnapshot a b bad

values.name: promoteDispatchment
values.comment: Using some function, create a TaskDispatchment with a different action type.
values.type: (List a -> List a') -> Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a'

values.name: promoteDispatchmentErrors
values.comment: Using some function, create a TaskDispatchment with a different error type.
values.type: (bad -> bad') -> Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a -> Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad' a

values.name: resultAgent
values.comment:
The other program agents defined so far are less succinct because they take two arguments, one
which applies to the success case and one which applies to the failure case. This one takes a single
function which processes the task's outcome as a Result, and so is generally a bit shorter to write.
values.type: (Result.Result y x -> Scaffold.App.AgentStatus bad a) -> Task.Task y x -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: run
values.comment:
Run an program without any startup task.

    run (myProgram `withSequenceInputs` [myInput, myInput2])
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: runAnd
values.comment: Run an program with a startup task
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a -> Scaffold.App.ProgramInput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: sink
values.comment:
The sink is the final stop for ProgramOutput. This should be attached at a port to get your
tasks running.
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Signal.Signal (Task.Task z ())

values.name: successAgent
values.comment:
This is a combination of agent and programBinary agent which processes successful results
to get an AgentStatus, otherwise giving the failed agent status.
values.type: (x -> Scaffold.App.AgentStatus bad a) -> Scaffold.App.AgentStatus bad a -> Task.Task y x -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: thisAddress
values.comment: Route the resulting actions from your TaskDispatchments to some action list address.
values.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisAddressAsync
values.comment: Same as thisAddress, but asynchronously as described above.
values.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisConnector
values.comment:
A tap defined using an ProgramConnector and some address. The ProgramTasks that pass through this tap will be
routed to the given address. This is a bit lower level than is needed in most cases.
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramConnector bad a -> Signal.Address (List a) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisErrorConnector
values.comment: Transform any errors in to lists of actions, then route them to the address.
values.type: Signal.Address (List a) -> (bad -> List a) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisForwardAddress
values.comment: Same as thisAddress, but with forwarding.
values.type: Signal.Address target -> (List a -> target) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisForwardAddressAsync
values.comment: Same as thisForwardAddress, but asynchronously as described above.
values.type: Signal.Address target -> (List a -> target) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: thisForwardConnector
values.comment:
Same as thisConnector but uses Address forwarding to transform action lists in to some other target type
for your address.
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramConnector bad a -> Signal.Address target -> (List a -> target) -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramOutput a b c bad

values.name: updated
values.comment: Give an UpdatedModel from a model, carrying an empty TaskDispatchment.

values.name: viewOutputTask
values.comment:
Get an ProgramTask from a ViewOutput. This is DEPRECIATED. Use TaskDispatchment wherever
possible.
values.type: Scaffold.App.ViewOutput a c bad -> Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a

values.name: withChildren
values.comment:
This takes a list of UpdatedModel or ViewOutput instances, and appends each one to the
TaskDispatchment of the current output. This is preferred when doing model composition with Machine.
For example:

    App.staged { collectionModel | memberViews = memberOutputs }
    |> App.withChildren memberOutputs

where memberOutputs is a list of machinePresent or machinePresentAs outputs in the example.
values.type: List { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a } -> { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a } -> { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a }

values.name: withDispatchment
values.comment: This is the same as `withTasks`, but it takes an already existing TaskDispatchment.
values.type: Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a -> { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a } -> { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a }

values.name: withDispatchments
values.comment: `withDispatchment` for multiple dispatchments.
values.type: List (Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a) -> { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a } -> { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a }

values.name: withTask
values.comment: Add a single task to the output of any of the three program functions.
values.type: Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a -> { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a } -> { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a }

values.name: withTasks
values.comment:
Add some tasks to the output of any of the three Program functions.

    updated model |> withTasks [actionTask [Jump, Run]]
    presented viewstuff |> withTasks [errorTask [reportError "You done goofed."]]

This is definitely the most elegant way to build a TaskDispatchment as well, especially in the
context of declaring causality.
values.type: List (Scaffold.App.ProgramTask bad a) -> { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a } -> { anything | dispatchment : Scaffold.App.TaskDispatchment bad a }

docs.name: TimeApp
docs.comment:
This module helps you start your application in a typical Elm workflow.
It assumes you are following [the Elm Architecture][arch] and using
[elm-effects][]. From there it will wire everything up for you!

**Be sure to [read the Elm Architecture tutorial][arch] to learn how this all
works!**

[arch]: https://github.com/evancz/elm-architecture-tutorial
[elm-effects]: http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/evancz/elm-effects/latest

# Start your Application
@docs start, Config, App

aliases.name: App
aliases.comment:
An `App` is made up of a couple signals:

  * `html` — a signal of `Html` representing the current visual
    representation of your app. This should be fed into `main`.

  * `model` — a signal representing the current model. Generally you
    will not need this one, but it is there just in case. You will know if you
    need this.

  * `tasks` — a signal of tasks that need to get run. Your app is going
    to be producing tasks in response to all sorts of events, so this needs to
    be hooked up to a `port` to ensure they get run.
aliases.type: { html : Signal.Signal Html.Html , model : Signal.Signal model , tasks : Signal.Signal (Task.Task Effects.Never ()) }

aliases.name: Config
aliases.comment:
The configuration of an app follows the basic model / update / view pattern
that you see in every Elm program.

The `init` transaction will give you an initial model and create any tasks that
are needed on start up.

The `update` and `view` fields describe how to step the model and view the
model.

The `inputs` field is for any external signals you might need. If you need to
get values from JavaScript, they will come in through a port as a signal which
you can pipe into your app as one of the `inputs`.
aliases.type: { init : ( model, Effects.Effects action ) , update : action -> Time.Time -> model -> ( model, Effects.Effects action ) , view : Signal.Address action -> model -> Html.Html , inputs : List (Signal.Signal action) }

values.name: start
values.comment:
Start an application. It requires a bit of wiring once you have created an
`App`. It should pretty much always look like this:

    app =
        start { init = init, view = view, update = update, inputs = [] }

    main =
        app.html

    port tasks : Signal (Task.Task Never ())
    port tasks =
        app.tasks

So once we start the `App` we feed the HTML into `main` and feed the resulting
tasks into a `port` that will run them all.

docs.name: TimeApp.Simple
docs.comment:
This module makes it super simple to get started making a typical web app.
This is what you want if you are new to Elm, still getting a handle on the
syntax and patterns.

It is designed to work perfectly with [the Elm Architecture][arch] which
describes a simple architecture pattern that makes testing and refactoring
shockingly pleasant. Definitely read [the tutorial][arch] to get started!

[arch]: https://github.com/evancz/elm-architecture-tutorial/

# Start your Application
@docs start, Config

aliases.name: Config
aliases.comment:
The configuration has three key components:

  * `model` — a big chunk of data fully describing your application.

  * `view` — a way to show your model on screen. It takes in two
    arguments. One is the model, which contains *all* the information about our
    app. The other is an [`Address`][address] that helps us handle user input.
    Whenever there is a click or key press, we send a message to the address
    describing what happened and where.

  * `update` — a function to update your model. Whenever a UI event
    occurs, is routed through the `Address` to this update function. We take
    in the message, the time, and the current model, then we give back a new model!

[The Elm Architecture][arch] augments this basic pattern to give you all the
modularity you want. But since we have whole model in one place, it is
also really easy to support features like *save* and *undo* that can be quite
hard in other languages.

[address]: http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/2.0.1/Signal#Mailbox
[arch]: https://github.com/evancz/elm-architecture-tutorial/
aliases.type: { model : model , view : Signal.Address action -> model -> Html.Html , update : action -> Time.Time -> model -> model }

values.name: start
values.comment:
This starts up your application. The following code sets up a counter
that can be incremented and decremented. The time between events is also displayed.
You can read more about writing programs like this
[here](https://github.com/evancz/elm-architecture-tutorial/).

    import Html exposing (div, button, text)
    import Html.Events exposing (onClick)
    import TimeApp.Simple as TimeApp
    import StartTime


    main =
      TimeApp.start { model = model, view = view, update = update }


    model =
      { count = 0
      , prevEventTime = StartTime.startTime
      , eventTime = StartTime.startTime
      }


    view address model =
      let
        secondsAgo = toString <| (model.eventTime - model.prevEventTime ) / 1000.0
      in
        div []
          [ button [ onClick address Decrement ] [ text "-" ]
          , div [] [ text <| (toString model.count) ++ ". Previously changed " ++ secondsAgo ++ " seconds ago" ]
          , button [ onClick address Increment ] [ text "+" ]
          , div [] [ ]
          ]


    type Action = Increment | Decrement


    update action time model =
      case action of
        Increment -> {count = model.count + 1, eventTime = time, prevEventTime = model.eventTime}
        Decrement -> {count = model.count - 1, eventTime = time, prevEventTime = model.eventTime}

Notice that the program cleanly breaks up into model, update, and view.
This means it is super easy to test your update logic independent of any
rendering.
